componenttextpreview: We announced at the end of last year, we were running about 50%-plus. Those operating rates have continued to improve throughout the first quarter. And the last rates, I would say, we're running about 2/3 capacity, overall, across the entire company, not
componenttext: We announced at the end of last year, we were running about 50%-plus. Those operating rates have continued to improve throughout the first quarter. And the last rates, I would say, we're running about 2/3 capacity, overall, across the entire company, not just flat-rolled.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Luke Folta with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Luke Folta with Longbow Research.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I got a couple on titanium. Just firstly, can you give us a feel for how the certification process is coming along at Utah? And also, maybe some color on when you -- or some timing around when you might bring Albany back?
componenttext: I got a couple on titanium. Just firstly, can you give us a feel for how the certification process is coming along at Utah? And also, maybe some color on when you -- or some timing around when you might bring Albany back?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: On the certification process, there's two things that have to happen. One is that the flat has to be up where we consider it operating at the standard practices, meaning, repeatable practices that have been fine-tuned to what we would consider then a prac
componenttext: On the certification process, there's two things that have to happen. One is that the flat has to be up where we consider it operating at the standard practices, meaning, repeatable practices that have been fine-tuned to what we would consider then a practice that we would certify. And so this first part of the year, we're working on optimizing those practices for unoptimized products. So the certification process doesn't begin until we have standard processes in place, a standard process that would be used across all of our 36 -- not chipsets, but production sets. So the first step in this is to get the process standardized, standardized work, if you will. Then the second part of that is determined by producing a lot of material in different sizes, mostly small sizes that we will use in different kinds of applications, that we will certify those applications before it goes into anything in a jet engine. And so that process usually takes another year. So we're really talking about getting this plant to full certification in the next 18 months.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And Albany?
componenttext: And Albany?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Albany depends on the market. There's lots of opportunities that are programmed opportunities that, if any of those particularly hit with us, we'll be looking hard at the Albany plant. Albany plant is our swing plant and it's in good shape. It's warm, it'
componenttext: Albany depends on the market. There's lots of opportunities that are programmed opportunities that, if any of those particularly hit with us, we'll be looking hard at the Albany plant. Albany plant is our swing plant and it's in good shape. It's warm, it's ready to go. The workforce, I'm sure they would like to be back into operation. We don't need it today. And so when that time comes, outside of where we are, and that really has got more to do with project work than where we are today, that plant could come back into operation quickly at any time.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, secondly, just when we think about titanium spot prices, we're starting to see evidence that we can start to see some uptick here. When should we expect that to start flowing through your realizations in the high-performance Metals segment, unde
componenttext: And then, secondly, just when we think about titanium spot prices, we're starting to see evidence that we can start to see some uptick here. When should we expect that to start flowing through your realizations in the high-performance Metals segment, understanding that you have some contracts that are indexed and also lead times extending and all that. Can you just give us a feel from when the trough is likely to be realized there?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the trough for the year has been realized. I think when you look at what our surcharge mechanisms are, as I mentioned in my comments, in our High Performance Metals business, we do not raise our indices at the ATI all back operations until a
componenttext: Well, I think the trough for the year has been realized. I think when you look at what our surcharge mechanisms are, as I mentioned in my comments, in our High Performance Metals business, we do not raise our indices at the ATI all back operations until at the end of the quarter or the beginning of the next quarter. So while we were producing in the first quarter, whatever the indexings were on January 1, that's what the indexes would have been on March 31. So first of all, those indexes, as was publicly announced, are all up. So you can see the prices going up now. Secondly, those same industries for materials are used in our contractual methods, so all prices are up. So I would say, the first quarter is the bottom, and we're going to see prices increasing.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Timna Tanners with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Timna Tanners with UBS.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about lead times extending out, and I missed it maybe. But can you quantify that a little bit more and kind of talk about the trend that you mentioned through the quarter and how that progress with regard to lead times utilization?
componenttext: You talked about lead times extending out, and I missed it maybe. But can you quantify that a little bit more and kind of talk about the trend that you mentioned through the quarter and how that progress with regard to lead times utilization?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as the quarter goes up, what I said was that lead times in our High Performance Metals, which is -- excluding the exotic metals, which has not had a good start, as I mentioned, that's going to, I think, begin to see more activity in the second half
componenttext: Well, as the quarter goes up, what I said was that lead times in our High Performance Metals, which is -- excluding the exotic metals, which has not had a good start, as I mentioned, that's going to, I think, begin to see more activity in the second half of the year as these delayed projects start to come back online, and we can reopen those bits and those quotes. But in the High Performance Metal section, our lead times have been expanding as we move throughout the quarter. So depending on the product area, it's two to eight weeks longer than it was at the first of the year. So depending on how far downstream you want to go into a bar or a shape versus, say, an ingot. Those product schedules are out on a considerable basis. I think I also mentioned that we're basically full at the current utilization rates for the second quarter. So you keep moving those out, which says that we'll be adding more utilization back into the business, and we'll be taking more product in the second half of the year. I think I also mentioned, I think Danny told me three times in this talk, so I'll mention it the fourth time, that we expect pricing improvements in the second half.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so my second question is, along those lines, SG&A was really light as was corporate expense. So how should we think about that going through the year as you mentioned you're going to need to perhaps add up, I guess, shifts or some sort of cost to mo
componenttext: Okay, so my second question is, along those lines, SG&A was really light as was corporate expense. So how should we think about that going through the year as you mentioned you're going to need to perhaps add up, I guess, shifts or some sort of cost to move your utilization up?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Timna, this is Rich. I think from the standpoint of SG&A, any add accruing would be in the SG&A area, be in the touch lay for the manufacturing cost areas. So I think when we look at corporate expenses, SG&A, I mean there's obviously some movement on a qu
componenttext: Timna, this is Rich. I think from the standpoint of SG&A, any add accruing would be in the SG&A area, be in the touch lay for the manufacturing cost areas. So I think when we look at corporate expenses, SG&A, I mean there's obviously some movement on a quarter-to-quarter basis, but I don't think it would be all that dramatic.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Levenson with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Levenson with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The mix right now is still about 57%, Flat-Rolled; 34%, High Performance. How do you see that changing over the course of the year?
componenttext: The mix right now is still about 57%, Flat-Rolled; 34%, High Performance. How do you see that changing over the course of the year?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think both businesses are going to go up, Steve. And I think that 60-40 relationship, in terms of tons or in terms of pounds, probably is going to remain if our Flat-Rolled Products business, which, we believe, is going to continue to move forward with
componenttext: I think both businesses are going to go up, Steve. And I think that 60-40 relationship, in terms of tons or in terms of pounds, probably is going to remain if our Flat-Rolled Products business, which, we believe, is going to continue to move forward with additional tonnage coming into it. So I don't know if the relationships -- I think they're both moving together. Our schedules have increased dramatically in our High Performance area which is, as you know, mostly aerospace and other difficult-to-produce markets, a lot of oil, oil and gas and land-based turbines, jet engines, airframe. So we would expect more profits coming out of that business, but we would also expect very good improvement in our Flat-Rolled side, too.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And for the second question, Boeing was out today saying that they're slowing deliveries of certain 787 parts to their final assembly facility. It sounds like they're shortages among some other parts. Do you think that's going to result in a spike in purc
componenttext: And for the second question, Boeing was out today saying that they're slowing deliveries of certain 787 parts to their final assembly facility. It sounds like they're shortages among some other parts. Do you think that's going to result in a spike in purchasing? Could that push guys out of their LTA limits and cause them to buy on spot rates?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think there's a couple of things that are always interesting as these things go up, and I kind of alluded to the fourth quarter conference call and other things. We talked back then about a disconnect between the supplier base and the OEMs on airframes,
componenttext: I think there's a couple of things that are always interesting as these things go up, and I kind of alluded to the fourth quarter conference call and other things. We talked back then about a disconnect between the supplier base and the OEMs on airframes, what they said they're going to make and what they were really going to do. And when we got -- as you know better than I do, when we got into December and firmed up these rates, I think there were people out there that may have been cut short someplace along the line or thought they could ramp up faster than they could. So I think, the bad news and the good news, the bad news is that they didn't order the parts where they could have got them in a smoothing type of schedule. The good news is that the business is picking up, and people are trying to do some restocking as well as keeping up with the build rates. The very good news is the build rates are going to go up. The best news is that the 787 is going to get built, and they are going to bring a lot of white tails up to sell at the end of period of time. So I think in the interim, Boeing has the time while this plan is being certified to make sure that their supply chain, in total, is in good shape to meet the rates that they said they're going to meet. And I have -- my personal bet is that they're going to meet these rates.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Gambardella with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Gambardella with JPMorgan.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Pat, I think I heard you say in your remarks earlier on that you would expect to see raw material prices go down and your base prices go up, though?
componenttext: Pat, I think I heard you say in your remarks earlier on that you would expect to see raw material prices go down and your base prices go up, though?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- when you see prices, Mike, in the stainless markets, pricing mechanisms are kind of an interesting factor into the market as, again, we saw raw material prices rise rather rapidly. But when we look at the best estimates of many of the peo
componenttext: Well, I think -- when you see prices, Mike, in the stainless markets, pricing mechanisms are kind of an interesting factor into the market as, again, we saw raw material prices rise rather rapidly. But when we look at the best estimates of many of the people that make estimates on raw materials, we still see, for example in nickel, 300 million pounds on the LME [London Metal Exchange]. So we're pretty confident, based on forecast from third parties, what we see that happened last year, other kinds of things, that will be some moderation from this rapid rise. In contrast to that, while this rapid rise in surcharges and volume has been taking place, there's been extremely little movement in base prices or on the conversion price. So the history has been, as these things level out and plateau or moderate or come down, then it's an opportunity to try to recover the prices that should be in effect for the amount of volume and market conditions on the conversion side. So my guess is that we'll see base prices move up and some moderation on the surcharge mechanisms.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just going forward, say, if we look back to the last peak in your earnings cycle back in 2007, when you made over $7 a share, $7.26, nickel prices back then hit a high, almost mid-year, $54,000 or more than twice of what they are right now. You typically
componenttext: Just going forward, say, if we look back to the last peak in your earnings cycle back in 2007, when you made over $7 a share, $7.26, nickel prices back then hit a high, almost mid-year, $54,000 or more than twice of what they are right now. You typically make a lot of money in very high nickel price environments, but if you don't expect nickel to really go up, can you give us a feel for how the amount of money that you invested since 2007 in terms of new capability, how that could offset some of the earnings loss, say, from the previous peak due to nickel prices being about half of what they are or back then?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We've continued, as you know, Mike, to work on the efficiencies and conversion cost in this business. We have a new finishing and new capabilities in our Plate business. We have new capabilities in our titanium sheet production, which is Flat-Rolled today
componenttext: We've continued, as you know, Mike, to work on the efficiencies and conversion cost in this business. We have a new finishing and new capabilities in our Plate business. We have new capabilities in our titanium sheet production, which is Flat-Rolled today. We basically have a dedicated sheet plant. We've modernized all of our cold rolling mills to state-of-the-art flatness gauge tension controls. We have improved our melt shop situation with the commodity melt shop and a specialty melt shop of both electrical steel and our nickel-based alloys and ingot casting, where we will, before the end of this year, in the second half, close a complete footprint down. So it isn't really the same company. We've been able to demonstrate over the last year, when business was really, really bad, very low utilization rates that we were still able to make some money even under the worst of market conditions. So it's a different equation as we go forward. And I think that if we had the typical rates for this typical conversion revenues for this kind of a business, coupled with normal surcharge mechanisms, we'll do just fine in that business. Rich, you might want to add what you think?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, I think the other -- your point, and we've said this publicly, I mean, first of all, the one comment about higher raw material cost in the '07 time frame. A large piece of that from an earnings standpoint was obviously offset by significant LIF
componenttext: Yes, Mike, I think the other -- your point, and we've said this publicly, I mean, first of all, the one comment about higher raw material cost in the '07 time frame. A large piece of that from an earnings standpoint was obviously offset by significant LIFO inventory reserve charges, since most of our inventory's on LIFO. But I think going forward, we would agree that we might turn out to be wrong. But we would agree that the amount of speculation that was going on in 2007 that drove raw material costs high, that those levels is unlikely to repeat itself. But what we do believe is that, in addition, all the cost reductions that Pat has alluded to and the capabilities we have from a manufacturing and a capacity standpoint, the amount of business and focus that we have globally, the diversification of the company, the capacities and the value-add focus that we have, we do believe that those kind of earnings that we achieved in the last cycle are achievable in the next cycle in just a different way. They won't be driven by some of the raw material cost volatility. It will be driven by higher value-added products, a different cost structure, increased volume. One of the things that we've said that we didn't have in place in 2007 that we will have in place as these markets grow going forward is the capability of producing 60 million pounds of titanium mill products in the kind of a product mix focus that we want that we didn't have that capability before. And with the 787 ramp up in the industrial markets and the use of titanium in oil and gas, those opportunities, we believe, will be there. And in addition, we think in that time period, we'll begin to see some of the demand growth from some markets that really weren't present in 2007 like nuclear.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So with the, say, the current level of nickel prices or about half of where they were back then, you feel you could still reach that $7.26 in earnings?
componenttext: So with the, say, the current level of nickel prices or about half of where they were back then, you feel you could still reach that $7.26 in earnings?

componenttext: Our view in the next three, three-plus years, we think that's achievable, yes. For all the reasons that Pat and I have just articulated.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the $375 million, how much of it is going to Rowley, Utah, how much of it is going to Brackenridge? And then, as you look forward to 2011, what do you see as a more likely number?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the $375 million, how much of it is going to Rowley, Utah, how much of it is going to Brackenridge? And then, as you look forward to 2011, what do you see as a more likely number?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Rowley will be finishing up here, largely from a cash expenditure standpoint in the first half. And then the timing of the spend, as we begin ramping up the hot rolling and processing facility investment, will begin in more earnest ways here in the
componenttext: Well, Rowley will be finishing up here, largely from a cash expenditure standpoint in the first half. And then the timing of the spend, as we begin ramping up the hot rolling and processing facility investment, will begin in more earnest ways here in the second half. And that matches up with the completion of some of the big projects, Rowley and the melt shop consolidation, et cetera, that we've been talking about. So as we look at the $375 million, more than half of that is expected to be focused in 2010 on the hot mill and processing facility. And as you know, that's roughly a four-year project. So as we look going forward, we would expect the kind of capital expenditure level of $350 million to $400 million to continue for the next several years until the hot mill project is complete. And we have the capability, because of how we're structuring that project, to speed it up or slow it down a little bit, depending upon what business circumstances are. But it's certainly our strong desire to complete that project and have it up and running before the end of 2013.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the use of the $560 million in cash and less revolver availability, what are you guys thinking strategically? Pension paid out, or I don't know, acquisitions, deleveraging? What are you thinking in terms of the use of that liquidity?
componenttext: And then in terms of the use of the $560 million in cash and less revolver availability, what are you guys thinking strategically? Pension paid out, or I don't know, acquisitions, deleveraging? What are you thinking in terms of the use of that liquidity?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think we'll have -- we don't believe we'll have a need to do anymore pension funding. We think that the pension was the actions that we took last year and the years before that. And hopefully, the smart asset allocation we have that we'll be
componenttext: Well, I don't think we'll have -- we don't believe we'll have a need to do anymore pension funding. We think that the pension was the actions that we took last year and the years before that. And hopefully, the smart asset allocation we have that we'll be able to not be in the position to have to put significant amounts in there. The other thing, as you know, we look at cash deployment in a balanced way. So certainly, we focus on what our obligations are to take care of them, and we fund managed working capital to grow earnings, which we did here in the first quarter and capital investments and the dividend policy. And if we have something left over, I think we've demonstrated in the past, that we look for the best ways to create shareholder value with that excess cash and free cash flow. So fundamentally, we don't have a different viewpoint today than we've always had. We do like the fact that we have an untapped credit facility of $400 million, and we like that sitting there, as well as a reasonable amount of cash on the balance sheet at any point in time so that we maintain financial flexibility to do things that are in the best interest of our shareholders. And that's the philosophy we operate to.

componenttext: With regard to the nickel alloy affecting prices in the High Performance Metals, just looking at the sequential decline, and Pat, I was wondering if you might be able to comment on it, just kind of thinking that a lot of improvements come from the engine side. headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's been some pretty interesting price competition on the nickel side of the business. But as the volumes go forward and lead times extend out, I think you're going to see less of some of the earlier pricing pressures. So we would expect
componenttext: Well, I think there's been some pretty interesting price competition on the nickel side of the business. But as the volumes go forward and lead times extend out, I think you're going to see less of some of the earlier pricing pressures. So we would expect in the surcharge mechanism, again, remember, we do it only once every three months, though, the second quarter has already had a price increase on all products shipping out from April, May and June. If the prices of nickel stay where they are, we'll see another price increase in the third quarter again. So you're going to see pricing move up there, and you're going to see volumes. Since the lead times are moving up, volume moving up also. So I think this is a market that's just under recovery, Brian, not really declining. I think we've probably seen the worst of it.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

componenttext: And one of your competitors yesterday said that they're seeing the lower end of nickel alloy market picking up quite a bit more. Is that an area that you're trying to capture or retain share? And could mix have been part of the contributing factor in Q1?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think there is. We're in an industrial market, in the oil and gas markets, as well as the jet engine and other markets. So as at that market is getting strengths, as we pointed out earlier in our comments, you might see some differential in pricing. But
componenttext: I think there is. We're in an industrial market, in the oil and gas markets, as well as the jet engine and other markets. So as at that market is getting strengths, as we pointed out earlier in our comments, you might see some differential in pricing. But I think, as the build rates continue now to be confirmed and are secure, and in fact, projected to increase, then we'll see a larger percentage of the business coming back toward jet engines and that there should be some self correcting in that also.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to get a bit of clarification on your comments earlier about an active versus a hot-idle capacity. In terms of taking from a 2/3 available to full availability, is it a matter of labor and adding additional shifts? Or are there additional things yo
componenttext: I want to get a bit of clarification on your comments earlier about an active versus a hot-idle capacity. In terms of taking from a 2/3 available to full availability, is it a matter of labor and adding additional shifts? Or are there additional things you have to do to raise equipment up time?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: It is a matter of orderly bringing people back and orderly bringing up production. In our company, we bring shifts back, we do reorientation, safety training, reorientation with the equipment, quality training. And so, it takes a period of time to bring a
componenttext: It is a matter of orderly bringing people back and orderly bringing up production. In our company, we bring shifts back, we do reorientation, safety training, reorientation with the equipment, quality training. And so, it takes a period of time to bring a shift back up, get people back and familiar with the jobs, move it in into production and then move it up. It doesn't happen in just one week to next week because the 2009 has been a severe-enough reduction that coming back in requires us to go through the full element of training and safety. So it is people and shifts.

componenttext: I think on the Flat-Rolled side or on the stainless side, that's always a potential factor. And I think we would have an even stronger view of that, that being the case, on the nickel alloy side and High Performance Metals. And I think he predicted that what we're seeing now we would see, and that's what we're seeing.

componenttext: One of the comments that I made, just to clarify, is that we have improved our forward loads throughout the first quarter, and that those loads continue improve as we're now moving through the second quarter. So the market is recovering, and I think we did go through a period of some very, very competitive pricing and some changing around of shares and some changing around of contractual arrangements. And that disruptiveness sometimes creates different kinds of reactions that usually gets solved as the market gets stronger and moves forward.

componenttext: Although, Kuni, I would add that your question about customer hedging behavior. I think it is safe to say that unless it's a very specific, more project-oriented business, that customers do not appear to be willing or eager to hedge with nickel at the current level. They think it's going to correct down. So there was more desire when nickel was at $8 than may be hedged than there is at $11 to $12.

componenttextpreview: We've had some interesting times. We've seen some depressed markets. But as we've had contractual arrangements with several of our major accounts, our shipments have been the same or relatively flat throughout 2009, and they were up 4% in the first quarte
componenttext: We've had some interesting times. We've seen some depressed markets. But as we've had contractual arrangements with several of our major accounts, our shipments have been the same or relatively flat throughout 2009, and they were up 4% in the first quarter. So we have an interesting situations, where we still have occasions where people are looking for a particular product because they need it right now. In other occasions, they're running out of warehouse material that they bought that they're using up or working down their inventories. So I would say, our earlier comments that we believe that market is about flat for us is what we would say, although, we had about a 4% increase in the first quarter.

componenttextpreview: I'm trying to get a handle on where the High Performance margins can go from here through the year. You mentioned surcharges up strongly in Q2 sequentially. I got, if I look at my model, it looks like they're up 25% to 30% versus Q1 at nickel. You mention
componenttext: I'm trying to get a handle on where the High Performance margins can go from here through the year. You mentioned surcharges up strongly in Q2 sequentially. I got, if I look at my model, it looks like they're up 25% to 30% versus Q1 at nickel. You mentioned lead times are extending, et cetera. On the other hand, you didn't take a LIFO-reserve charge this quarter, and I assume that's because you assume these element prices will retrench through the year. But let's just say they stay where they are today, across all of the products, how should we think about margins? Are we going to see expansion from here? Or has any expansion on the increased volume and surcharge rise going to be offset by LIFO?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're in pretty good shape on the High Performance side of the company. I'm going to let Rich go through the technical explanation of how we look at LIFO and how we look at these margins. We said we thought that these prices, on the nickel side, w
componenttext: I think we're in pretty good shape on the High Performance side of the company. I'm going to let Rich go through the technical explanation of how we look at LIFO and how we look at these margins. We said we thought that these prices, on the nickel side, would moderate in the second half, hears lots of people predicting that. But basically, rising nickel in the end and all, at least as it's going up, should be good for us as we move forward. Go ahead, Rich.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when you look specifically at High Performance Metals and the impact on LIFO, obviously, you can't just look at nickel. You also have to look at titanium and titanium sponge, and you know what the public comments are about the contractual ent
componenttext: Yes, I think when you look specifically at High Performance Metals and the impact on LIFO, obviously, you can't just look at nickel. You also have to look at titanium and titanium sponge, and you know what the public comments are about the contractual enterprises year-over-year. So that, combined with mix, becomes pretty, pretty big drivers of a LIFO assumption. I think that as -- you know how we do LIFO. I mean, we are projecting what we believe our year-end cost will be, year end being based upon our inventory turns, essentially the last quarter of the year across the businesses by individual pool, to come up with a current-year index, and that apply to the LIFO calculation. And the projection of year-end LIFO inventory determines what the full year LIFO reduction or increase on the reserve will be, and then we take that ratably on a quarterly basis. So we'll update that every quarter. Our view here at the end of the first quarter is that, as we've said, that raw material cost will moderate. To the extent that they don't, obviously, that would be impacted in our revised assumption as we go on, on a quarterly basis. Having said that, to the extent that they don't, I think that you'll see FIFO [first-in, first-out] profits increase as well. So how that plays against the LIFO-reserve change would remain to be seen. But I don't think, at this point in time, it would be a significant driver in one way or another, but we'll see. It all depends on what raw material costs do.

componenttext: On share account, why wouldn't we be seeing the dilutive effect of the convertible debt? headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the question on the share count and the impact on the convertible. First of all, we're governed obviously by the accounting rules in terms of how to deal with the diluted calculation on the convertible, and it's very fact specific depending upon the
componenttext: Yes, the question on the share count and the impact on the convertible. First of all, we're governed obviously by the accounting rules in terms of how to deal with the diluted calculation on the convertible, and it's very fact specific depending upon the company. So the drivers of that for us are the earnings, obviously; the tax rate; and the interest expense on the convertible, that's flowing through the income statement on a quarterly basis. And in our case, that's also impacted by the fact that we capitalized a portion of our total interest expense under the accounting rules because of the construction and progress on our long-term capital projects. So the bottom line is, when you put all of those factors in as it pertains to ATI, on a quarterly basis, using the 98 million share count, which excludes the convertible effect, basically, our earnings per share has to be at or about $0.25 a share in the quarter before the convertible issuance is considered dilutive. So because we're below $0.25, if we were above that, then we would have had to assume that the convertible shares were in fact converted, which would increase our diluted shares up to about 108 million shares. But then we would also have to add back to the reported GAAP net income a portion of the interest expense that's associated with that converted, because the convert assumes that equity, not debt. But we would have to adjust that for the amount of prorated amount of interest that we've capitalized. So that's a long answer. But the real impact, the real threshold, is if you're add or below $0.25 a share using the 98 million shares, it would be anti-dilutive and therefore not included.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then the second question is on the Flat-Rolled revenue and the outlook there.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The outlook is positive. Lead times, again, have moved in this business. Schedules are filling virtually across all of our product lines on Flat-Rolled. I do believe there's some restocking going on as people are surprised, maybe, by some of the things th
componenttext: The outlook is positive. Lead times, again, have moved in this business. Schedules are filling virtually across all of our product lines on Flat-Rolled. I do believe there's some restocking going on as people are surprised, maybe, by some of the things that they've seen they've run out. They want to not only meet their current poll for their materials, but there is some restocking into the system. That especially happens if there's any schedule in increases. Now we've been able to bring back capacity in this business rather soon. We've been able to move up our melt shop schedules, move our hot rolling schedules up a bit, run some overtime quickly in the finishing end. So there is still capacity to go, but we're looking to -- we're looking in our basic products to get up to that in the stainless steel sheet and plate, to get up around 350,000 tons. And then with the specialty products making up the other 40% more of that business, we would expect that if this trends all hold together, and this recovery stays on track that it's on now, that we're going to see quarter-on-quarter improvement, quarter-on-quarter more tonnage to we're back to full utilizations or utilizations that we consider at practical capacity. So this is a pretty good recovery on the Flat-Rolled side that we've seen over the last 90 days.

componenttext: I don't think we all has -- like I said, we bring back people back in. We have to train. We have some shuffling around to do. But basically, we're talking about equipment that's been kept in good shape. We're not talking about -- we've already restarted all of the full capacity of our two major melt shops. We have some capacity in the specialty metals to bring back up, but that's not expensive start up. So I don't see we'll have anything that would be material or major at this point going forward in start-up costs.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's a good index out there, John, any place. This is what you can buy from a scrap dealer. So there is. I can tell you that the prices have moved up dramatically from the fourth quarter continuing to move up through the end of the first
componenttext: I don't think there's a good index out there, John, any place. This is what you can buy from a scrap dealer. So there is. I can tell you that the prices have moved up dramatically from the fourth quarter continuing to move up through the end of the first quarter. And there is some availability issues today with one supplier having to solve some quality problems and just the availability of material assets as the cycle picks back up. So I think, in our particular case, we're glad to have the availability to us or the opportunity to move more sponge production and if we choose to versus the scrap market. Other thing I think to consider is that, as the programs of Boeing have some near-net size kind of production coming out of Russia today, that, that scrap that used to be in the U.S. is now held in Russia, not coming to the U.S., at least that portion of it. So it's an interesting game that is changing from dealer to dealer from week to week.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that we're under contract with our major customers. And so our shipments, as I pointed out, were actually up 4%. But I think the market itself is not robust in any sense of the word. There is some specific areas that requires specific products
componenttext: I would say that we're under contract with our major customers. And so our shipments, as I pointed out, were actually up 4%. But I think the market itself is not robust in any sense of the word. There is some specific areas that requires specific products of grain oriented that are pulling. But I think, basically, it's a flat market right now, maybe declining even in total in the industry. Around the world, the market's up. That's for sure. The global market would be higher when we consider India and China and other parts of the world. So we put it all together. I'd say the world market is bigger. There is more supply there than what they're used to be. But U.S. market has yet to recover back to the levels that we would like to see.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Q2 will be somewhere in the same range as Q1, maybe a little bit less, as we continue to ramp up. The number will continue to go down each quarter in 2010, as we begin to produce and grow the production of sponge. And we'll be then at a cost leve
componenttext: I think, Q2 will be somewhere in the same range as Q1, maybe a little bit less, as we continue to ramp up. The number will continue to go down each quarter in 2010, as we begin to produce and grow the production of sponge. And we'll be then at a cost level that we think is a reasonable standard cost, and therefore, we'll be valuing the sponge in inventory at that level. Until then, basically in the first quarter, all the costs, pretty much all the costs associated with the sponge facility in the first quarter, hit P&L as start-up cost. It'll be somewhat less than that in the second quarter. It will be less than that even more in the third, and finally in the fourth, we wouldn't expect any.

[Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Dan Greenfield, Director, Investor Relations and Corporate Communications. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keisha. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Allegheny Technologies Earnings Conference Call for the First Quarter 2010. This conference call is being broadcast on our website at www.atimetals.com. Members of the media had been invited to listen
componenttext:
Thank you, Keisha. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Allegheny Technologies Earnings Conference Call for the First Quarter 2010. This conference call is being broadcast on our website at www.atimetals.com. Members of the media had been invited to listen to this call. Participating in the call today are Pat Hassey, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rich Harshman, Executive Vice President, Finance and Chief Financial Officer.
All references to net income and earnings in this conference call mean net income and earnings attributable to ATI. After some initial comments, we will ask for questions. During the question-and-answer session, please limit yourself to two questions to be considerate of others on the line. Please note that all forward-looking statements this afternoon are subject to various assumptions and caveats as noted in the earnings release. Actual results may differ materially. Here is Pat Hassey.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and thanks to everyone for joining today's call. Let's start by discussing our first quarter performance and some positive implications for our business going forward. Sales were up 10% over last quarter to approximately $900 million. Apples-
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and thanks to everyone for joining today's call. Let's start by discussing our first quarter performance and some positive implications for our business going forward. Sales were up 10% over last quarter to approximately $900 million. Apples-to-apples, earnings were up from last quarter's $0.10 per share, excluding $0.26 of positive LIFO, to $0.24 per share without the healthcare legislation charge, or 140%. 
Shipments of most of our products increased, the one exception being, exotic alloys, in many cases, by double digits compared to the fourth quarter of 2009. More importantly, overall order receipts were up significantly causing lead times to extend by an additional two to eight weeks for High Performance Metals. Again, exotic alloys being the exception. Asset utilization rates increased throughout the first quarter, with the highest utilization being in March. These are all signs that we are recovering from the global contraction that impacted our business in 2009. 
In our business, recovery begins with volume, which improves capacity utilization. We are seeing continued positive signs, recovery and improving volume, second quarter production schedules are basically booked full at our current utilization, rates, lead times are extending and scrap is in short supply. Based on these continued market conditions, we believe there may be opportunities for improving base prices in the second half of 2010 as the business cycle continues to recover. 
Raw material surcharges for the second quarter shipments will be higher due to rising material costs. However, in our Flat-Rolled Products segment, base prices for many products, particularly stainless sheet and plate, remain low because of these rapidly rising material surcharges. The customers' total transaction price is up, but the base or conversion price is still very low. 
We believe we could see some moderation of raw material prices, coupled with increasing base prices, in the second half of 2010. These are all signs that a true business cycle recovery is underway. With steady quarter-on-quarter improvement, we continue to see 2010 as a transition year to resumption of secular growth in our key markets.
One more point, our direct international sales increased to approximately 34% of sales in the first quarter 2010. Today, ATI is more globally focused than ever before. A particularly important note, our Flat-Rolled Products segment achieved a record 35% of direct international sales in the first quarter of 2010. Our International business is recovering. An example, first quarter 2010 order entry from Asia is more than 3x the order level of the first quarter of 2009. Overall, our order book increased throughout the first quarter and continues to grow in the second quarter. 
Of note and comment is ATI's total first quarter titanium mill product shipments. This includes our High Performance Metals, plus Flat-Rolled Products, plus Uniti joint venture conversion. Total titanium mill product shipments for the first three months 2010 were 9.2 million pounds. We now believe we will ship over 40 million pounds of titanium products in 2010, so stay tuned for more as we go forward in this market.
Moving to our segments, all figures are comparisons of the first quarter of 2010 to the fourth quarter 2009 since this is the most current indication of cyclical recovery. In our High Performance Metals segment, shipments of our titanium-based alloys increased 17%. Shipments of our nickel-based alloys, superalloys and specialty alloys increased 7%. This increase follows a 21% improvement in the fourth quarter of 2009 from the third quarter of 2009. 
Jet engine supply chain has begun to recover as demand continues to build. After reducing inventories in 2009, the supply chain is becoming more in line with current aircraft build rates and increasing aftermarket demand. In addition, the jet engine supply chain appears to be more confident that the aircraft build rates are secure and may increase going forward. 
Inquiry rates and orders for our premium titanium alloys, nickel-based alloys and superalloys and specialty alloys point to sustained improvement. Prices for many of our products are now beginning to increase as lead times are extending and this should benefit, again, the second half shipments of 2010. 
We're also seeing increased activity from the oil and gas and medical markets. Shipments of our exotic alloys in the first quarter decreased substantially due to delayed, but not canceled, projects in the defense and chemical processing industries during 2009. We entered 2009 with the strong backlog for our exotic alloys. 
After the global financial issues hit, the backlog was worked down over the last year. This is a business that historically lags the economy by about six months, both up and down. Order increase for exotic alloys are just now beginning to increase, so we do expect shipments to gradually improve in the second half of 2010.
Operating profit in our High Performance Metals segment was approximately 22% of sales, excluding the idle facilities and new sponge facilities start-up costs of nearly $10 million in the first quarter. This is not where we want to be. 
So where are we? First, our Titanium and Nickel-based Alloys business did quite well in market share and volume improvements. On the other hand, our Exotic Alloys business did not perform anywhere near our 2009 levels because of delayed projects and programs. Operating profit in our High Performance Metals segment was negatively impacted by $9.9 million of startup in idle facility costs, mostly associated with our Raleigh, Utah plant and the Albany, Oregon titanium sponge facilities. 
Lastly, in the High Performance Metals segment, in our pricing mechanisms, we adjust raw material surcharges at the end of each quarter, not during the quarter. So we expect to benefit from higher raw material indices in the second quarter.
Now moving to our Flat-Rolled Products segment. First quarter shipments of our high-value flat-rolled products increased 12% compared to the fourth quarter of 2009. Here's some highlights: Shipments of our Engineered and Precision-Rolled Strip products improved 15%. Demand is recovering from the global automotive market. In the construction market, orders reached near-historic highs for high-efficiency gas furnaces, there's some stimulus money. Demand from the aerospace and electronics markets continue to improve. In addition, we are just beginning to realize initial growth from our STAL expansion in China. 
Shipments of our grain-oriented electrical steel products to the global electrical energy market increased 4%. Shipments of our flat-rolled nickel alloys and specialty stainless alloys increased 34% due to increased activity, with some restocking in the oil and gas, electrical energy and aerospace distribution markets. 
First quarter's shipments of our flat-rolled titanium products, including Uniti, improved to 3.1 million pounds. First quarter shipments of our standard stainless sheet and plate products are up 22% compared to the fourth quarter 2009 and up 54% compared to the first quarter 2009, at or about 78,000 tons. 78,000 tons, annualized, puts us within the 300,000 to 350,000 tons we need to effectively pace our operations. 
We saw steady improvements in efficiency from volume each month in the first quarter. Giving us more confidence in this market, industry data reflects service center inventories remained at 2.5 months, which is still the historical low. Meanwhile, average base prices are still very low, while surcharges are rising. The benchmark 304 stainless surcharge will be $1.10 in May and is expected to rise to approximately $1.25 in June based on current monthly average raw material prices. 
Engineered Products segment was profitable in the first quarter, as we continue to see improving conditions for many of our products, particularly in the oil and gas market due to increasing demand for our tungsten drilling products. 
Today, I would like to focus on two of our key markets. First, aerospace and defense and second, oil and gas. We believe these markets are not only showing signs of recovery, but we're seeing early signs of secular growth. In the aerospace market, sentiment changed dramatically in late February and into March. Boeing and Airbus both announced that they are not cutting current aircraft production schedules, but instead they plan to increase production in 2010 and '11. Refer to our last conference call a quarter ago. 
Airbus plans to increase production in their single-aisle 320 series later this year. Boeing plans to increase production in their 777 and newly upgraded 747-8 aircraft during the next two years. In addition, Boeing continues to report that flight test of their new 787 Dreamliner and upgraded 787 are going well. First deliveries are expected by the end of 2010. 
Last week, Boeing said they plan to make an announcement during the second quarter regarding a possible increase to their 737 single-aisle production rates. And by the end of this year, both commercial airframe makers plan and decide on, first, a new single aisle, or an updated re-engine of their existing single-aisle aircraft. 
We liked the way ATI is positioned to benefit from these aircraft production rate increases of both legacy and the new airplanes. We also are very well positioned to benefit from the next generation airframe and jet engine programs. First, both engines and airframes are big parts of our business. We have had strategic relationships with most of the key players. We have continued to improve the strategic position with new and expanded long-term contracts and with innovative new products. We have new and unsurpassed manufacturing capabilities, which, when coupled with our innovative new products, enable us to grow faster as well as larger in this growing aerospace and defense market sector. 
We like the sector trends, particularly the trend to new lightweight aircraft powered by innovative new engines. We like the trend to near net shapes, which helps our customers improve their buy-to-fly ratio, improve their parts-making productivity and reduce their cost of making parts. Near net shapes also provide ATI the opportunity to do more value-added processing through both our Flat-Rolled Products and Long Products businesses. For example, certain titanium long product near net shapes. 
We start by melting the raw materials into an ingot, forging a billet, hot rolling a bar and then hot rolling a shape. We sell the ingots, we sell the billets, we sell the bars and we sell further value-added near net shapes. In the rock products, mill products, near net shapes begin with melting raw materials to an ingot for long products, or slab for flat-rolled products. We like this trend. 
International aerospace market continues to grow. Going out further in the decade, the new Comac, Bombardier and Mitsubishi have announced plans to introduce new aircraft that use future-generation jet engines that are under development, such as GE's LeapX and Pratt & Whitney's Geared Turbo Fan. 
Also, ATI will continue to benefit from the new designs in future airframes, or from modifications and redesigns in existing airframes that use our specialty alloys, as well as from the re-engine of legacy aircraft. Our specialty metals are being put on the front of the wagon, while other's materials are rolling off the back. Lastly, the need to up armor and lightweight land-based military vehicles opens new doors through design for our latest alloys and products to protect our service men and women. 
Now turning to the Oil and Gas markets. The world continues to use and need more energy, as developing and advanced nations grow their per capita GDP and their citizens move to modern conveniences and life improvement. According to a respected industry source, to meet growing global demand, "We need to find and get into production one new Saudi Arabia every three years."  
Oil and gas exploration has moved to extremely demanding locations, such as deepwater offshore and to unconventional sources, such as shale gas and LNG deep in the earth. These environments require the strong and highly corrosive resistant alloys that we have invented and make today. 
Here are some facts that indicate ATI's first quarter 2010 penetration and performance in this oil and gas market. Sales to this market increased by nearly 50% compared to a year ago, and increased by approximately 25% compared to the fourth quarter 2009. Nearly 50% of our first quarter sales to the oil and gas market were direct international sales. It's a global market for us. We not only like the growth in rig count, we also like the faster-than-ten growth in wells associated with shale gas and high-pressure, high-temperature exploration and production. 
Offshore projects continue to be engineered around the globe. And ATI is well positioned to benefit. We're improving our position with our existing key customers, adding new customers, becoming more global and seeing good growth in our innovative products, such as our family of super duplex and lean duplex stainless alloys, for umbilical subsea applications and top-side applications, in our Data 2 [Datalloy 2] non-magnetic specialty alloy for drill strings and horizontal drilling, particularly in shale gas. We expect our shipments to the oil and gas market to continue to improve and to grow throughout 2010.
Finally, a quick update on our remaining strategic capital projects. We are pleased with the startup of our Rowley, Utah premium titanium sponge facility. We're operating more reduction furnaces and developing standard processes. This is a very big project, so we plan to ramp up the production throughout 2010 in a systematic manner. 
The melt shop consolidation at our Brackenridge, Pennsylvania specialty melt shop is progressing on schedule. We reduced the footprint, and we expect considerable cost savings and its production efficiencies from this project when it is fully operational later this year. We expect to benefit by up to $30 million of annualized cost reductions associated with this project, again, beginning in the second half of 2010. 
We are now in the critical final vendor selection process for our Brackenridge, Pennsylvania advanced hot-rolling and processing facility. All permits are in hand. The site preparation work is nearly completed. Overall, we expect 2010 capital investments to be approximately $375 million. 
Before we open the call to questions, a final comment. First of all, our first quarter performance, operating performance, as well as execution, as well as improving order entry for most of our products, reinforces our view that 2010 will be a year of steady, quarter-on-quarter improvement. We continue to believe 2010 is the transition year from 2009's global contraction to the resumption of secular growth trends previously achieved in our key global markets. 
We expect to recover and then grow faster than our core global markets because we have an improved market position as demonstrated by our improving volume and forward load, new customers and expanded LTAs, innovative new product offerings, new and technically advanced manufacturing capabilities, and finally, a globally focused reach that, combined with the solid reputation of ATI and a solid international customer base in our key growth markets, allows us to grow rapidly. 
I think with those comments, operator, we'll now open up the call for any questions.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of David Martin with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about the stainless steel market. Can you just give us a bit more color on this business and its competitive landscape today? And I'm curious as to whether you've sacrificed some market share in this business, as I think your shipments
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about the stainless steel market. Can you just give us a bit more color on this business and its competitive landscape today? And I'm curious as to whether you've sacrificed some market share in this business, as I think your shipments were up a little over 20% quarter-over-quarter, I think NAS [North American Stainless] reported volume growth in excess of 50% last night.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: This depends on how far down you're starting from, I guess. But no, we haven't sacrificed a lot of share. We're concentrating more on the value-added products. We mentioned here, I think, very clearly that our Oil and Gas business is growing rapidly. We'r
componenttext: This depends on how far down you're starting from, I guess. But no, we haven't sacrificed a lot of share. We're concentrating more on the value-added products. We mentioned here, I think, very clearly that our Oil and Gas business is growing rapidly. We're shipping a lot more product on an international basis than what we have in the past. So if you want to come back to exactly general distribution, or what is the product mix, what kinds of things are you doing, I would say that you're going to continue to see us growing in this business again. We mentioned in my comments that we need 300,000 to 350,000 tons of base load and sheet plate. We're going to generate that 300,000 to 350,000 tons. We're around 320,000 annualized in the first quarter, it will be better in the second quarter. Our prediction is it'll get better in the third quarter and better in the fourth quarter. We don't want much more than that, on those products.
