componenttextpreview: We announced at the end of last year, we were running about 50%-plus. Those operating rates have continued to improve throughout the first quarter. And the last rates, I would say, we're running about 2/3 capacity, overall, across the entire company, not
componenttext: We announced at the end of last year, we were running about 50%-plus. Those operating rates have continued to improve throughout the first quarter. And the last rates, I would say, we're running about 2/3 capacity, overall, across the entire company, not just flat-rolled.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Luke Folta with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Luke Folta with Longbow Research.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I got a couple on titanium. Just firstly, can you give us a feel for how the certification process is coming along at Utah? And also, maybe some color on when you -- or some timing around when you might bring Albany back?
componenttext: I got a couple on titanium. Just firstly, can you give us a feel for how the certification process is coming along at Utah? And also, maybe some color on when you -- or some timing around when you might bring Albany back?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: On the certification process, there's two things that have to happen. One is that the flat has to be up where we consider it operating at the standard practices, meaning, repeatable practices that have been fine-tuned to what we would consider then a prac
componenttext: On the certification process, there's two things that have to happen. One is that the flat has to be up where we consider it operating at the standard practices, meaning, repeatable practices that have been fine-tuned to what we would consider then a practice that we would certify. And so this first part of the year, we're working on optimizing those practices for unoptimized products. So the certification process doesn't begin until we have standard processes in place, a standard process that would be used across all of our 36 -- not chipsets, but production sets. So the first step in this is to get the process standardized, standardized work, if you will. Then the second part of that is determined by producing a lot of material in different sizes, mostly small sizes that we will use in different kinds of applications, that we will certify those applications before it goes into anything in a jet engine. And so that process usually takes another year. So we're really talking about getting this plant to full certification in the next 18 months.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And Albany?
componenttext: And Albany?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Albany depends on the market. There's lots of opportunities that are programmed opportunities that, if any of those particularly hit with us, we'll be looking hard at the Albany plant. Albany plant is our swing plant and it's in good shape. It's warm, it'
componenttext: Albany depends on the market. There's lots of opportunities that are programmed opportunities that, if any of those particularly hit with us, we'll be looking hard at the Albany plant. Albany plant is our swing plant and it's in good shape. It's warm, it's ready to go. The workforce, I'm sure they would like to be back into operation. We don't need it today. And so when that time comes, outside of where we are, and that really has got more to do with project work than where we are today, that plant could come back into operation quickly at any time.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, secondly, just when we think about titanium spot prices, we're starting to see evidence that we can start to see some uptick here. When should we expect that to start flowing through your realizations in the High Performance Metals segment, unde
componenttext: And then, secondly, just when we think about titanium spot prices, we're starting to see evidence that we can start to see some uptick here. When should we expect that to start flowing through your realizations in the High Performance Metals segment, understanding that you have some contracts that are indexed and also lead times extending and all that. Can you just give us a feel from when the trough is likely to be realized there?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that trough for the year has been realized. I think when you look at what our surcharge mechanisms are, as I mentioned in my comments, in our High Performance Metals business, we do not raise our indices at the ATI all-back operations until
componenttext: Well, I think that trough for the year has been realized. I think when you look at what our surcharge mechanisms are, as I mentioned in my comments, in our High Performance Metals business, we do not raise our indices at the ATI all-back operations until at the end of the quarter or the beginning of the next quarter. So while we were producing in the first quarter, whatever the indexes were on January 1, that's what the indexes would have been on March 31. So first of all, those indexes, as was publicly announced, are all up. So you can see the prices going up now. Secondly, those same indices for materials are used in our contractual methods, so all prices are up. So I would say, the first quarter is the bottom, and we're going to see prices increasing.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Timna Tanners with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Timna Tanners with UBS.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about lead times extending out and I missed it maybe. But could you quantify that a little bit more and kind of talk about the trend as you mentioned through the quarter and how that progress with regard to lead times and utilization?
componenttext: You talked about lead times extending out and I missed it maybe. But could you quantify that a little bit more and kind of talk about the trend as you mentioned through the quarter and how that progress with regard to lead times and utilization?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as the quarter goes up, what I said was that lead times in our High Performance Metals, excluding the exotic metals, which has not had a good start, as I mentioned, that's going to, I think, begin to see more activity in the second half of the year
componenttext: Well, as the quarter goes up, what I said was that lead times in our High Performance Metals, excluding the exotic metals, which has not had a good start, as I mentioned, that's going to, I think, begin to see more activity in the second half of the year as these delayed projects start to come back online, and we can reopen those bits and those quotes. But in the High Performance Metal section, our lead times have been expanding as we move throughout the quarter. So depending on the product area, it's two to eight weeks longer than it was at the first of the year. So depending on how far downstream you want to go into a bar or a shape versus, say, an ingot, those product schedules are out on a considerable basis. I think I also mentioned that we're basically full at the current utilization rates for the second quarter. So you keep moving those out, which says that we'll be adding more utilization back into the business, and we'll be taking more product in the second half of the year. I think I also mentioned, I think, Danny told me three times in this talk, so I'll mention it the fourth time, that we expect pricing improvements in the second half.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So my second question is, along those lines, SG&A was really light as was corporate expense. So how should we think about that going through the year as you mentioned you're going to need to perhaps add up, I guess, shifts or some sort of cost to move you
componenttext: So my second question is, along those lines, SG&A was really light as was corporate expense. So how should we think about that going through the year as you mentioned you're going to need to perhaps add up, I guess, shifts or some sort of cost to move your utilization up?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Timna, this is Rich. I think from the standpoint of SG&A, any add accruing wouldn't be in the SG&A area, it'd be in the touch labor, the manufacturing cost areas. So I think when we look at corporate expenses, SG&A, I mean there's obviously some movement
componenttext: Timna, this is Rich. I think from the standpoint of SG&A, any add accruing wouldn't be in the SG&A area, it'd be in the touch labor, the manufacturing cost areas. So I think when we look at corporate expenses, SG&A, I mean there's obviously some movement on a quarter-to-quarter basis, but I don't think it would be all that dramatic.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Levenson with Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Levenson with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The mix right now is still about 57%, Flat-Rolled; 34%, High Performance. How do you see that changing over the course of the year?
componenttext: The mix right now is still about 57%, Flat-Rolled; 34%, High Performance. How do you see that changing over the course of the year?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think both businesses are going to go up, Steve. And I think that 60-40 relationship, in terms of tons or in terms of pounds, probably is going to remain if our Flat-Rolled Products business, which, we believe, is going to continue to move forward with
componenttext: I think both businesses are going to go up, Steve. And I think that 60-40 relationship, in terms of tons or in terms of pounds, probably is going to remain if our Flat-Rolled Products business, which, we believe, is going to continue to move forward with additional tonnage coming into it. So I don't know if the relationships -- I think they're both moving together. Our schedules have increased dramatically in our High Performance area, which is, as you know, mostly aerospace and other difficult-to-produce markets, a lot of oil, oil and gas and the land-based turbines, jet engines, airframe. So we would expect more profits coming out of that business, but we'd also expect very good improvement in our Flat-Rolled side, too.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And for the second question, Boeing was out today saying that they're slowing deliveries of certain 787 parts to their final assembly facility. It sounds like there are shortages among some other parts. Do you think that's going to result in a spike in pu
componenttext: And for the second question, Boeing was out today saying that they're slowing deliveries of certain 787 parts to their final assembly facility. It sounds like there are shortages among some other parts. Do you think that's going to result in a spike in purchasing? Could that push guys out of their LTA limits and cause them to buy on spot rates?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think there's a couple of things that are always interesting as these things go up, and I kind of alluded to the fourth quarter conference call and other things, we talked back then about a disconnect between the supplier base and the OEMs on airframes,
componenttext: I think there's a couple of things that are always interesting as these things go up, and I kind of alluded to the fourth quarter conference call and other things, we talked back then about a disconnect between the supplier base and the OEMs on airframes, what they said they're going to make and what they were really going to do. And when we got -- as you know better than I do, when we got into December and firmed up these rates, I think there were people out there that may have been cut short someplace along the line or thought they could ramp up faster than they could. So I think, the bad news and the good news, the bad news is that they didn't order the parts when they could have got them in a smoothing type of schedule. The good news is that the business is picking up and people are trying to do some restocking as well as keeping up with the build rates. The very good news is the build rates are going to go up. The best news is that the 787 is going to get built and they are going to bring a lot of white tails up to sell at the end of period of time. So I think in the interim, Boeing has the time while this plan is being certified to make sure that their supply chain, in total, is in good shape to meet the rates that they said they're going to meet. My personal bet is that they're going to meet these rates.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Gambardella with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Gambardella with JPMorgan.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Pat, I think I heard you say in your remarks earlier on that you would expect to see raw material prices go down and your base prices go up, though?
componenttext: Pat, I think I heard you say in your remarks earlier on that you would expect to see raw material prices go down and your base prices go up, though?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, when you see prices, Mike, in the stainless markets, pricing mechanisms are kind of an interesting factor into the market as, again, we saw raw material prices rise rather rapidly. But when we look at the best estimates of many of the peopl
componenttext: Well, I think, when you see prices, Mike, in the stainless markets, pricing mechanisms are kind of an interesting factor into the market as, again, we saw raw material prices rise rather rapidly. But when we look at the best estimates of many of the people that make estimates on raw materials, we still see, for example in nickel, 300 million pounds on the LME [London Metal Exchange]. So we're pretty confident, based on forecast from third parties, what we see that happened last year, other kinds of things, that will be some moderation from this rapid rise. In contrast to that, while this rapid rise in surcharges and volume has been taking place, there's been extremely little movement in base prices or on the conversion price. So the history has been, as these things level out and plateau or moderate or come down, then it's an opportunity to try to recover the prices that should be in effect for the amount of volume and market conditions on the conversion side. So my guess is that we'll see base prices move up and some moderation on the surcharge mechanisms.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just going forward, say, if we first if we look back to the last peak in your earnings cycle back in 2007 when you made over $7 a share, $7.26, nickel prices back then hit a high, almost mid-year, $54,000 or more than twice of what they are right now. You
componenttext: Just going forward, say, if we first if we look back to the last peak in your earnings cycle back in 2007 when you made over $7 a share, $7.26, nickel prices back then hit a high, almost mid-year, $54,000 or more than twice of what they are right now. You typically make a lot of money in very high nickel price environments, but if you don't expect nickel to really go up, can you give us a feel for how the amount of money that you invested since 2007 in terms of new capability, how that could offset some of the earnings loss, say, from the previous peak due to nickel prices being about half of what they are or back then?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We've continued, as you know, Mike, to work on the efficiencies and conversion cost in this business. We have a new finishing and new capabilities in our Plate business. We have new capabilities in our titanium sheet production, which is Flat-Rolled today
componenttext: We've continued, as you know, Mike, to work on the efficiencies and conversion cost in this business. We have a new finishing and new capabilities in our Plate business. We have new capabilities in our titanium sheet production, which is Flat-Rolled today. We basically have a dedicated sheet plant. We've modernized all of our cold rolling mills to state-of-the-art flatness gauge tension controls. We have improved our melt shop situation with the commodity melt shop and a specialty melt shop of both electrical steel and our nickel-based alloys and ingot casting, where we will, before the end of this year, in the second half, close a complete footprint down. So it isn't really the same company. We've been able to demonstrate over the last year, when business was really, really bad, very low utilization rates that we were still able to make some money even under the worst of market conditions. So it's a different equation as we go forward. And I think that if we had the typical rates for this typical conversion revenues for this kind of a business, coupled with normal surcharge mechanisms, we'll do just fine in that business. Rich, you might want to add what you think?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, I think the other -- your point, and we've said this publicly, I mean, first of all, the one comment about higher raw material cost in the '07 time frame. A large piece of that from an earnings standpoint was obviously offset by significant LIF
componenttext: Yes, Mike, I think the other -- your point, and we've said this publicly, I mean, first of all, the one comment about higher raw material cost in the '07 time frame. A large piece of that from an earnings standpoint was obviously offset by significant LIFO inventory reserve charges, since most of our inventory's on LIFO. But I think going forward, we would agree that we might turn out to be wrong. But we would agree that the amount of speculation that was going on in 2007 that drove raw material costs high, that those levels is unlikely to repeat itself. But what we do believe is that, in addition, all the cost reductions that Pat has alluded to and the capabilities we have from a manufacturing and a capacity standpoint, the amount of business and focus that we have globally, the diversification of the company, the capacities and the value-add focus that we have, we do believe that those kind of earnings that we achieved in the last cycle are achievable in the next cycle in just a different way. They won't be driven by some of the raw material cost volatility. It will be driven by higher value-added products, a different cost structure, increased volume. One of the things that we've said that we didn't have in place in 2007 that we will have in place as these markets grow going forward is the capability of producing 60 million pounds of titanium mill products in the kind of a product mix focus that we want that we didn't have that capability before. And with the 787 ramp up in the industrial markets and the use of titanium in oil and gas, those opportunities, we believe, will be there. And in addition, we think in that time period, we'll begin to see some of the demand growth from some markets that really weren't present in 2007 like nuclear.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So with the, say, the current level of nickel prices or about half of where they were back then, you feel you could still reach that $7.26 in earnings?
componenttext: So with the, say, the current level of nickel prices or about half of where they were back then, you feel you could still reach that $7.26 in earnings?

componenttextpreview: In what time period?
componenttext: In what time period?

componenttextpreview: Well, in the next several years.
componenttext: Well, in the next several years.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our view in the next three, three-plus years, we think that's achievable, yes. For all the reasons that Pat and I have just articulated.
componenttext: Our view in the next three, three-plus years, we think that's achievable, yes. For all the reasons that Pat and I have just articulated.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Levy with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Levy with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the $375 million, how much of it is going to Rowley, Utah, how much of it is going to Brackenridge? And then, as you look forward to 2011, what do you see as a more likely number?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the $375 million, how much of it is going to Rowley, Utah, how much of it is going to Brackenridge? And then, as you look forward to 2011, what do you see as a more likely number?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Rowley will be finishing up here, largely from a cash expenditure standpoint in the first half. And then the timing of the spend, as we begin ramping up the hot rolling and processing facility investment, will begin in more earnest ways here in the
componenttext: Well, Rowley will be finishing up here, largely from a cash expenditure standpoint in the first half. And then the timing of the spend, as we begin ramping up the hot rolling and processing facility investment, will begin in more earnest ways here in the second half. And that matches up with the completion of some of the big projects, Rowley and the melt shop consolidation, et cetera, that we've been talking about. So as we look at the $375 million, more than half of that is expected to be focused in 2010 on the hot mill and processing facility. And as you know, that's roughly a four-year project. So as we look going forward, we would expect the kind of capital expenditure level of $350 million to $400 million to continue for the next several years until the hot mill project is complete. And we have the capability, because of how we're structuring that project, to speed it up or slow it down a little bit, depending upon what business circumstances are. But it's certainly our strong desire to complete that project and have it up and running before the end of 2013.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the use of the $560 million in cash and less revolver availability, what are you guys thinking strategically? Pension paid out, or I don't know, acquisitions, deleveraging? What are you thinking in terms of the use of that liquidity?
componenttext: And then in terms of the use of the $560 million in cash and less revolver availability, what are you guys thinking strategically? Pension paid out, or I don't know, acquisitions, deleveraging? What are you thinking in terms of the use of that liquidity?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think we'll have -- we don't believe we'll have a need to do anymore pension funding. We think that the pension was the actions that we took last year and the years before that. And hopefully, the smart asset allocation we have that we'll be
componenttext: Well, I don't think we'll have -- we don't believe we'll have a need to do anymore pension funding. We think that the pension was the actions that we took last year and the years before that. And hopefully, the smart asset allocation we have that we'll be able to not be in the position to have to put significant amounts in there. The other thing, as you know, we look at cash deployment in a balanced way. So certainly, we focus on what our obligations are to take care of them, and we fund managed working capital to grow earnings, which we did here in the first quarter and capital investments and the dividend policy. And if we have something left over, I think we've demonstrated in the past, that we look for the best ways to create shareholder value with that excess cash and free cash flow. So fundamentally, we don't have a different viewpoint today than we've always had. We do like the fact that we have an untapped credit facility of $400 million, and we like that sitting there, as well as a reasonable amount of cash on the balance sheet at any point in time so that we maintain financial flexibility to do things that are in the best interest of our shareholders. And that's the philosophy we operate to.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Yu with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Yu with Citi.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the nickel alloy affecting prices in the High Performance Metals, just looking at the sequential decline, and Pat, I was wondering if you might be able to comment on it, just kind of thinking that a lot of improvements come from the engine
componenttext: With regard to the nickel alloy affecting prices in the High Performance Metals, just looking at the sequential decline, and Pat, I was wondering if you might be able to comment on it, just kind of thinking that a lot of improvements come from the engine side. It's a bit counter intuitive.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's been some pretty interesting price competition on the nickel side of the business. But as the volumes go forward and lead times extend out, I think you're going to see less of some of the earlier pricing pressures. So we would expect
componenttext: Well, I think there's been some pretty interesting price competition on the nickel side of the business. But as the volumes go forward and lead times extend out, I think you're going to see less of some of the earlier pricing pressures. So we would expect in the surcharge mechanism, again, remember, we do it only once every three months, though, the second quarter has already had a price increase on all products shipping out from April, May and June. If the prices of nickel stay where they are, we'll see another price increase in the third quarter again. So you're going to see pricing move up there, and you're going to see volumes. Since the lead times are moving up, volume moving up also. So I think this is a market that's just under recovery, Brian, not really declining. I think we've probably seen the worst of it.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And one of your competitors yesterday said that they're seeing the lower end of nickel alloy market picking up quite a bit more. Is that an area that you're trying to capture or retain share? And could mix have been part of the contributing factor in Q1?
componenttext: And one of your competitors yesterday said that they're seeing the lower end of nickel alloy market picking up quite a bit more. Is that an area that you're trying to capture or retain share? And could mix have been part of the contributing factor in Q1?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think there is. We're in the industrial markets in the oil and gas markets, as well as the jet engine and other markets. So as at that market is getting strength, as we pointed out earlier in our comments, you might see some differential in pricing. But
componenttext: I think there is. We're in the industrial markets in the oil and gas markets, as well as the jet engine and other markets. So as at that market is getting strength, as we pointed out earlier in our comments, you might see some differential in pricing. But I think, as the build rates continue now to be confirmed and are secure, and in fact, projected to increase, then we'll see a larger percentage of the business coming back toward jet engines and that there should be some self correcting in that also.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to get a bit of clarification on your comments earlier about active versus hot-idle capacity. In terms of taking from the two-thirds available to full availability, is it a matter of labor and adding additional shifts? Or are there additional thing
componenttext: I want to get a bit of clarification on your comments earlier about active versus hot-idle capacity. In terms of taking from the two-thirds available to full availability, is it a matter of labor and adding additional shifts? Or are there additional things you have to do to raise equipment up time?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: It is a matter of orderly bringing people back and orderly bringing up production. In our company, we bring shifts back, we do reorientation, safety training, reorientation with the equipment, quality training. And so it takes a period of time to bring a
componenttext: It is a matter of orderly bringing people back and orderly bringing up production. In our company, we bring shifts back, we do reorientation, safety training, reorientation with the equipment, quality training. And so it takes a period of time to bring a shift back up, get people back and familiar with the jobs, move that into production and then move it up. It doesn't happen in just one week til next week because the 2009 has been a severe-enough reduction that coming back in requires us to go through the full element of training and safety. So it is people and shifts.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Is that something you're doing now kind of in anticipation's of the back half pick up?
componenttext: Is that something you're doing now kind of in anticipation's of the back half pick up?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think on the Flat-Rolled side or on the stainless side, that's always a potential factor. But we don't think, at this point in time, that it has been a major factor in terms of the demand improvement that we've seen thus far this year. And I think we wo
componenttext: I think on the Flat-Rolled side or on the stainless side, that's always a potential factor. But we don't think, at this point in time, that it has been a major factor in terms of the demand improvement that we've seen thus far this year. And I think we would have an even stronger view of that, that being the case, on the nickel alloy side and High Performance Metals. We think that's purely fundamental driven for all the reasons that Pat actually began to articulate in the third quarter earnings release last year. And I think he predicted that what we're seeing now we would see, and that's what we're seeing.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

componenttext: One of the comments that I made, just to clarify it, is that we have improved our forward loads throughout the first quarter, and that those loads continue to improve as we're now moving through the second quarter. So the market is recovering, and I think we did go through a period of some very, very competitive pricing and some changing around of shares and some changing around of contractual arrangements. And that disruptiveness sometimes creates different kinds of reactions that usually gets solved as the market gets stronger and moves forward.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Although, Kuni, I would add that your question about customer hedging behavior, I think it is safe to say that unless it's a very specific, more project-oriented business, that customers do not appear to be willing or eager to hedge with nickel at the cur
componenttext: Although, Kuni, I would add that your question about customer hedging behavior, I think it is safe to say that unless it's a very specific, more project-oriented business, that customers do not appear to be willing or eager to hedge with nickel at the current level. They think it's going to correct down. So there was more desire when nickel was at $8 than may be hedged than there is at $11 to $12.

componenttext: We've had some interesting times. We've seen some depressed markets, but as we've had contractual arrangements with several of our major accounts, our shipments have been the same or relatively flat throughout 2009 and they were up 4% in the first quarter. So we have an interesting situations, where we still have occasions where people are looking for a particular product because they need it right now. In other occasions, they're running out of warehouse material that they bought that they're using up or working down their inventories. So I would say, our earlier comments that we believe that market is about flat for us is what we would say, although, we had about a 4% increase in the first quarter.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to get a handle on where the High Performance margins can go from here through the year. You mentioned surcharges up strongly in Q2 sequentially. I got, if I look at my model, it looks like they're up 25% to 30% versus Q1 at nickel. You mention
componenttext: I'm trying to get a handle on where the High Performance margins can go from here through the year. You mentioned surcharges up strongly in Q2 sequentially. I got, if I look at my model, it looks like they're up 25% to 30% versus Q1 at nickel. You mentioned lead times are extending, et cetera. On the other hand, you didn't take a LIFO-reserve charge this quarter, and I assume that's because you assume these element prices will retrench through the year. But let's just say they stay where they are today across all of the products, how should we think about margins? Are we going to see expansion from here? Or has any expansion on the increased volume and surcharge rise going to be offset by LIFO?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're in pretty good shape on the High Performance side of the company. I'm going to let Rich go through the technical explanation of how we look at LIFO and how we look at these margins. We said we thought that these prices, on the nickel side, w
componenttext: I think we're in pretty good shape on the High Performance side of the company. I'm going to let Rich go through the technical explanation of how we look at LIFO and how we look at these margins. We said we thought that these prices, on the nickel side, would moderate in the second half, so there's lots of people predicting that. But basically, rising nickel in the end and all, at least as it's going up, should be good for us as we move forward. Go ahead, Rich.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when you look specifically at High Performance Metals and the impact on LIFO, obviously, you can't just look at nickel. You also have to look at titanium and titanium sponge, and you know what the public comments are about the contractual spo
componenttext: Yes, I think when you look specifically at High Performance Metals and the impact on LIFO, obviously, you can't just look at nickel. You also have to look at titanium and titanium sponge, and you know what the public comments are about the contractual sponge prices year-over-year. So that, combined with mix, becomes pretty, pretty big drivers of the LIFO assumption. I think that as -- you know how we do LIFO. I mean, we are projecting what we believe our year-end cost will be, year end being based upon our inventory turns, essentially the last quarter of the year across the businesses by individual pool to come up with a current-year index, and that apply to the LIFO calculation. And the projection of year-end FIFO inventory determines what the full year LIFO reduction or increase on the reserve will be, and then we take that ratably on a quarterly basis, so we'll update that every quarter. Our view here at the end of the first quarter is that, as we've said, that raw material cost will moderate. To the extent that they don't, obviously, that would be impacted in our revised assumption as we go on, on a quarterly basis. Having said that, to the extent that they don't, I think that you'll see FIFO [first-in, first-out] profits increase as well. So how that plays against the LIFO-reserve change would remain to be seen. But I don't think, at this point in time, it would be a significant driver one way or another, but we'll see. It all depends on what raw material costs do.

componenttext: On the share account, why wouldn't we be seeing the dilutive effect of the convertible debt? The second question, that'll be for Pat, and that is on the Flat-Rolled revenue. Really, really nice move up from the bottom that we saw in revenue in the second quarter of 2009, and I'm just wondering what your sense would be in terms of what impact did inventory restocking of customers come into play? And on a sequential basis, how much more upward movement might we see as the quarters progress throughout the year?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the question on the share count and the impact on the convertible. First of all, we're governed obviously by the accounting rules in terms of how to deal with the diluted calculation on the convertible, and it's very fact specific depending upon the
componenttext: Yes, the question on the share count and the impact on the convertible. First of all, we're governed obviously by the accounting rules in terms of how to deal with the diluted calculation on the convertible, and it's very fact specific depending upon the company. So the drivers of that for us are the earnings, obviously, the tax rate and the interest expense on the convertible that's flowing through the income statement on a quarterly basis. And in our case, that's also impacted by the fact that we capitalized a portion of our total interest expense under the accounting rules because of the construction and progress on our long-term capital projects. So the bottom line is, when you put all of those factors in as it pertains to ATI, on a quarterly basis, using the 98 million share count, which excludes the convertible effect, basically, our earnings per share has to be at or about $0.25 a share in the quarter before the convertible issuance is considered dilutive. So because we're below $0.25, if we were above that, then we would have had to assume that the convertible shares were in fact converted, which would increase our diluted shares up to about 108 million shares. But then we would also have to add back to the reported GAAP net income a portion of the interest expense that's associated with that converted because the convert assumes that equity, not debt. But we would have to adjust that for the amount of prorated amount of interest that we've capitalized. So that's a long answer. But the real impact, the real threshold, is if you're at or below $0.25 a share using the 98 million shares, it would be anti-dilutive and therefore not included.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then the second question is on the Flat-Rolled revenue and the outlook there.
componenttext: And then the second question is on the Flat-Rolled revenue and the outlook there.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The outlook is positive. Lead times, again, have moved in this business. Schedules are filling virtually across all of our product lines on Flat-Rolled. I do believe there's some restocking going on as people are surprised, maybe, by some of the things th
componenttext: The outlook is positive. Lead times, again, have moved in this business. Schedules are filling virtually across all of our product lines on Flat-Rolled. I do believe there's some restocking going on as people are surprised, maybe, by some of the things that they've seen they've run out. They want to not only meet their current pull for their materials, but there is some restocking into the system. That especially happens if there's any schedule in increases. Now we've been able to bring back capacity in this business rather soon. We've been able to move up our melt shop schedules, move our hot rolling schedules up a bit, run some overtime quickly in the finishing end. So there is still capacity to go, but we're looking in our basic products to get up to that in the stainless steel sheet and plate, to get up around 350,000 tons. And then with the specialty products making up the other 40% more of that business, we would expect that if this trends all hold together, and this recovery stays on track that it's on now, that we're going to see quarter-on-quarter improvement, quarter-on-quarter more tonnage til we're back to full utilizations or utilization that we consider at practical capacity. So this is a pretty good recovery on the Flat-Rolled side that we've seen over the last 90 days.

componenttext: I don't think we all has -- like I said, we bring people back in. We have to train. We have some shuffling around to do. componenttextpreview: I don't think there's a good index out there, John, any place. This is what you can buy from a scrap dealer. So there is, I can tell you that the prices have moved up dramatically from the fourth quarter continuing to move up through the end of the first
componenttext: I don't think there's a good index out there, John, any place. This is what you can buy from a scrap dealer. So there is, I can tell you that the prices have moved up dramatically from the fourth quarter continuing to move up through the end of the first quarter. And there is some availability issues today with one supplier having to solve some quality problems and just the availability of material assets as the cycle picks back up. So I think, in our particular case, we're glad to have the availability to us or the opportunity to move more sponge production and if we choose to versus the scrap market. Other thing I think to consider is that, as the programs of Boeing have some near-net size kind of production coming out of Russia today, that, that scrap that used to be in the U.S. is now held in Russia, not coming to the U.S., at least that portion of it. So it's an interesting game that is changing from dealer to dealer from week-to-week.

componenttext: I would say that we're under contract with our major customers. And so our shipments as I pointed out, were actually up 4%, but I think the market itself is not robust in any sense of the word. There is some specific areas that requires specific products of grain oriented that are pulling. But I think, basically, it's a flat market right now, maybe declining even in total in the industry. Around the world, the market's up. That's for sure. The global market would be higher when we consider India and China and other parts of the world. So we put it all together. I'd say the world market is bigger. There is more supply there than what they're used to be. But U.S. market has yet to recover back to the levels that we would like to see.

componenttext: I think, Q2 will be somewhere in the same range of , Q1,maybe a little bit less as we continue to ramp up. headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the second quarter 2010 Allegheny Technologies earnings conference call. My name is Keisha, and I’ll be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in listen-only mode. We will conduct the q
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the second quarter 2010 Allegheny Technologies earnings conference call. My name is Keisha, and I’ll be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in listen-only mode. We will conduct the question-and-answer session towards the end of this conference. As a reminder, this call is being recorded for replay purposes.
I’ll now like to hand the call over to Mr. Dan Greenfield, Director, Investor Relations and Corporate Communications. Please proceed.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keisha. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Allegheny Technologies earnings conference call for the second quarter 2010. This conference call is being broadcast on our Web site at www.atimetals.com. Members of the media have been invited to list
componenttext:
Thank you, Keisha. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Allegheny Technologies earnings conference call for the second quarter 2010. This conference call is being broadcast on our Web site at www.atimetals.com. Members of the media have been invited to listen to this call.
Participating on the call today are Pat Hassey, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rich Harshman, Executive Vice President, Finance and Chief Financial Officer. All references to net income and earnings in this conference call mean net income and earnings attributable to ATI.
After some initial comments, we will ask for questions. During the question-and-answer session please limit yourself to two questions to be considerate of others on the line. Please note that all forward-looking statements this afternoon are subject to various assumptions and caveats as noted in the earnings release. Actual results may differ materially. Here is Pat Hassey.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and thanks to everyone joining today’s call. Our key global markets are performing well. Our strategy has been to target certain markets that we believe deliver long-term secular growth trends that are greater than GDP. The fundamentals of
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and thanks to everyone joining today’s call. Our key global markets are performing well. Our strategy has been to target certain markets that we believe deliver long-term secular growth trends that are greater than GDP. The fundamentals of these markets remain intact, even during a time of general economic uncertainty, primarily here in the U.S. and Europe. We continue to see 2010 as a transition year to the resumption of growth.
Here are some highlights of our second quarter 2010 performance. Sales were up 17% over last quarter to over $1billion. Earnings improved $0.36 per share, which includes nearly $9 million of start-up and idle facility costs and an additional $5.5 million LIFO inventory valuation reserve charge. Shipments of most of our products reached their highest levels in six quarters.
Order entry for our High Performance Metals segment products from the aerospace and oil and gas markets continue to improve with lead times extending into the fourth quarter.
ATI is not immune from short-term economic conditions. Caution and uncertainty best describe our stainless business, which is primarily driven by U.S. and global economic conditions.
Some additional second quarter highlights. We remained focused on improving our cost structure with over $35 million of gross cost reductions in the second quarter bringing our year-to-date total to $72 million.
Total titanium shipments, including conversion of our Uniti Titanium joint venture were 9.7 million pounds in the second quarter. This brings 2010 total titanium shipments to nearly 19 million pounds.
During the second quarter, titanium shipments increased 17% or over 1 million pounds compared to the first quarter of 2010 in our High Performance Metal segment from improved demand in the aerospace market. Flat-Rolled Products’ titanium shipments including Uniti joint venture conversion products were about 2.6 million pounds.
Our direct international sales increased over 35% of sales in the second quarter. Today, ATI is more globally focused on markets than ever before.
We continue to introduce innovative new products and achieve several major new product milestones in the second quarter. We announced the first long-term agreement for the use of our new ATI 718Plus alloy for jet engine applications.
ATI 718Plus alloy is the first new nickel based super alloy introduced to the jet engine market in at least 40 years. We believe this is the first of many applications of this innovative new product.
Our game-changing high-strength titanium ATI 425 alloy was introduced to the aerospace and defense market during the AeroMat Technical Conference, and the Eurosatory, the European Defense Conference.
We recently concluded a year long program to characterize the mechanical properties of ATI 425 alloy. Results have been approved and this proprietary alloy is now certified for a broad application in the aerospace industry.
Customer interest in this new product is strong, particularly for the newly certified sheet product. The aerospace and defense industries now have for the first time a high strength titanium alloy that is available in long length sheet coils.
The industry now has for the first time a high strength titanium alloy that is cold-rollable and cold-formable. These attributes are expected to significantly reduce the full cost of producing parts made of high strength titanium.
At last week’s Farnborough Air Show, our technical and marketing people met with many existing and new customers, who are considering this new product. We now have a long list of customers, some new to ATI, who are interested in ATI 425 alloy.
The protocol for introduction to the market goes like this. First, design allowables approve for sheet and plate, this is done. Second, results approved for addition in the Metallic Materials Properties Development and Standardization Hand Book Number 6, a prerequisite for broad application of this alloy in the aerospace industry, this is done.
Three, testing by customers for various applications. This is now ongoing with increased interest, and lastly customer specifies the ATI 425 alloy for specific end uses. We believe that this is coming potentially in a big way. How do we see the impact of ATI 425 alloy? It has created market pull.
Customers want to design with it. ATI 425 alloy is a replacement for 6-4 titanium, the most common high-strength titanium alloy. In addition, we believe substitution opportunities exist beyond titanium alloys.
We believe ATI 425 alloy has the potential to generate hundreds of millions of dollars in incremental revenue for ATI.
Now, let’s turn to our key markets. Sentiment has changed dramatically in the aerospace markets since the first quarter of 2010. Both Boeing and Airbus have announced they plan to increase their production schedules. At last week’s Farnborough Air Show, optimism was high. A significant number of new orders were added to backlogs that were already at record levels.
Boeing 787 Dreamliner flew into the show and was available for tours. All eyes were on that plane when it took off and left the show on Tuesday. Throughout 2009, when the aerospace supply chain was destocking, we had said that we expected the aerospace market to recover in 2010. That scenario was playing out for ATI even better than we had expected as aircraft build rates are increasing.
Those who visited the ATI aerospace stand at the air show saw the progress we are making in growing our share in this important market. For the first time, we displayed jet engine parts made with our new ATI 718Plus alloy.
Second; our new high-strength titanium ATI 425 alloy in samples of continuous cold-rolled sheet formed plate and prototype aerospace fasteners, a display of ATI Powder Metals products. Remember we recently acquired this business in late 2009. Lastly, new cutting system designed to improve the productivity of machining, difficult to machine materials, such as titanium alloys and nickel-based super alloys.
In addition during an air show event, ATI Allvac was recognized by Rolls-Royce and presented with the Chief Procurement Officer award. According to Rolls-Royce, this honor was awarded to ATI Allvac ‘After successfully reducing overall product costs and contributing toward our environmental responsibilities by limiting the usage of natural resources the company. ATI Allvac has also made sustained investment in the state-of-the-art facilities that have embedded lean practices.’
During the oil and gas market, we continue to make progress in improving our position in this global market.
First, first half sales were 70% higher than the first half of 2009, and over 40% of first half sales to this market were international. While current and future production regulation in the Gulf of Mexico is uncertain, global oil rig count is steadily increasing, driven in large part by unconventional gas such as the Marcellus Shale here in Western Pennsylvania and the tar sands in Canada.
Demand remained strong for our specialty flat-rolled products, our nickel-based alloys or completion tools, our specialty alloy for drill collars and our tungsten drill products.
The investments we’ve made in our Sheffield U.K. facility to melt and machine-engineered products are now paying off.
Demand is strong for our proprietary Datalloy 2 drill collars and our ATI 718-OP nickel-based alloy completion tools and for other ATI nicked-based alloys.
Looking ahead, we continue to improve our position in the oil and gas market with innovative new products and new global customers. In addition, several very large oil and gas projects in Asia and in the Middle East are moving forward. Orders for our materials are expected to be placed later this year.
In the electrical energy market, demand for our grain-oriented electrical steel products remained relatively flat. Demand from the nuclear electrical energy market continues to improve.
The medical market reached over 5% of first half 2010 sales. Biomedical manufacturers continue to purchase at a brisk pace. Demand was strong for our niobium, titanium alloys from the medical equipment market for MRI applications. These are all good signs for ATI products.
Turning to our businesses that are more dependent on the general economy of the United States, second quarter 2010 shipments of our standard stainless sheets and plate products increased 17% compared to the first quarter of 2010.
Industry data reflects service center inventories remain at a seasonally adjusted rate of just 2.8 months, which is still historically low. In addition, customers see no reason to purchase more than they need even though average base prices are low because the surcharges are declining.
The benchmark 304 stainless surcharge was $1.27 per pound in June. It is $1.08 per pound in July. It will be $0.96 per pound in August, and it is expected to be approximately $0.94 per pound in September based upon current moderating raw material prices. That is a $0.34 per pound or 27% drop in the surcharge since the yearly high set in June.
In addition, the summer months are normally seasonally slower for our stainless business. So customers are taking a wait-and-see attitude until raw material prices stabilize. Finally, it’s important to note that we do not believe end use demand for our stainless products is deteriorating.
Moving to our strategic capital projects, we have continued to invest in unsurpassed manufacturing. The ramp up process at our Rowley, Utah premium titanium sponge facility is continuing. We plan to continue to ramp production throughout 2010 in a systematic manner.
The melt shop consolidation at our Brackenridge, Pennsylvania melt shop is essentially complete. We reduced our footprint and we expect considerable cost savings and production efficiencies from this project when it is fully operational. We expect to benefit by up to $30 million of annualized cost reductions associated with this project beginning later this year. The full impact of the project begins in 2011
On June 21, we announced that ATI has selected Siemens VAI to design, engineer and supply the hot rolling mill at our Brackenridge, PA facility. We believe our new hot rolling and processing facility will provide unsurpassed manufacturing capability and versatility in the production of our unique range of mission critical metallics.
The state-of-the-art facility is designed to further transform our Flat-Rolled Products segment’s operating performance across all business cycles. We now expect 2010 capital investments to be approximately $325 million.
Before we open the call for questions, a last comment about the third quarter and the second half of 2010, in the second half, we expect our High Performance Metals segment to improve quarter-on-quarter at about 7% to 8%. We see the aerospace market and this segment’s other markets beginning to accelerate throughout 2011 to a robust level in 2012 and beyond.
Our Engineered Products segment businesses continue to improve. We expect a lower third quarter due to normal seasonality, particularly the August vacation period in Europe. Growth should resume in the fourth quarter and continue into 2011.
In the third quarter, our Flat-Rolled Products segment is experiencing raw material costs to out-of-phase surcharges from the rapid decline in nickel prices from the second quarter highs. Lower volume from the wait-and-see attitude by service center and end-use customers are affecting this unit’s performance.
These conditions are expected to significantly reduce third quarter Flat-Rolled Products’ operating profit. However, we expect a rapid rebound in the fourth quarter due to renewed stocking. We do not believe end-use demand for our standard stainless products is deteriorating.
By 2011 and beyond, we expect to grow faster than our core global markets because we have improved our market position from improving volume and forward load, new customers and expanded LTAs, innovation of new products, new and technically advanced manufacturing capabilities, and finally a global focus combined with a solid reputation and internal customer base in key growth markets.
With this opening comment, we’d now like to turn the call open for any questions.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions). Your first question comes from the line of Luke Folta with Longbow Research.
componenttext: (Operator instructions). Your first question comes from the line of Luke Folta with Longbow Research.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions. Just firstly on your guidance, if I’m interpreting you correctly, I think you are saying that the impact from the stainless steel raw material surcharge mismatch will probably outweigh some of the improvements that you’re seeing i
componenttext: Couple of questions. Just firstly on your guidance, if I’m interpreting you correctly, I think you are saying that the impact from the stainless steel raw material surcharge mismatch will probably outweigh some of the improvements that you’re seeing in the nickel-based alloys business in the third quarter, but you’re seeing a bounce back in 4Q. Correct me if I’m wrong about the third quarter, but I guess my question is would you expect the fourth quarter number as you see things today to be your best quarter of the year or will that be the second quarter?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you’ve got it right. I think the third quarter will be down. We’ve talked about these issues before. And I think you’ve seen this from some of the other reporting companies, is to have a rapidly dropping nickel, basically nickel surcharge an
componenttext:
I think you’ve got it right. I think the third quarter will be down. We’ve talked about these issues before. And I think you’ve seen this from some of the other reporting companies, is to have a rapidly dropping nickel, basically nickel surcharge and couple that with lower volume. So you cannot move the metal through your operations at the higher surcharges, so just isn’t enough volume to get it out. So therefore it lingers on through the quarter and will cost money. That’s what the third quarter is going to experience. It’s going to be a down quarter.
At the same time, the customers are doing that, the shelves are destocking because demand remains fairly stable out there. So what we think in the fourth quarter is that we will see the demand come back with also restocking on the shelves to meet the business condition. So if you’re asking me today I would think the fourth quarter would be the best quarter of the year for Flat-Rolled.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, as a follow-up, when you think about the pick up that we saw in the titanium and nickel-based alloys business, in the press release you had said that it was mostly due to engine and after-market. Was that pretty much the sole increase? I’m jus
componenttext: Secondly, as a follow-up, when you think about the pick up that we saw in the titanium and nickel-based alloys business, in the press release you had said that it was mostly due to engine and after-market. Was that pretty much the sole increase? I’m just trying to get a sense of what the leverage is for you guys to improving engine fundamentals?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think there’s two issues there. The first one is that we had a pretty good business coming back in the jet engine business, which we had talked about earlier and we had forecasted, if you recall, that we did not see any decline in build rates, but, in
componenttext:
I think there’s two issues there. The first one is that we had a pretty good business coming back in the jet engine business, which we had talked about earlier and we had forecasted, if you recall, that we did not see any decline in build rates, but, in fact when we looked at the fourth quarter 2009, we thought they would at least be stable. Well, now we have a situation not only with stable but increasing build rates coming and I think you’re seeing the engine makers come back to try to get their inventories in line with what demand that they now see going forward. That’s one issue there.
Our airframe business was pretty much at the minimum levels that we’ve contracted to, so it remained steady. The other growth that we had was in the industrial titanium markets coming back in Asia and in other areas. We even had some business in the defense sector that we had some wins on. So when you put all that together what you find is a pretty robust second quarter for titanium moving up 1 million pounds. But as you look at the mix of more industrial applications, you saw that the pricing stayed relatively stable. We didn’t get the price increase that we wanted overall, but we did get price increases on the aerospace side.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you starting to see any benefits at this point from the 787 related engine programs like the Trent 1000 and GEnx?
componenttext: Are you starting to see any benefits at this point from the 787 related engine programs like the Trent 1000 and GEnx?

componenttext: I think that’s certainly part of my comments of the engine makers getting ready for the ramp up of those programs as they look forward.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gautam Khanna with Cowen & Company. Please proceed.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gautam Khanna with Cowen & Company. Please proceed.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I just wanted to ask a couple of questions Pat or Rich on when you talk about robust gains in 2011 in some of the later cycle, long cycle businesses, what is your expectation for titanium shipments next year? I mean on the airframe side of Boeing are
componenttext: Yes. I just wanted to ask a couple of questions Pat or Rich on when you talk about robust gains in 2011 in some of the later cycle, long cycle businesses, what is your expectation for titanium shipments next year? I mean on the airframe side of Boeing are you going to expect to see a big pick up next year or is that something more likely to occur in 2012?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you have it right, Gautam. I think we’re going to see jet engine business move rapidly. I think we’re going to see the industrial markets for titanium, especially in some of the oil and gas and desalinization, chemical processing, heat exchang
componenttext:
I think you have it right, Gautam. I think we’re going to see jet engine business move rapidly. I think we’re going to see the industrial markets for titanium, especially in some of the oil and gas and desalinization, chemical processing, heat exchangers, nuclear markets begin to ramp pretty well. There is some defense business that looks attractive. I think the airframe business will continue along at about the same pace until the excess inventories begin to be worked off.
So it depends on how fast that they ramp those businesses. Depends on the extra build rates and how fast they ramp for the single-aisles. They all use titanium too and all the engines that are on those programs use the titanium product. So we expect to see this begin to ramp in 2011. As the airframe programs come on stream, the nuclear business moves where we think it’s going to be and the programs that we’re shooting for and some of the other applications that are out there and especially with the new 425 alloy and our business gaining share in the overall market, we see 2012 being a very robust year for us.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just quickly to follow up on the question about titanium pricing in the quarter. Do you think Q2 was the bottom for average selling price? I know its mix dependent, but obviously, your Q3 surcharges on fixed were up quite a bit?
componenttext: Just quickly to follow up on the question about titanium pricing in the quarter. Do you think Q2 was the bottom for average selling price? I know its mix dependent, but obviously, your Q3 surcharges on fixed were up quite a bit?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say this Gautam, I’d say the first half is the bottom. We actually got some pricing on different segments in the second quarter. You are absolutely correct in the surcharge mechanism. When we look at what the current conditions are for 6-4 bulk
componenttext:
I would say this Gautam, I’d say the first half is the bottom. We actually got some pricing on different segments in the second quarter. You are absolutely correct in the surcharge mechanism. When we look at what the current conditions are for 6-4 bulk weldable process scraps. So this is a scrap that’s cleaned, ready to be applied into a bulk weldable stick. That price has now moved up to $6.75 per pound.
So when you’ll start back looking at that kind of product in the fourth quarter, that’s up $4 a pound and that’s why our surcharge mechanism moved unexpectedly to some customers, almost to $2 a pound. So, I would say the first half of the year is the bottom for that and you are going to see rising surcharges on the titanium side. You’re also going to see as these product lines move forward depending on the application, depending on the size, shape or form, better, better pricing going forward.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Parr with KeyBanc Capital Markets. Please proceed.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Parr with KeyBanc Capital Markets. Please proceed.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess you were talking a little bit Pat about the third quarter and clearly the Flat-Rolled business is going to be down from the second quarter because of the mismatch. But I guess, you’re also indicating that you thought that the quarter for the cor
componenttext:
I guess you were talking a little bit Pat about the third quarter and clearly the Flat-Rolled business is going to be down from the second quarter because of the mismatch. But I guess, you’re also indicating that you thought that the quarter for the corporation as a whole might be weaker than the second quarter or were you just talking to the Flat-Rolled business?
Can you give us some color and help reconcile some of the new projects, the cost reduction activity, the growth in high performance business and how you’d reconcile that against this short-term, call it a pause, in a standard flat-rolled business?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the business on the High Performance Metals side, we expect to have improved operating profit in the third quarter. The Engineered Products business although we have improving margins with the cutting tool business, basically losing the vacation peri
componenttext:
Yes, the business on the High Performance Metals side, we expect to have improved operating profit in the third quarter. The Engineered Products business although we have improving margins with the cutting tool business, basically losing the vacation period in Europe, and we sell about half our cutting tools business in Europe on many of our items. So the cutting tool business is split. We’re going to see that seasonality and vacation schedules in the U.S. So we’re going to see the Engineered Products business even though we’re continuing to improve on pricing and penetration somewhat down, not a lot but, yes.
Then we get to Flat-Rolled Products. Now Flat-Rolled Products as you saw on the first quarter we had a $42 million operating margin we’re not going to get there and these other two segments are not going to offset that division when we start talking about metal mismatches coupled with lower volume. So in the end, we’re talking something lower than the second quarter.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
