componenttext: Good luck, continuing to penetrate into these markets and I think you guys are doing a great job on the titanium side and certainly the aerospace and energy markets, foreign markets making a lot of progress there. If I could just ask one other question, the new rolling mill, what’s the timetable for that too to begin commissioning that you had talked about in your comments?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: This is about a 40 month project. So that puts us out to basically 2013. We have as you noted in our comments we’ve got about $50 million reduction in our estimated spend this year. So we’re out into 2013 with that start-up.
componenttext: This is about a 40 month project. So that puts us out to basically 2013. We have as you noted in our comments we’ve got about $50 million reduction in our estimated spend this year. So we’re out into 2013 with that start-up.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Olin with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Olin with Cleveland Research.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So I’m going to bite on the 425 comments because it’s something that interests me. I have kind of run through the numbers in terms of what I think the market potential is and I come up with roughly 5 million pounds of kind of visible market share oppo
componenttext: So I’m going to bite on the 425 comments because it’s something that interests me. I have kind of run through the numbers in terms of what I think the market potential is and I come up with roughly 5 million pounds of kind of visible market share opportunities, and then I assume 20 bucks a pounds and that’s kind of where you’re getting the $100 million from. Have you gone through any kind of analysis on how big or how much market share you could take with this new product?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just give you my opinion, Chris. You were down at our tour of the Carolina facility when we showed you the product and showed you how it forms and showed you that product that basically looks like aluminum sheet coil, you can unroll. It’s just re
componenttext:
Let me just give you my opinion, Chris. You were down at our tour of the Carolina facility when we showed you the product and showed you how it forms and showed you that product that basically looks like aluminum sheet coil, you can unroll. It’s just really a game changer. So when we look at this, we basically are getting inquires across every mill product segment of the titanium market today. We are basically getting inquiries in every product form that we make, from wire all the way through thick plate. So I could almost say that we don’t know its total potential, but we do know that those markets are basically the entire 6-4 spectrum of mill products in the titanium business.
Now, we know we’re not going to replace 6-4 across the board, but this product is going to take share and it’s going to place us in the business where we have never been before. We came out of the Farnborough Air Show with a list of inquiries and follow-ups that on a spreadsheet take up two full pages of people that wanted to get samples, want us to come talk about it, want us to see what they do, want us to see if we can fit their applications, just coming out of the Farnborough Air Show.
So how fast we go, it’s going to be based on how fast the customer can reengineer to use these products and also how fast we can gear up to get to the volume levels that we’re talking about. Now, when we look at this product, my comment around hundreds of millions of dollars, this is a proprietary product that has a patent on it through around 2017. So when we look at that, we know that this product is worth hundreds of millions of dollars to this corporation and we also know that we’re being pleasantly surprised about people contacting us that are not to replace other materials or in other designs to lightweight their applications that are currently using today steel or alumina.
So because of its formability and its ability to be cold-formed, the total cost, their net size, total cost and availability of sizes and lead times brings this product to the forefront of the new application across all of our market segments. So I can’t tell you what it is but, Chris, you have a good head for numbers and applications, the question is how fast does it come and how fast can we get these things into place. We have the characterizations done. We have the Mil-Handbook-6 for aerospace complete. We have people testing it now. So it’s a question of how many hits and how fast we can ramp up.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess when I looked at it from the channel point of view, it seems to be most popular within defense right now. So I would assume that if you were successful in terms of penetrating the market, you could see some defense contracts maybe on the plate and
componenttext: I guess when I looked at it from the channel point of view, it seems to be most popular within defense right now. So I would assume that if you were successful in terms of penetrating the market, you could see some defense contracts maybe on the plate and sheet side coming up over the next year, but it would probably take a couple of years to get on some of these aerospace application. So maybe a longer curve after some initial contracts, is that a good way to look at it?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think there are certain applications that we’re getting inquiries for that would be since it is a direct replacement for 6-4 there’s certain applications that could be substituted almost instantaneously in lower cost, so we’ll see some aerospace a
componenttext: I think there are certain applications that we’re getting inquiries for that would be since it is a direct replacement for 6-4 there’s certain applications that could be substituted almost instantaneously in lower cost, so we’ll see some aerospace applications before I would ask you to consider that thought and looking into your studies. I agree with you on the program side, it’ll be as fast as a new program comes on. There will be this product on a new program some place, just when does the new program come on.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Last question I have, just on the nickel alloy market. I heard you on the jet engine strength, but have you seen any kind of near-term hiccup in terms of orders here on the jet engine side? Is there anything in terms of the adjustment negative occurring?
componenttext: Last question I have, just on the nickel alloy market. I heard you on the jet engine strength, but have you seen any kind of near-term hiccup in terms of orders here on the jet engine side? Is there anything in terms of the adjustment negative occurring?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: There is no hiccup. I would say that the second quarter flattened out in growth. The first quarter aren’t like a catch-up. Let’s just get everything you can get as fast as you can get it, but right now what we are seeing is a moderation of that to the
componenttext:
There is no hiccup. I would say that the second quarter flattened out in growth. The first quarter aren’t like a catch-up. Let’s just get everything you can get as fast as you can get it, but right now what we are seeing is a moderation of that to the second quarter. As I looked at the second half, we’ve given you some guidance around the 7% or 8%, but that growth in the first half at 30% of quarter is not talking about operating profit coming through. It is not going to happen in the second half, but it’s a sizeable growth when you compare it to anything else in the U.S. markets.
We’re double, triple GDP growth of there. So we are pretty happy with that size and we are really happy with the new announced single-aisle build rates and we are happy with the ramp up finally of the 787 and within the next 30 months of A350. So, I don’t think we would call anything we’ve seen so far a hiccup. I’d call it a flattening of growth.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me, throw out one last one. Anything different on the 737 wing redesign, have you heard something different from your suppliers or your customers?
componenttext: Let me, throw out one last one. Anything different on the 737 wing redesign, have you heard something different from your suppliers or your customers?

componenttext: No, I think I have addressed that in my last comments. I have my own personal views of it, but we haven’t got any new information to share on that.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Levenson with Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Levenson with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just in relation to what you are talking about for third quarter, certainly second quarter had the startup and idle costs and the LIFO reserve in there, is the number you’re suggesting for second quarter also going to include startup, idle facility and
componenttext: Just in relation to what you are talking about for third quarter, certainly second quarter had the startup and idle costs and the LIFO reserve in there, is the number you’re suggesting for second quarter also going to include startup, idle facility and LIFO costs or is that something you think is running off now?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think given on a startup cost, I think given the systematic approach we’re taking in Rowley because most of that is really coming out of Rowley. We will continue to see some startup cost in the third quarter, it may not be quite at the level of
componenttext:
Steve, I think given on a startup cost, I think given the systematic approach we’re taking in Rowley because most of that is really coming out of Rowley. We will continue to see some startup cost in the third quarter, it may not be quite at the level of the second quarter, but it won’t be all that far away we don’t think at this time.
The LIFO side, as you know, we reevaluate that every quarter based upon where we think raw material costs, primarily raw material costs, but it’s all the costs, its labor and overhead to come up with the current year index. But it’s really primarily driven by raw material costs. So we’ll reevaluate where we think raw material costs will be at the end of the year. If that reevaluation is consistent with our assumptions that we’re making today, the $5.5 million is a catch-up, because we didn’t book anything in the first quarter. So it will be half of that in the third quarter if the assumptions remain consistent.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010

componenttext: Well, I think as we look forward, Steve, we’re happy to be a totally integrated sponge producer. I think scrap prices continue to rise. They are up $4 in the first six months of this year. I think as we look at the restructuring of the industry with a lot more near-net size coming in from VSMPO out of Russia into the Boeing Corporation, there is going to be a lot less scrap in the U.S. So I don’t expect those scrap prices to moderate. So I’m glad to have the sponge production.

componenttext: Well, we’ve looked at the history, I don’t believe we’re going to see those prices peak the way we did the last time, but there was people that when we were talking about scrap prices moving back towards $7.750 thought we were crazy. componenttextpreview: I think you mentioned earlier that the aero-engine business is improving and the question is does this richen your mix in the High Performance Metals nickel alloys? Could you comment on the two quarters of price declines we’ve seen even though nickel pr
componenttext: I think you mentioned earlier that the aero-engine business is improving and the question is does this richen your mix in the High Performance Metals nickel alloys? Could you comment on the two quarters of price declines we’ve seen even though nickel price have averaged higher over that same period?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the simple answer to the question is the aero-engine demand is a higher value product than, for example, rotating quality aero engine nickel products are obviously higher values than static. You look at average selling prices. Our average selling pri
componenttext:
Yes, the simple answer to the question is the aero-engine demand is a higher value product than, for example, rotating quality aero engine nickel products are obviously higher values than static. You look at average selling prices. Our average selling prices are nickel and specialty alloys and the specialty alloys are primarily low nickel-bearing grades for industrial applications and oil and gas. So they have a lower selling price than higher nickel-bearing grades do or richer alloy mix or jet engine alloy mix.
So when you look at our average selling prices for that we disclosed, it is heavily mix sensitive. I think it is fair to say that on the aero-engine or the high value market side that there are two pieces of transaction price. One is the surcharges and with nickel going up, surcharges go up accordingly, and the second is base prices and we are seeing some improvement in base prices due to the improving demand picture.

componenttextpreview: As you know John, it’s dependent upon two things. It’s dependent upon the surcharges and it’s dependent upon the base price. I think we are seeing, first of all, it’s a combination of volume, which Pat has already addressed and it’s a combinatio
componenttext:
As you know John, it’s dependent upon two things. It’s dependent upon the surcharges and it’s dependent upon the base price. I think we are seeing, first of all, it’s a combination of volume, which Pat has already addressed and it’s a combination when you look at the kind of volume that in, both Europe and the U.S. and the impact I think that our assumption is that base prices are going to be more competitive in the third quarter than they were in the second quarter. Surcharges will be what they are. That’s very transparent and it’s dependent upon what all the raw material costs fell into our end. Those are fairly well known now because of the two months lag in terms of how the surcharges work.
So it’s primarily volume, some moderation of base prices and product mix, including the difference between high value as well as the standard grade. Then, finally, the biggest impact in the quarter is what we’ve already talked about and that is the surcharge mismatch because of the fairly dramatic fall from the April and May highs of nickel, but also chrome and iron units to what they are today and they how they match up against the surcharge. So, all of that is really driving the impact as we see the flat-rolled products in the third quarter.

componenttext: I think you’ll have to look at the design that the new planes will have. The design of the twin-aisle that came out with the composite and titanium, which is clearly titanium win. If you’re looking at what could happen with single-aisles, I think you might see a competitive alternative, but it’s the best chance aluminum has. So the question is whether you get other redesigns or whether you start to see a twin-aisle shrunk to a single-aisle type aircraft with the same design. If that’s the case, titanium wins.

componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered, but could you expand on your prior comments regarding your oil drilling restrictions in the U.S. Is this just a timing issue as equipment has moved or is there more to it than this?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven’t seen much impact in terms of our existing sales and businesses. 40% of what we are doing is now in international sale, so only 60% was in the U.S. With the Marcellus gas in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, that was a major increase in dr
componenttext:
Well, we haven’t seen much impact in terms of our existing sales and businesses. 40% of what we are doing is now in international sale, so only 60% was in the U.S. With the Marcellus gas in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, that was a major increase in drilling and drilling rigs and tools and pipe and all those kind of things.
So what we can’t detect and what I suspect is that if we hadn’t had the moratorium, the business would have been better, a lot better. But it is better without it, because it’s growing so fast with the Marcellus gas and our ability to penetrate these markets on an international basis. So our business is up in total. I wish it could have been up more. I don’t think it’s a good thing long term for the industry to see these rigs move or to have a moratorium on drilling, when we’re a nation that needs this energy and we need it domestically.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the third quarter 2010 Allegheny Technologies earnings conference call. My name is Keisha and I’ll be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct
componenttext:
Good day ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the third quarter 2010 Allegheny Technologies earnings conference call. My name is Keisha and I’ll be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session (Operator instructions). As a reminder this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Dan Greenfield, Senior Director of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications. Please proceed.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you Keisha. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Allegheny Technologies earnings conference call for the third quarter 2010. This conference call is being broadcast on our Web site at www.atimetals.com. Members of the media have been invited to listen
componenttext:
Thank you Keisha. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Allegheny Technologies earnings conference call for the third quarter 2010. This conference call is being broadcast on our Web site at www.atimetals.com. Members of the media have been invited to listen to this call.
Participating in the call today are Pat Hassey, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Rich Harshman, President and Chief Operating Officer, and Dale Reid, Senior Vice President, Finance and Principal Financial Officer. All references to net income and earnings in this conference call mean net incomes and earnings attributable to ATI.
After some initial comments, we will ask for questions. During the question-and-answer session, please limit yourself to two questions to be considerate of others on the line. Please note that all forward-looking statements this afternoon are subject to various assumptions and caveats as noted in the earnings release. Actual results may differ materially.
Here is Pat Hassey.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and thanks to everyone joining us for today’s call. Our key global markets are performing well. We’ve seen strong year-on-year recovery as sales increased 52% in the third quarter or 39% for the full year to-date 2009. Sales for the first
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and thanks to everyone joining us for today’s call. Our key global markets are performing well. We’ve seen strong year-on-year recovery as sales increased 52% in the third quarter or 39% for the full year to-date 2009. Sales for the first nine months of 2010 are just $45 million below our sales for all of 2009. We continue to improve the efficiency of our operations.
Cost reductions year-to-date are $102 million. We’ve exceeded our $100 million goal for cost reductions in 2010 and nine months. With a strong cash balance and a strong balance sheet, cash on hand increased to over $443 million. Net debt to total capitalization improved to 23% and total debt to capitalization improved to 34%.
Our strategy has been to target certain market sectors that we believe are in the long term secular growth trends that are greater than the average global GDP. We still see 2010 as a transition year to the resumption of strong secular growth in those key global markets.
Order entry and optimism has improved from several markets. We recently announced price increases for our nickel based alloys and specialty alloys both in long products and flat rolled products.
In addition, Uniti our industrial titanium joint venture announced a price increase for CP titanium products. Because of extending lead times, these price increases are expected to impact 2011 performance beginning in the first quarter.
As we previously announced, third quarter operating profit was negatively impacted by certain issues. First is a volatile and erratic price of LME traded nickel. We booked a significant LIFO catch up charge in the third quarter. From April to July the average LME nickel price dropped by 26%. From July to October it rose 23%. So we had to change our assumptions and book the charge.
We now expect a full year 2010 LIFO inventory valuation reserve charge of approximately $54 million. So, the third quarter catch-up charge was an additional $33 million. Currently, we expect a $14 million LIFO charge in the fourth quarter 2010.
These LIFO charges mainly impact our flat-rolled product results. In addition, the nickel price movement has been causing unusual buying patterns by some customers, particularly for our standard stainless products.
Shipments in September were surprisingly strong part of this is likely due to customer buying to beat the rising October surcharge. October buying is also strong as customers are trying to beat the November surcharge increase.
While month-on-month shipments are choppy, we are seeing recovery. Overall demand for standard stainless products is keeping paced with the modest GDP growth of the U.S. and European economies.
Other issues that impacted the third quarter operating profit are the start-up, idle facility, and major maintenance charges.
High Performance Metals segment operating profit was negatively impacted by approximately $12 million of start-up and idle facility, costs associated with our titanium sponge operations. We expect these charges to be similar in the fourth quarter.
By approximately $7 million related to a two-week shutdown of our zirconium facilities to adjust inventory levels and perform major maintenance. We do not expect this charge to continue in the fourth quarter 2010.
Flat-Rolled Products segment operating profit was negatively impacted by $5 million of higher than normal major maintenance expenses. We do not expect such a charge in the fourth quarter 2010. While these start-up costs have been a headwind to 2010 operating profit, we expect our strategic capital projects to benefit ATI performance in 2011 and beyond.
The melt shop consolidation at our Brackenridge, Pennsylvania melt shop is complete. We reduced our footprint and expect to benefit by up to $30 million of annualized cost reductions beginning in 2011.
Our titanium and super alloy forge facility in Bakers, North Carolina continues to obtain customer qualifications and has much needed forging and finishing capacity and capabilities. Timing on completion of this project looks good as demand is strengthening from our aerospace, oil and gas and electrical energy customers.
The ramp up at our Raleigh, Utah premium titanium sponge facility is continuing. We are producing sponge and we are now working on standardizing the process and improving yields.
We expect capital expenditures on our new hot rolling and processing facility to begin increasing in the fourth quarter 2010, and we now expect 2010 capital investments to be approximately $250 million.
Strength in our key markets is providing the foundation for resumption of strong secular growth beginning in 2011. We believe aerospace remains a long-term growth market for ATI. Both Boeing and Airbus have announced planned increases to their production schedules. Their backlogs are strong and they are being extended by new orders.
Single-aisle aircraft production rates are growing. Double-aisle aircraft rates such as for the 777 are also growing. The 787 has been delayed, but we expect demand from this next generation aircraft to pickup throughout 2011.
For ATI, aero engine demand is being driven by all of the aircraft schedules. In addition, aero engine spares, our spare demand is being driven by a strong recovery in passenger and freight traffic and also the growing size of the global fleet.
Now, turning to the oil and gas market, U.S. and international drill rig counts continue a steady climb driving our order backlogs and pushing out lead times for certain products.
ATI revenue from this market for the first nine months of 2010 has grown by 65% compared to the same period in 2009. In addition direct international sales accounted for 42% of our sales to the oil and gas market during the first nine months of 2010.
We expect this strong demand to continue, we’re seeing opportunities to supply our products, particularly specialty plate for several large global projects.
Demand is strong in our high performance metal segment for our specialty steels used for non-magnetic drill collars and for our nickel-based alloys for completion tools. Demand will improve for our tungsten drilling products.
In the chemical process industry, we’re seeing opportunities for several large sea water desalinization plants that could potentially, significantly drive demand for CP titanium. Titanium is being considered as a substitute for copper nickel alloys in these applications.
In the electrical energy market, demand of our grain-oriented electrical steel products remained relatively flat but at 80% capacity levels for ATI. Demand from the nuclear electrical energy market, for our zirconium products has remained flat while activity has picked up for specialty alloy plate for spent nuclear fuel storage. Orders improve for our nickel-based super alloys for gas turbines in the quarter.
The medical market reached nearly 6% of sales for the first nine months of 2010. Biomedical sales have been steady at high levels during the year. Demand was strong for our niobium, titanium alloys from the medical equipment market for MRI applications. These are all very good signs for ATI.
ATI is innovating for the future. We are adding innovative new products to improve customer productivity and so that they can make their products better and faster. We have a robust pipeline of new products.
In 2010, we announced the first long term agreement for the use of our new ATI 718 plus alloy for jet engine applications. We expect this innovative new alloy to grow our share in the aero-engine market, particularly as the aircraft build schedules increase.
Following the technical and commercial rollouts of ATI 425 titanium alloy sheet and plate this summer, the team has seen a rush of technical and material enquiries from the aerospace and defense markets, as well as other high end markets. Customer interest in this new product is strong.
Our customers recognize that total cost solutions this new alloy can provide. Customer testing in the early phases of qualification has gone well. Process qualification adoption of a new alloy in the aerospace business will take about 12 to 18 months.
A prototype application constructive of our new alloys is on display this week at the Army USA Annual Meeting in Washington D.C. If you plan to be there, go to the AM General Display and look for a sign that reads ATI and AM General Survivability Solutions. You will see a blast bucket that is tested and proved and made with our new materials.
We recently added titanium fastener stock to our list of diversified product offerings. ATI now provides titanium alloy as well as nickel and specialty alloy fastener stock to the aerospace and defense market.
We expect demand from the fastener supply chain to be strong, when and as airframe production ramps up to meet the new build schedules. We also recently commercialized another new lean duplex stainless steel.
ATI 2102 lean duplex stainless steel contains even less nickel and moly than our other lean duplex ATI 2003 alloy. This is a global leader with a broad range of super duplex, duplex, and lean alloys. Demand for duplex stainless steel is growing as customers look for alternatives that reduce exposure to high and volatile raw material costs.
ATI Ludlum is working with our new ATI Powder business to develop a line of borated stainless steels. Borated stainless requires a complex chemistry that is not easily melded, thus the use of powders. These alloys are used for the storage of spent nuclear fuel.
During the first nine months of 2010, we’ve been navigating through some choppiness and uncertainty that often characterizes a recovery year. We see 2010 as a transition year to the resumption of strong secular growth in our key global markets. Our new assets and innovative products are setting a solid foundation for growth.
In my personal view, I feel more optimistic today about 2011 than I did at any other time during this year in 2010. We are now seeing more evidence that the strong recovery is underway in our key markets, volume is up, asset utilization is increasing and pushing out lead times. We announced several price increases that we believe will permit us to increase the returns on our available capacity.
ATI is growing our share in these markets with new products. We’re being recognized by new customers as a strategic source to do all that we can now provide and our industry leading quality and service. We’re growing our share through our market sector teams.
We’re better positioned than ever in the aerospace, defense, oil and gas and nuclear energy markets. Because of market demand, we introduced titanium fastener stock and near-net shapes to the aerospace business.
We invested in the machining center at our Sheffield, U.K. facility and we’re now providing fully machined drill collars and other products to the oil and gas market. Demand has been terrific for this product and lead times are pushed out well into 2011. These new assets are also capable of machining our products for the aerospace and defense industry.
The actions we have taken allow us to improve our share and grow faster than the markets we’ve identified that have secular growth trends that are greater than the global average GDP.
Frankly, we feel very good about 2011 and beyond. However, factors beyond our control really impact our short-term visibility. Because of so much uncertainty, particularly in the U.S., and the volatility of many raw material prices, we cannot predict the actions of our customers particularly in the final weeks of this year, it is just uncertain.
For example, will customers add inventory, maintain current inventory levels or reduced or their actions be impacted in the short-term by the uncertainty of the lame duck Congress, actions by the Federal Reserve, uncertain regulatory environment or other outside or internal factors of their business? The answer to that is I just don’t know.
What I do have is a strong conviction that 2011 will be far better for ATI than 2010. That 2012 will be better than 2011, and that 2013 continues and will be far better than 2012. So we have a very optimistic view of the long-term prospects, starting next year and beginning to go forward. I think that’s enough comments from me and we’ll open up the meeting now for any questions anyone might have.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good, thanks. Just two questions from me. Wanted to ask about how you’re seeing the impact of new capacity coming from the Thyssen stainless mill? The second one is really in response to the article we saw on American metal market, on the sidelines of t
componenttext: Good, thanks. Just two questions from me. Wanted to ask about how you’re seeing the impact of new capacity coming from the Thyssen stainless mill? The second one is really in response to the article we saw on American metal market, on the sidelines of the titanium conference, talking about Boeing’s outlook for the restocking being several years away and your thoughts on that as well.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let’s jump on the first one which is the Thyssen facilities. Thyssen is just starting up those facilities, as you know, they have a fairly strong position in the U.S. today, with their Mexinox operations and also imports coming in from Europe and other
componenttext:
Let’s jump on the first one which is the Thyssen facilities. Thyssen is just starting up those facilities, as you know, they have a fairly strong position in the U.S. today, with their Mexinox operations and also imports coming in from Europe and other areas through Canada into the country. So this whole facility in our view in Alabama is to streamline our operations and to bring stainless into their market that they already have a large share of today. So they’re starting up their first mill.
What they’re doing, as we’ve heard at this point in time is, it’s a test, they’re taking basically small orders. They’re not trimming the order or looking for confirmation of the quality out of this piece of equipment and they are basically in a cold rolling stage. They are actually bringing in white coils out of Germany. So they are not even being hot rolled. Eventually they’ll be bringing in slab from Germany to roll here and they’ll roll it on their new hot rolling facilities and then they’ll finish it in their cold rolling facilities. We think Thyssen is a good competitor. I think they are a good company. They provide a good product and I don’t think it changes much in the U.S. market except for their cost structure.
The second question on Boeing restocking. I don’t know if there is a restocking issue, but Boeing has certainly a growing issue. So what we see is that these airplane programs are booked to the future. They are going to continue to ramp. We have a situation next year that the 787 for all practical purposes is going to ramp up throughout 2011. They are increasing their production in their single isles going forward in the 777, in the 747-8.
So whatever inventories that they have on hand, those inventories are going to be coming down. In our particular circumstances, we have agreements to supply that customer at certain levels. Those agreements call for take or pay volumes at certain levels and prices and so we will be producing at least to those volumes as we go forward.
I think there is also good possibilities that as the rest of the titanium business as we see it begins to ramp on these new projects throughout the world that continuing supplies will start to see prices moving up, scrap prices are moving up. Now I think one supplier just announced price increases for next year on sponge, we see rising scrap prices in our own domestic markets which make our investments in sponge look better to us every day.
So, I think as this market ramps up Boeing is going to be very happy. They have any excess inventory on hand as the market ramps up for the production levels that we see coming throughout the industry, not just the aerospace industry, but throughout the world including the desalination projects, chemical processing, projects that we are now seeing coming on the books and being asked for and starting in 2011, 2012, 2013. So, we feel pretty good about the overall supply demand relationship regardless of Boeing.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question, I just want to talk about titanium sponge a bit more. Firstly, just your Rowley sponge facility. Can you give us an update as far as the progress in getting the products that are certified for broader quality products? And then secondly, j
componenttext: First question, I just want to talk about titanium sponge a bit more. Firstly, just your Rowley sponge facility. Can you give us an update as far as the progress in getting the products that are certified for broader quality products? And then secondly, just your overall source in sponge sourcing strategy for 2011, if I remember correctly I think you have some third-party contract that’s rolling off and I’m just curious to see if you’re going to be trying to supply more internally through Rowley or if you extended that contract or what’s going on there?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just start this way. It looks like our mill product shipments including unities conversion and in 2010 are going to approach quantities in the high 30s. So, we’re going to have 37 million, 38 million pounds of final production ship this yea
componenttext:
Well, let me just start this way. It looks like our mill product shipments including unities conversion and in 2010 are going to approach quantities in the high 30s. So, we’re going to have 37 million, 38 million pounds of final production ship this year. That number is going to increase substantially as we look at production in 2011. We are talking volumes way up in double-digits.
So, we need sponge and we need the production out of Rowley and we also have a fairly large amount of production coming in from outside the company which we’ve always said that we’re going to do because we do not have enough have sponge on hand to handle our own fully loaded product lines. We still see titanium moving up into quantities over these next ‘11, ‘12 and ‘13, but we think we’ll be shipping 60 million pounds of finished product, including our Uniti joint ventures. So, you see where we’re coming from in overall sponge capacity. We will continue to buy on the outside.
So, with the Rowley facility our goal is to get that plant up and running, rotating quality, making rotating quality sponge. In order to do that we have to have a standardized process that is in control and capable of producing rotating quality each and every day of the week across all 36 sets of units there. So, where we are today? We’re in production. We are still continuing to develop that process, but we feel that we have it in control with capable and locked in on making rotating quality parts, until we have that process locked in then the product that we are producing goes to lower grade products such as B quality, or aircraft frame quality, or industrial quality titanium.
So there is two things that are happening, we are locking in the processes we need to produce the rotating quality. We’re getting the equipment and its capable and under control and we are working on ways to make sure that we have the right yields and the right recoveries out of what we are doing. So, this is a process that we’re continuing to improve. Hopefully, early next year we’ll have what we want in place and we’ll begin the qualification process for rotating quality.

componenttext: And then just secondly, I am curious to know what happened with the nickel-based alloy and titanium shipments sequentially? We had seen a decline there? Can you give us a feel for what happened? What were the moving parts and then what we can expect in the fourth quarter and then in 2011?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what you’re seeing is product mix shifts from one category of finished product to different one. We’re selling a lot less in. We’re selling more fabricated parts so that, that moves the tenants around on the titanium side. We’ve seen a lot
componenttext:
I think what you’re seeing is product mix shifts from one category of finished product to different one. We’re selling a lot less in. We’re selling more fabricated parts so that, that moves the tenants around on the titanium side. We’ve seen a lot more nickel growth into the third quarter. We’ll see that into the fourth quarter. I think we’re seeing nickel growing into the fourth quarter and we’re going to see titanium kind of staying flat and up in the aero-engine side, down in the airframe side, through the end of the year.
A lot of this is determined by needs of customers into the first quarter so answering your second part about the first quarter, we think that we’re going to ramp fairly quickly next year into these higher quantities beginning early in the year and we kind of look at the fourth quarter as I mentioned earlier ending the year somewhere 37 million pound to 38 million pound. So we shipped 29 million so far including conversion work. It’s just back and forth between forms whether it’s going to be sheet, plate, and rounds whatever. So its mix and its end markets we’re supplying a lot of metal outside the aerospace market these days. So oil and gas, its chemical processing, its airframe, its aero engine. So, all those factors are moving parts.

componenttext: Okay. What sort of volumes are you thinking about in terms of the desalination opportunities?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Those are huge volumes. Each one of those facilities assuming that the copper, nickel is replaced by titanium and the reason for that is that in the Middle East area or in warm salt water titanium is performing very well. Copper is leaching into the ocean
componenttext:
Those are huge volumes. Each one of those facilities assuming that the copper, nickel is replaced by titanium and the reason for that is that in the Middle East area or in warm salt water titanium is performing very well. Copper is leaching into the oceans and you have fish problems and all that kind of things. So suddenly we have a brand new market that is not a new market, but it’s a really brand new great market for titanium products.
Each one of these desalinization plants, if you could visualize it in your mind between all the equipment that goes into this, and the power units that run it, and the size of the pieces of equipment that condense and change and distill and all this kind of things, it’s about a block long. There is all the tubing, all the piping that come from the ocean end and when you talk about a project here, you’re talking millions of pounds of titanium. I mean by millions of pounds, 12 to 15 million pounds of titanium at a time. These are huge projects, changes the dynamics of the entire titanium supply.

componenttextpreview: I am sorry. I missed your question. Powder Metals? Powder Metals is fitting and great. These are super scientist kind of guys. We are looking at those guys as how they can improve products and move our product mix up across all of our product forms. They
componenttext:
I am sorry. I missed your question. Powder Metals? Powder Metals is fitting and great. These are super scientist kind of guys. We are looking at those guys as how they can improve products and move our product mix up across all of our product forms. They are now as you may have seen, we have moved them into as a sub business unit of ATI Allvac. So they are working directly in the aero engine business and in the airframe business.
We are also working on the borated stainless steel sheet and plate and they have other development projects for other jet engine customers and government projects in all kinds of things. So, this was a great fit for us. We like the technology. It was needed in the company. We think it’s a product of the future growing each year and the integration into ATI has been very successful.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Regarding pensions as you know basically there are a couple of factors that come into the calculations. One is what’s happening on the asset side and so far our asset returns this year have been fairly good, but we won’t know what that final number is
componenttext:
Regarding pensions as you know basically there are a couple of factors that come into the calculations. One is what’s happening on the asset side and so far our asset returns this year have been fairly good, but we won’t know what that final number is going to be obviously, until we reach the end of the year.
The other factor obviously is the point in time determination of a discount rate. We’ve obviously, seen interest rates come down over the course of the year, but depending upon what happens with the Fed and what happens with interest rate between now and the end of the year, we will see where that comes out. Obviously, declining interest rates are not helpful to us from a pension expense standpoint, but to some extent those are somewhat offset by what happens on the asset side. So, sitting here right now it’s a little bit too early to tell where we’re going end up the year, so we’ll have to wait and see.

componenttext: Yes, thanks for taking the call. Couple questions, I guess. One is in Q4, I recognize there is some volatility and it’s hard to predict kind of the year-end inventory management by our customers, but we do know what the surcharges are on all the products and we know that the LIFO will be a 14 million and we think net, net in earnings what kind of ballpark, will that be in $0.25 to $0.35?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Pat said it really quite frankly very well. The things that you just mentioned, we know that where the surcharge will be in November. We know what the trend is in terms of nickel, remember nickel isn’t the only element of the surcharge but we kn
componenttext:
I think Pat said it really quite frankly very well. The things that you just mentioned, we know that where the surcharge will be in November. We know what the trend is in terms of nickel, remember nickel isn’t the only element of the surcharge but we know what that’s doing and is likely to do in December or have a reasonable idea.
I think what we don’t know quite frankly is where the customer behavior pattern will be and Pat articulated the uncertainty I think that exists in the short-term, you see where the average number of months inventory is on the stainless side, it’s really pretty low. So, customers are reacting near-term to a fairly longer lead times on the stainless sides than they were maybe nine months ago, but certainly still fairly short lead times.
So, I think our view of the fourth quarter is that the issues that we’re dealing with are the same ones that the customers are dealing with and we’re going to have some costs that we incurred in the third quarter that won’t be there in the fourth quarter, Pat articulated those and those are all in our earnings release. In terms of what the volume is going to end up being is really going to be dependent upon what actions the customers do in terms of their yearend inventory management, and what they need. I think the fourth quarter is going to be the best, we can make it, and we’re heading into the first quarter of 2011, and 2011 quite frankly with a lot of steam and very optimistic outlook on how 2011 looks.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s actually, as you can talk about longer term period than the fourth quarter right now.
componenttext: It’s actually, as you can talk about longer term period than the fourth quarter right now.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: To that question actually titanium scrap prices up, surcharges no prices weaker. In Q1, could you remind us again kind of what you anticipate average metal prices will do titanium side, come Q1 relative to this year, and I’d say that (inaudible) you do
componenttext: To that question actually titanium scrap prices up, surcharges no prices weaker. In Q1, could you remind us again kind of what you anticipate average metal prices will do titanium side, come Q1 relative to this year, and I’d say that (inaudible) you do have quarterly surcharge above that, so some of that benefit of the rising scrap has been recognized through the year. So maybe you can give us a sense for how much is going to tie it to annual re-indexing versus the quarterly surcharge with respect to your LPA and your non-LPA base business. So we can get a sense for what the price likely to be, and then as a second part of that, if you don’t mind can you give us some color on any traction you’ve had on the titanium faster products. Have you signed any new contracts there or what we could expect out of that thing.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just put some color around it. I’m not going to talk about specific price actions that we’re going to take. I will say that the first thing in a recovery of any product line or in our businesses is the return of volume. We have now seen in 2010
componenttext:
Let me just put some color around it. I’m not going to talk about specific price actions that we’re going to take. I will say that the first thing in a recovery of any product line or in our businesses is the return of volume. We have now seen in 2010 the return of volume to fairly good levels and we’re anticipating very good double digit growth next year in the overall titanium market. I also mentioned that there is now projects outside of aerospace that will take very, very large volumes of sponge and melting and finished product in order to supply and they are coming from all over the world. Mostly out of Asia, and the Mid East. So these are big new projects that change the dynamics of that industry.
I think changing dynamic will be the price of scrap and as you look at the price of scrap that will influence the overall price of what sponge will sell for on a spot basis. So those two things in the past, I think we can presumably to price increases both in the surcharge, in the demand and in the pricing of the product. We have seen them move rapidly in the past in very short periods of time. So I am not going to predict what the pricing could be, but I will reiterate anyone that has inventories of titanium will probably be glad to have them, as they move into next year. So we are bullish about the titanium market and its volume and in its ability to increase revenues, unit revenues.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Couple of things. Please pardon me for not being very smart about this, but we’ve seen titanium scrap be relatively tight all year. Again, I don’t know if you can give some more color on how much you’re seeing it move up here in August, September, O
componenttext:
Couple of things. Please pardon me for not being very smart about this, but we’ve seen titanium scrap be relatively tight all year. Again, I don’t know if you can give some more color on how much you’re seeing it move up here in August, September, October timeframe, but I’d love to get a color there? And then on the other hand, you got the Boeing guys saying, Well, we got enough titanium and we’re not really going to order much more than the minimum for at least a couple of years. And you’ve got lots of demand and it just seems like there is a disconnect.
I guess maybe there is another way for me to try to itemize this, so I can make the more sense out of it. I’m sure you talked about this until you’re blew in the face Pat, and I don’t want to beat the dead horse so to speak, but I really like to get your sense about how you feel the disconnect between titanium scrap and maybe some of the comments at the OEM level, how you reconcile all that?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, you are a really smart guy, so I would ever say I am not too educated about anything I have ever talked to you about, but let me just put some facts on the table that may frame this for you a little bit differently. Number one, in the scrap in Unite
componenttext: Mark, you are a really smart guy, so I would ever say I am not too educated about anything I have ever talked to you about, but let me just put some facts on the table that may frame this for you a little bit differently. Number one, in the scrap in United States, VSMPO and Boeing’s joint venture for producing near-net parts have started up in Russia, so we have less scrap in United States at least on that end of the business than what we’ve had in past years. So, there is some difference in what scrap 464 and aerospace products be.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, the actual supply of scrap has come down?
componenttext: So, the actual supply of scrap has come down?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It could be less, yes, absolutely. Two, the industrial markets for titanium are growing very rapidly on a global basis, as I’ve mentioned several times here or so. Scrap is going to go into that kind of a market. Now, in actual changes we ended the year
componenttext:
It could be less, yes, absolutely. Two, the industrial markets for titanium are growing very rapidly on a global basis, as I’ve mentioned several times here or so. Scrap is going to go into that kind of a market. Now, in actual changes we ended the year with bulk-weldable solid scrap around $3.50 a pound. I think the latest buy we have made is $7, $7 for processed bulk-weldable scrap.
So the fact of the matter is the market tells you it’s in short supply. I don’t care what anybody else says, when you got $7 of bulk-weldables it’s different than in January, like twice as much. We know that business is increasing next year in the double-digit rate, so this is going to get somewhat shorter. We on our own revered paths have locked in pads so that the scrap that we generate through our total value chain much of it will come back to us and not go to the open market. So we have all those factors sitting out there.
I think the other determination as to how much supply is at any particular customer is there is a key phrase in there that we have to work on and I don’t have any better understanding than you do, but the phrase goes like this. I have this much supply under current build rates. So, I am using so much today, and if I add it all together that’s how long it’s going to take me to get down to the level I want.
When I look at increasing build rates or a new program coming on or, for example, let’s just use one customer like the 175 new F-15’s, I think it’s F-15 or F-18. F-18 is out of St. Louis that were unexpected those are all titanium bulkheads and things like that. Does that change your time to move inventories? All these things have some assumptions in them.
So, our information, what I am giving you is some color as I think that titanium is getting momentum, scrap prices are up, we know that production will be up and there is some big projects out there that will as they come through, can really change the dynamics of the whole thing.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so while the OEM aerospace business is providing a base load right now, there is enough other stuff going on and that you’re going to see growth in the interim and then when that does come on, you have a leveraged upside, I guess, is that a fair way
componenttext: And so while the OEM aerospace business is providing a base load right now, there is enough other stuff going on and that you’re going to see growth in the interim and then when that does come on, you have a leveraged upside, I guess, is that a fair way of thinking about it?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think when you I think a lot of people think of titanium usage in the airframe and they are thinking just of the 787 program but there is all of the models have some component of titanium in it and then you get into the engine side so the engine side is
componenttext: I think when you I think a lot of people think of titanium usage in the airframe and they are thinking just of the 787 program but there is all of the models have some component of titanium in it and then you get into the engine side so the engine side is growing. The 737 is ramping up and growing. The A320 is ramping up and growing in terms of volume. The production of the engines to match the ramp up of the double isles is demanding, these are bigger engines that demand more and more titanium metal products for engine set. So it’s more than just 787 program, its every model that the airframers are making and every engine that goes on into those airframe plus, the aftermarket business.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, the other thing that people have to understand is, you don’t make these products out of sponge. You have to melt it and then you have to fabricate it and so the twist points or the pricing points will go into, in the end, product form. Can I get a
componenttext: Mark, the other thing that people have to understand is, you don’t make these products out of sponge. You have to melt it and then you have to fabricate it and so the twist points or the pricing points will go into, in the end, product form. Can I get a piece of plate, can I get a billet, can I get a tube, can I get shape, can I get a sheet because this capacity constraint is going to move from the sponge to the melting to the fabrication of those products and the good news for the company you’re talking about is that we have all those end product fabrications tabs and we have capacities in those pass that other people don’t have.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: One thing, this maybe just a side line, but when you look at the increasing mix of double isle and larger planes in 2012, and those engines that are being used to drive those larger airframes, maybe three times the weight, the final weight, I was just won
componenttext: One thing, this maybe just a side line, but when you look at the increasing mix of double isle and larger planes in 2012, and those engines that are being used to drive those larger airframes, maybe three times the weight, the final weight, I was just wondering is there an easy way to think about the increase in titanium for those bigger engines as opposed to the increase in nickel based alloys? I mean is one side of the metal get more of an upside than the other?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think by the way it is still about 35, 65 something like that. The other way, you really have to do it, the people just look at units and look. Today if people start counting airplane programs simply by units, from a metals producer’s standpoint, you
componenttext: I think by the way it is still about 35, 65 something like that. The other way, you really have to do it, the people just look at units and look. Today if people start counting airplane programs simply by units, from a metals producer’s standpoint, you will get a skewed answer. You really have to do what you are talking about. You have to look at the relationship and the size of the aircraft both in engine and airframe, versus the number of units. So we are in the same boat there.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask one follow up question, and again you guys have got so much growth and so much new programs and projects going on in ‘10 and you look at the Brackenridge consolidation, the ramp up of sponge capacity, all the cost reductions momentum
componenttext: If I could just ask one follow up question, and again you guys have got so much growth and so much new programs and projects going on in ‘10 and you look at the Brackenridge consolidation, the ramp up of sponge capacity, all the cost reductions momentum in general that you have going on, is there any way you can quantify how much less of this kind of start up and new sort of spending activity from a P&L standpoint, how much less of that we are going to see in ‘11 versus ‘10.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well hopefully the startup costs in the primary side of the business will be finished by the end of the first quarter. We are going to have some ramp up costs in the sense of bringing people on and training them, but I think we’ll have the process where
componenttext:
Well hopefully the startup costs in the primary side of the business will be finished by the end of the first quarter. We are going to have some ramp up costs in the sense of bringing people on and training them, but I think we’ll have the process where we want it to be, let’s say, somewhere around the end of the first quarter next year. So that will go away.
The operations and consolidation of Brackenridge are complete. We’re really thrilled of what we have there. In fact, we’re seeing some of those savings today at the Breckenridge plant. The way we’re operating the plant on the new hot mill complex is that it’s a totally separate part of the plant, it’s fenced off and the older part of the plant is operating independent of the new facilities. So that will have no interference or cost factors to the new side of the plant. As time goes forward on the super alloy forging facility, it’s just a matter of getting more products qualified, so we can use the facility for every end product that we would like to use it for. But I think the cost to start up over there is just a question of qualification.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: That was a DLA order for 6-4 plate. DLA is really looking at a different way of buying titanium mill products, primarily in a plate product form to service some of the basic needs of the DOD. We did win that. That was a nice win for ATI. It’s really one
componenttext:
That was a DLA order for 6-4 plate. DLA is really looking at a different way of buying titanium mill products, primarily in a plate product form to service some of the basic needs of the DOD. We did win that. That was a nice win for ATI. It’s really one of the first initial forays, if you will, into supplying titanium product to the DLA. I think the bigger opportunities exist more on the armor side, that’s where we are working, using ATI 425 alloy for fabrication applications that’s the comment that Pat made in his prepared comments at the AUSA show here this week. We’re also working on some high hard steels for armor applications.
So, I think the armor market is a relatively new market for ATI. It’s one that we are focused on from a market sector team standpoint. I think initially at least the applications will be high hard steels and ATI 425 and possibly 6-4 plate, as well. Armor applications primarily plate but also the possibility of some of our casting product that comes out of our Wah Chang operations in high performance metals.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: One more question if I look at the margins in the HPM you have consistently improved over the last couple of quarters along with the profitability 150 basis points in second quarter and then 120 basis points again in the third quarter. This is all I am se
componenttext: One more question if I look at the margins in the HPM you have consistently improved over the last couple of quarters along with the profitability 150 basis points in second quarter and then 120 basis points again in the third quarter. This is all I am sequentially talking about a sequentially increase. Is it, I mean, can we assume that at some point in future you may go back to the margins we saw in ‘05, ‘06, ‘07, ‘08 sort of 30% type of numbers. Are you thinking it is going to be more of a volume opportunity than going to that kind of high margins?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it’s going to be both. I think that certainly the margins that we are making today in that segment aren’t what we expect to make in the ‘11, ‘12, ‘13 time frame as we look at the full spectrum of the capabilities we have both in nickel a
componenttext:
I think it’s going to be both. I think that certainly the margins that we are making today in that segment aren’t what we expect to make in the ‘11, ‘12, ‘13 time frame as we look at the full spectrum of the capabilities we have both in nickel and titanium and specialty alloys and exotic alloys. But I think that the margin dollars if you will, I think we’ve said this before.
Despite what we said earlier, we’re not planning for titanium scrap to be $20 a pound again, like it was in ‘07, but you know what, it may be, who knows. If it is, we pay that eventually, but you have a timing element there, perhaps where you have a short-term advantage. I think that the margin growth and earnings per share growth are going to be a combination of a richer product mix, new products, including powder, higher volumes.
And the benefits of all the cost reductions that we’ve put into these business over the years, and the new products we’re talking about are not only the development of the powder business, but also fastener stock in all alloy systems, not just nickel, but also titanium.
And the end market growth, all of which Pat has talked about earlier. I think as you saw from us the last time, I think we made some prognostications before the last ramp-up of where we would have expect those segment margins to be, and we blew through them. So, I think the one thing you can rest assured of that the margins will be as good as we can make them, but the earnings will come from a variety of different sources.

componenttext: I got two questions. First, at the titanium conference, there was also some comments made about substantial reductions and lot of requirement on future 787 built because of these new and net shapes, and can you help me put this in the context of the total cost solution we talked about earlier, and the price margin versus a volume trade-off impact on ATI, and then secondly on the high performance metals, the last quarter you mentioned that profits of growth 7% to 8% sequentially in 3Q and 4Q, and we certainly saw then third quarter results because this continue to hold true for the fourth quarter?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let’s just take the first one. The interesting part about getting to near net size is unless you change, completely change the product form, some place along the supply chain, the same pounds are being made. For example, you have this new machining join
componenttext:
Let’s just take the first one. The interesting part about getting to near net size is unless you change, completely change the product form, some place along the supply chain, the same pounds are being made. For example, you have this new machining joint venture with VSMPO and Boeing. I am assuming, Boeing is buying from that joint venture and buying much more near net sizes, but VSMPO still has to produce the same amount of product in order to get it into that form. The same amount of metal in the industry is being used, even though Boeing may not be buying it in that form.
The same thing with us, as Boeing comes in and ask for near net size shapes, we actually have improved margins on that product, even though it may be less pounds that they are buying from us, but when we look at the total amount of sponge that we cast, the total going into the melt, into the ingot to make that product, we are still making those units and using those capacities to produce a near net size that is closer for the customer to buy and then we charge more for that product, but it takes the same utilization out of the industry.
So it’s a very complex thing to really understand. It isn’t that the airplane in the total value chain will take less metal. It’s the customer at the end is buying different products that he is buying less metal for more money. The total value chain is still producing basically the same amount of product. So that’s one way to look at it.
I think in terms of pricing, our price increases that we just recently announced, and we just recently announced and we just recently announced on the base price and also that’s the transaction business, and also on our surcharges are pretty well set for the fourth quarter. Those kind of announcements are for product that’s currently being booked into the first quarter of next year not the fourth quarter of this year.

componenttext:
We’re really talking about product forms and you’re talking about product forms that are similar but not exactly the same in terms of the end fabrication or certification. So, schedules for our nickel products are well into the beginning of the first quarter, titanium is out a little bit further.
On the flat-rolled side you might be able to get something of those kind of products that’s plate maybe yet something this year, but if you are really talking about generally we’re booking the first quarter there also. So, whether it’s oil and gas or whether it’s energy or whether it’s jet engine those products are all well into the first quarter. People that have maintained buffers with us or under long-term LTAs that have blocked capacities for the quarter they may be getting their products in a shorter lead time.

componenttextpreview: Thank you. Could you describe the Rowley start-up a little more. Are the losses steady about the same every month or is one month more like two million another month like five million. Do they vary when you try to do a longer production run and do a longe
componenttext: Thank you. Could you describe the Rowley start-up a little more. Are the losses steady about the same every month or is one month more like two million another month like five million. Do they vary when you try to do a longer production run and do a longer sequence, and just give us a flavor of your progress and stay with testing etcetera and qualification?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’m just going to give you an overview answer then I’ll ask Rich to give you a more, if he wants to put any color on it. Basically, John what we’re doing is running sets of units and we are getting sponge from each run. And then we have to make sure
componenttext:
I’m just going to give you an overview answer then I’ll ask Rich to give you a more, if he wants to put any color on it. Basically, John what we’re doing is running sets of units and we are getting sponge from each run. And then we have to make sure we have good sponge, so in the end we have a sporadic issue if we have had a problem with the particular unit for some reason.
But generally speaking, we’re working on improving the yields across the board, and then improving the overall quality that will get us to rotate our quality. Basically the chemistry, it’s coming line and looks pretty good, we’re making progress on that week-on-week, run-on-run, we have a curing issue on these vessels where the first run has some curing to do to it with brand new vessel coming into production versus a vessel that’s under its second or third run, and then training of people and peer process developments. So I think it’s a normal progression. We’re making product, we’re getting sponge out of the facility. We’d like better yields, and we’d like better cost. So that’s what we’re working on. Rich, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I just think John, it’s a fairly uniform experience, I mean, it’s the months don’t vary to that magnitude. I think once we get through the end of this year and all of the 36 furnaces have at least one if not two reduction runs on them and we sta
componenttext:
No. I just think John, it’s a fairly uniform experience, I mean, it’s the months don’t vary to that magnitude. I think once we get through the end of this year and all of the 36 furnaces have at least one if not two reduction runs on them and we start lock in as Pat said, the chemistry, especially after the run and you kind of burn in the retort, the chemistries are really very good. I mean, they’re right there rotating quality, and now you really just have to go through a process of locking in the manufacturing process, once you produced that sponge cake, you got to crush it, you got to inspect it, you got to get it into heat and melt it all the way through and to get the chemistries of the ingot etc., etc.,.
And it’s a fairly long actually manufacturing process. It’s not just loading the tickle on the mag and to the retort and after the seven day or eight day or nine day period you know what you’ve got. You’ve got to take it all the way through melt and it’s a time-consuming process. I think as we get to the end of this year into the first quarter, this is going to be a facility that is going to be producing world-class sponge and we and our shareholders are going to be very happy we have it.

componenttext: Yes, I think we’ve said that we would be somewhere around the $300 million, but we haven’t walked in totally yet. There could be a project that comes along that we really, really like. I think the good news as we look at this year, we ended this quarter with $443 million in cash. Cash seems to be coming through. We have now rebuilt all of our working capital for the levels of production that we are at today. We kind of like that. We’re going to generate cash. We are going to do much better next year. And I think as the hot mill project ramps up, we are going to be somewhere in that $300 million range.

componenttext: Hi, guys. I would love to get a little more color on Q4 profitability and perhaps the trajectory into the early part of ‘11, not to be so short sighted, but I recall, and correct if I am wrong with back in Q2 in July the commentary or at least my impression was that Q4 would be the best quarter of year. I am not sure, if any of the feelings have changed toward that given volumes and pricing actions of late, but if you guys could help me understand the trajectory of earnings and those comments back in Q2?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re really not giving any guidance today, Fran for the fourth quarter. We have too many issues around outside influences. The real issue on that quarter is going to be what happens from December 15 to December 31 in terms of what customers are going t
componenttext:
We’re really not giving any guidance today, Fran for the fourth quarter. We have too many issues around outside influences. The real issue on that quarter is going to be what happens from December 15 to December 31 in terms of what customers are going to do on their own cash positions. They were going to take the product if we have surcharges that are higher in January than in December. If they have their issues from whatever sources inside or outside or government regulations, taxes. This is just a quarter that is difficult and foggy.
We don’t want to get into giving guidance in this quarter other than what we’ve said and we’ve had a very thorough news release that gives you all the issues. We said there’s going to be, as we know, continuing start-up costs on the primary side, and it also says that we shouldn’t have any more one-time issues that we know of today. The commodity side, the LIFO side is a wildcard. We have our own trajectory today. We’ve got that trajectory at a $14 million LIFO reserve charge, but that could move around too. So that’s why we’re not giving guidance, Fran.
