headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Pat, I got them. I think Pat said it really quite frankly very well. The things that you just mentioned, we know that where the surcharge will be in November. We know what the trend is in terms of nickel, remember nickel isn't the only element of t
componenttext: Thanks Pat, I got them. I think Pat said it really quite frankly very well. The things that you just mentioned, we know that where the surcharge will be in November. We know what the trend is in terms of nickel, remember nickel isn't the only element of the surcharge but we know that's doing and it is likely to do in December or have a reasonable idea. I think what we don't know, quite frankly, is where the customer behavior pattern will be and Pat articulated the uncertainty, I think, that exists in short-term, you see where the average number of months inventory is on the stainless side, it's really pretty low. So customers are reacting near-term to fairly longer lead times on the stainless side than they were maybe 9 months ago, but certainly still fairly short lead times. So I think our view of the fourth quarter is that the issues that we're dealing with are the same ones that the customers are dealing with and we're going to have some cost that we incurred in the third quarter that won't be there in the fourth quarter. Pat articulated those and those are all in the earnings release. And in terms of what the volume is going to be and end up being is really going to be dependent upon what the customers -- what actions the customers do in terms of their year-end inventory management and what they need. So I think the fourth quarter is going to be the best we can make it. And we're heading into the first quarter of 2011, and 2011 quite frankly with a lot of steam and a very optimistic outlook on how 2011 looks.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually easier to talk about a longer term period than the fourth quarter right now.
componenttext: It's actually easier to talk about a longer term period than the fourth quarter right now.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: To that question, you mentioned titanium scrap prices up, surcharges [indiscernible] in Q1. Could you remind us again kind of what you anticipate average metal prices will do on the titanium side come Q1 relative to this year? And I say that mindful that
componenttext: To that question, you mentioned titanium scrap prices up, surcharges [indiscernible] in Q1. Could you remind us again kind of what you anticipate average metal prices will do on the titanium side come Q1 relative to this year? And I say that mindful that you do have quarterly surcharges [indiscernible] so some of that benefit of the rising stock has been recognized through to the year. So maybe you can give us a sense for how much is going to tie it to annual reindexing versus the quarterly surcharge with respect to your LPA and your non-LPA base business. So we can get a sense for what the price is likely to be. And then as a second part to that, if you don't mind giving us some color on any traction you've had on the titanium fastener products. Have you signed any new contracts there and what we could expect out of that?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me put some color around it. I'm not going to talk about specific price actions that we're going to take. I will say this. I will say that the first thing in a recovery of any product line or in our businesses is the return of volume. We have now seen
componenttext: Let me put some color around it. I'm not going to talk about specific price actions that we're going to take. I will say this. I will say that the first thing in a recovery of any product line or in our businesses is the return of volume. We have now seen, in 2010, the return of volume to fairly good levels and we're anticipating very good double-digit growth next year in the overall titanium market. I also mentioned that there's now projects outside of aerospace that will take very, very large volumes of sponge and melting and finished product in order to supply and they're coming from all over the world, mostly out of Asia and the Mid East. So these are big new projects that changed the dynamics of that industry. I think a changing dynamic will be the price of scrap and as you look of the price of scrap, that will influence the overall price of what sponge will sell for on a spot basis. So when we have those 2 things, those 2 things in the past, I think, we can presumably lead to price increases, both in the surcharge, in the demand and in the pricing of the products. We have seen them move rapidly in the past, in very short periods of time. So I'm not going to predict what the pricing could be, but I will reiterate anyone that has inventories of titanium will probably be glad they have them as they move into next year. So we're bullish about the titanium market in its volume and in its ability to increase revenues, unit revenues.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the fastener?
componenttext: And the fastener?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Fastener business is a business that we have had contacts on nickel basis and we've had interest from customers on our abilities to produce product. We have produced sample products across the board. We do have production orders today, and we have com
componenttext: The Fastener business is a business that we have had contacts on nickel basis and we've had interest from customers on our abilities to produce product. We have produced sample products across the board. We do have production orders today, and we have commitments on certain alloys going into 2011 and I'll just leave it at that.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Parr with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Parr with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple things and please pardon me for not being very smart about this, but we've seen titanium scrap be relatively tight all year. Again, I don't know if you can give some more color on how much you're seeing it move up here in August, September, Octob
componenttext: A couple things and please pardon me for not being very smart about this, but we've seen titanium scrap be relatively tight all year. Again, I don't know if you can give some more color on how much you're seeing it move up here in August, September, October timeframe but I'd love to give color there. And then on the other hand, you got the Boeing guys saying well we got enough titanium and we're not really going to order much more than the minimum for at least a couple of years, and you've got lots of demand and it just seems like there's a disconnect. I guess maybe there's another way for me to try to itemize this, so I can make some more sense out of it. And I'm sure you talk about this until you're blue in the face, Pat, I don't want to beat the dead horse, so to speak. But I'd really like to get your sense about how you feel the disconnect between titanium scrap and maybe some of the comments at the OEM level, how you reconcile all that?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just put some facts on the table that may frame this for you a little bit differently. Number one, in the scrap, in the United States, VSMPO and Boeing's joint venture for producing near-net parts have started up in Russia. So we've had less scrap
componenttext: Let me just put some facts on the table that may frame this for you a little bit differently. Number one, in the scrap, in the United States, VSMPO and Boeing's joint venture for producing near-net parts have started up in Russia. So we've had less scrap in the United States at least on that end of the business than what we've had in the past years. So there is some difference in what scrap 464 and aerospace products be.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the actual supply of scrap has come down?
componenttext: So the actual supply of scrap has come down?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It could be less, yes. Absolutely. Two, the industrial markets for titanium are growing very rapidly on a global basis, as I've mentioned several times here, so scrap is going to go into that kind of a market. Now in actual changes, we entered the year wi
componenttext: It could be less, yes. Absolutely. Two, the industrial markets for titanium are growing very rapidly on a global basis, as I've mentioned several times here, so scrap is going to go into that kind of a market. Now in actual changes, we entered the year with bulk weldable solid scrap around $3.50 a pound. I think the latest buy we've made is $7 -- $7 for processed bulk weldable scrap. So the fact to the matter is, the market tells you it's in short supply. I don't care what anybody else says, when you've got $7 of bulk weldables, it's different than in January, like, twice as much. We know that business is increasing next year in the double-digit rates. So as this is going to get somewhat shorter, We [indiscernible] have locked in pads, so that the scrap that we generate through our total value chain, much of it will come back to us and not go to the open market. So we have all those factors sitting out there. I think the other determination as to how much supply is at any particular customer is if there's a key phrase in there that we have to work on and I don't have any understanding than you do but the phrase goes like this, I have this much supply under current build rates. So I'm using so much today and if I add it all together that's how long it's going to take me to get down to the level I want. When I look at increasing build rates or a new program coming on or for example, let's just one customer like 175 new F-15s, I think it's F-15 or F-18. F-18s out of St. Louis that were unexpected, those are all titanium bulkheads and things like that, does that change your time to move inventories? All these things have some assumptions in them. So our information and what I'm giving you is some color that says, I think that titanium is getting momentum, scrap prices are up. We know that production will be up and there's some big projects out there that will, as they come through, can really change the dynamics of the whole thing.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so while the OEM aerospace business is providing a base load right now, there's enough other stuff going on that you're going to see growth in the interim and then when that does come on you have a leveraged upside, I guess. Is that a fair way of thin
componenttext: And so while the OEM aerospace business is providing a base load right now, there's enough other stuff going on that you're going to see growth in the interim and then when that does come on you have a leveraged upside, I guess. Is that a fair way of thinking about it?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is a fairway of thinking about it.
componenttext: That is a fairway of thinking about it.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Mark, in addition, I think a lot of people think of titanium usage in the airframe and they're thinking just of the 787 program but all of the models have some component of titanium in it and then you get in to the engine side, right? So the engine si
componenttext: And Mark, in addition, I think a lot of people think of titanium usage in the airframe and they're thinking just of the 787 program but all of the models have some component of titanium in it and then you get in to the engine side, right? So the engine side is growing. The 737 is ramping up and growing. The A320 is ramping up and growing in terms of volume. The production of the engines to match the ramp-up of the double-aisles is demanding either bigger engines that demand more and more titanium metal products per engine set. So it's more than just the 787 program. It's every model that the airframers are making and every engine that goes on those airframes, plus the aftermarket business that's there.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, the other thing that I think people have to understand is, you don't make these products out of sponge, you have to melt it and then you have to fabricated it and so the squeeze points or the pricing points will go into, in the end, product form. Ca
componenttext: Mark, the other thing that I think people have to understand is, you don't make these products out of sponge, you have to melt it and then you have to fabricated it and so the squeeze points or the pricing points will go into, in the end, product form. Can I get a piece of plate? Can get a billet? Can I get a tube? Can I get a shape? Can I get a sheet? Because this capacity constraint is going to move from the sponge, to the melting, to the fabrication of those products and the good news for the company you're talking about is, we have all those end product fabrication paths and we have capacities in those paths that other people don't have.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: One thing, this may be just a side light, but you look at the increasing mix of double-aisled and larger planes in 2012 and those engines that are being used to drive those larger airframes maybe 3x the weight, the final weight. I'm just wondering is ther
componenttext: One thing, this may be just a side light, but you look at the increasing mix of double-aisled and larger planes in 2012 and those engines that are being used to drive those larger airframes maybe 3x the weight, the final weight. I'm just wondering is there an easy way to think about the increase in titanium for those bigger engines as opposed to the increase in nickel-based alloys. I mean, is there -- is one side of the metal get more of an upside than the other?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think by weight it's still about 35, 65 something like that. The other way you really have to do it, if people just look at units -- today, if people start counting airplane programs simply by units from a metals producers' standpoint, you'll get a skew
componenttext: I think by weight it's still about 35, 65 something like that. The other way you really have to do it, if people just look at units -- today, if people start counting airplane programs simply by units from a metals producers' standpoint, you'll get a skewed answer. You really have to do what you're talking about. You have to look at the relationship of the size of the aircraft both in the engine and airframe versus the number of units. So we're in the same boat here.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask one follow-up question. And again, you guys have got so much growth and so much new programs and projects going on in '10. And you look at the Brackenridge consolidation, the ramp-up of sponge capacity, all the cost reduction momentum
componenttext: If I could just ask one follow-up question. And again, you guys have got so much growth and so much new programs and projects going on in '10. And you look at the Brackenridge consolidation, the ramp-up of sponge capacity, all the cost reduction momentum in general that you have going on. Is there anyway you can quantify how much less of this kind of start up and new sort of spending activity from a P&L standpoint, how much less of that we're going to see in '11 versus '10?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, hopefully, the startup costs in the primary side of the business will be finished by the end of the first quarter. We're going to have some ramp up costs in the sense of bringing people on and training them. But I think we'll have the process where
componenttext: Well, hopefully, the startup costs in the primary side of the business will be finished by the end of the first quarter. We're going to have some ramp up costs in the sense of bringing people on and training them. But I think we'll have the process where we want it to be, let's say, somewhere around the end of the first quarter next year. So that will go away. The operations, the consolidation in Brackenridge are complete. We're really thrilled with what we have there. In fact, we are seeing some of those savings today at the Brackenridge plant. The way we're operating the plant on the new hot mill complex is that it's a totally separate part of plant. It's fenced off. And the older part of the plant is operation independent of the new facilities. So that will have no interference or cost factors to the new side of the plant. As time goes forward on the superalloy forging facility, it's just a matter of getting more products qualified. So we could use the facility for every end product that we would like to use it for. I think the cost of start up over there is just a question of qualification.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: There was a news recently that you have gotten some defense contract also. Can you tell us, I mean, in terms of titanium, what kind of penetration or what kind of interest do you see from defense side for titanium demand?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich you want to take this?
componenttext: Rich you want to take this?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that was a DLA order for 6-4 plate. DLA is really looking at a different way of buying titanium mill products, primarily plate, in a plate product form to service some of the needs, the basic needs, of the DOD. We did win that, that was a nice win
componenttext: Yes. So that was a DLA order for 6-4 plate. DLA is really looking at a different way of buying titanium mill products, primarily plate, in a plate product form to service some of the needs, the basic needs, of the DOD. We did win that, that was a nice win for ATI. It's really one of the first initial forays, if you will, into supplying titanium product to the DLA. I think the bigger opportunities exist more on the armor side. That's where we're working using ATI 425 alloy for fabrication applications that's the comment that Pat made in his prepared comments at the AUSA show here this week. We're also working on some high hard steels for armor application. So I think the armor market is a relatively new market for ATI, it's one that we are focused on from a market sector team standpoint. I think initially, at least, the applications will be high hard steels and ATI 425 and possibly 6-4 plate as well in armor applications, primarily plate, but also the possibility of some of our casting product that comes out of our Wah Chang operations in high performance metals.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And one more question -- if I look at the margins in the HPM, you have consistently improved over the last couple of quarters along with the profitability, 150 basis points in the second quarter and then 120 basis points again in the third quarter. This i
componenttext: And one more question -- if I look at the margins in the HPM, you have consistently improved over the last couple of quarters along with the profitability, 150 basis points in the second quarter and then 120 basis points again in the third quarter. This is all I'm sequentially -- I'm talking about sequential increase. Is that, I mean, can we assume that at some point in the future you may go back to the margins we saw in '05 , '06 and '07, '06, '07 and '08 of sort of 30% type of numbers. Are you thinking it's going to be more of a volume opportunity than going to that kind of high margins?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to be both. I mean, I think certainly the margins that we're making today in that segment aren't what we expect to make in the '11, '12, '13 timeframe as we look at the full spectrum of the capabilities we have both in nickel and titani
componenttext: I think it's going to be both. I mean, I think certainly the margins that we're making today in that segment aren't what we expect to make in the '11, '12, '13 timeframe as we look at the full spectrum of the capabilities we have both in nickel and titanium specialty alloys and exotic alloys. But I think that the margin dollars, if you will, I think we've said this before, we're not planning, for example, despite what we said earlier, we're not planning for titanium scrap to be $20 a pound again, like it was in '07. But you know what, it may be. Who knows? If it is, we pay that eventually but you have a timing element there, perhaps where you have a short-term advantage but I think that the margin growth and the earnings per share growth are going to be a combination of a richer product mix, new products, including powder, higher volumes and the benefits of all the cost reductions that we put into these businesses over the years and the new products we're talking about are not only the development of the Powder business but also fastener stocks in all alloy systems, not just nickel but also titanium. And the end market growth, all of which Pat has talked about earlier. So I think, we're not, as you saw from us the last time, I think we made some prognostications before the last ramp up of where we would expect those segment margins to be and we blew through them. So I think the one thing you can rest assured of that the margins will be as good as we can make them but the earnings will come from a variety of different sources.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Yu with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Yu with Citi.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I've got 2 questions. First, at the titanium conference, there was also some comments made about substantial reductions and prior requirements on future 787 builds because of near-net shapes. I mean can you help me put this in the context of the total cos
componenttext: I've got 2 questions. First, at the titanium conference, there was also some comments made about substantial reductions and prior requirements on future 787 builds because of near-net shapes. I mean can you help me put this in the context of the total cost solution you talked about earlier and the price margin versus volume trade-off impact on ATI? And then secondly, on the high-performance metals, last quarter you mentioned that profits of growth 7% to 8% sequentially in 3Q and 4Q, we certainly saw that in third quarter results, does this continue to hold true for the fourth quarter?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's just take the first one. The interesting part about getting to near-net sizes. Unless you change the -- completely change the product form, someplace along the supply chain, the same pounds are being made. For example, you have this new machining jo
componenttext: Let's just take the first one. The interesting part about getting to near-net sizes. Unless you change the -- completely change the product form, someplace along the supply chain, the same pounds are being made. For example, you have this new machining joint venture with VSMPO and Boeing. I'm assuming Boeing's buying from that joint venture and buying much more near-net sizes, but VSMPO still has to produce the same amount of product in order to get it into that form. The same amount of metal in the industry is being used even though Boeing may not be buying it in that form. The same thing with us as Boeing comes in and asks for near-net sized shapes, we actually have improved margins on that product even though it may be less pounds that they're buying from us but when we look at the total amount of sponge that we cast, the total going into the melt, into the ingot to make that product, we're still making those units and using those capacities to produce a near-net size that is closer for the customer to buy and then we charge more for that product, but it takes the same utilization out of the industry. So it's a very complex thing to really understand. It isn't that the airplane in the total value chain will take less metal, it's the customer at the end is buying different products that he's buying less metal for more money. But the total value chain is still producing basically the same amount of product, so that's one way to look at it. I think in terms of pricing. Our price increases that we just recently announced and we just recently announced on the base price and also, that's the transaction business and also on our surcharges are pretty well set for the fourth quarter and those kind of announcements are for product that's currently being booked into the first quarter of next year, not the fourth quarter of this year.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like the improvement in unit margins should more than offset any kind of volume reduction on a net sales basis.
componenttext: So it sounds like the improvement in unit margins should more than offset any kind of volume reduction on a net sales basis.

componenttext: That will happen and you'll also see better pricing after the first of the year than you'll see in the fourth quarter.

componenttextpreview: We're really talking about product forms and you're talking about product forms that are similar but not exactly the same in terms of the end fabrication or certifications. So schedules for nickel products are well into the beginning of the first quarter.
componenttext: We're really talking about product forms and you're talking about product forms that are similar but not exactly the same in terms of the end fabrication or certifications. So schedules for nickel products are well into the beginning of the first quarter. Titanium is out a little bit further. On the flat-rolled side, you might be able to get something of those kind of products that's plate and maybe yet something this year, but if you're really talking about generally, we're booking the first quarter there also. So whether it's oil and gas or whether it's energy or whether it's jet engine, those products are all well into the first quarter. People that have maintained buffers with us or under long-term LTAs that have blocked capacity for the quarter, they may be getting their products in a shorter lead time.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Tumazos with John Tumazos Very Independent Research.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you describe the Rowley start up a little more. Are the losses steady, about the same every month or is 1 month more like 2 million, another month like 5 million? Do they vary when you try to do a longer production run and do a longer sequence? Just
componenttext: Could you describe the Rowley start up a little more. Are the losses steady, about the same every month or is 1 month more like 2 million, another month like 5 million? Do they vary when you try to do a longer production run and do a longer sequence? Just give us a flavor of your progress and state of testing, et cetera and qualification.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to give you an overview answer. Then I'll ask Rich to give you more -- if he wants to put any color on it. Basically, John, what we're doing is running sets of units and we are getting sponge from each run and then we have to make sure we h
componenttext: I'm just going to give you an overview answer. Then I'll ask Rich to give you more -- if he wants to put any color on it. Basically, John, what we're doing is running sets of units and we are getting sponge from each run and then we have to make sure we have good sponge. So in the end we have a sporadic issue if we have had a problem with a particular unit for some reason. But generally speaking, we're working on improving the yields across the board and then improving the overall quality that will get us to rotator quality. Basically, the chemistry looks -- is coming in line. It looks pretty good. We're making progress on that week-on-week, run-on-run. We have a curing issue on these vessels where the first run has some curing to do to it with a brand-new vessel coming into production versus a vessel that's under it's second or third run. And then training of people and peer process development. So I think it's a normal progression. We are making product. We are getting sponge out of the facility. We'd like better yields and we'd like better costs. So that's what we're working on. Rich, you want to add anything to that?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I just think, John, it's a fairly uniform experience. I mean the months don't vary to that magnitude. I think once we get through the end of this year and all of the 36 furnaces have at least one, if not 2 reduction runs on them and we start the lock
componenttext: No. I just think, John, it's a fairly uniform experience. I mean the months don't vary to that magnitude. I think once we get through the end of this year and all of the 36 furnaces have at least one, if not 2 reduction runs on them and we start the lock in. As Pat said, the chemistry, especially after the first run, and you kind of burn in the retort, the chemistries are really very good. I mean they're right there at rotating quality and now you really just have to go through the process of locking in the manufacturing process, getting -- once you produce that sponge cake, you've got to crush it, you've got to inspect it, you've got to get it into heat and melt it all the way through and get the chemistries of the ingot et cetera, et cetera and it's a fairly long, actually, manufacturing process. It's not just loading the tickle onto the molten mag into the retort and then after the 7 or 8 or 9-day period, you know what you've got. You've got to take it all the way through melt and it's a time-consuming process. So I think as we get to the end of this year and into the first quarter, this is going to be a facility that is going to be producing world-class sponge and we and our shareholders are going to be very happy we have it.

componenttext: Yes. I think we've said that we would be somewhere around the $300 million but we haven't locked in totally yet. There could be a project that comes along that we really, really like. I think the good news, as we look at this year, we ended this quarter with $443 million in cash. Cash seems to be coming through. We've now rebuilt all of our working capital for the levels of production that we're at today. We kind of like that. We're going to generate cash. We're going to do much better next year and I think as the hot mill project ramps up, we're going to be somewhere in that $300 million range.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd love to get a little more color on Q4 profitability and perhaps the trajectory into the early part of '11. Not to be so shortsighted but I recall, or correct me if I'm wrong, but back in Q2, in July, the commentary or at least my impression was that Q
componenttext: I'd love to get a little more color on Q4 profitability and perhaps the trajectory into the early part of '11. Not to be so shortsighted but I recall, or correct me if I'm wrong, but back in Q2, in July, the commentary or at least my impression was that Q4 would be the best quarter of the year and I'm not sure if any of the feelings have changed toward that, given volumes and pricing actions of late. But if you guys could help me understand the trajectory of earnings and those comments back in Q2?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're really not giving any guidance today, Fran, for the fourth quarter. We have too many issues around outside influences. The real issue on that quarter is going to be what happens from December 15 to December 31, in terms of what customers are going t
componenttext: We're really not giving any guidance today, Fran, for the fourth quarter. We have too many issues around outside influences. The real issue on that quarter is going to be what happens from December 15 to December 31, in terms of what customers are going to do on their own cash positions. They're going to take the product if we have surcharges that are higher in January than in December. If they have their issues from whatever sources inside or outside or government regulations, taxes. This is just a quarter that is difficult and foggy and we don't want to get into giving guidance in this quarter other than what we've said and we've had a very thorough news release that gives you all the issues. We said there's going to be, we know continuing startup costs on the primary side and it also says that we shouldn't have anymore one-time issues that we know of today and the commodities side, the LIFO side is a wildcard. We have own trajectory today. We've got that trajectory at a $14 million LIFO reserve charge, but that could move around, too. So that's why we're not giving guidance, Fran.

componenttext: And due to time constraints, this concludes our Q&A session. I would now like to hand the call back over to Pat Hassey for any closing remarks.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We thank you all for joining us today. We have a dynamic situation coming next year. We have growth coming next year. We appreciate you joining us today and we thank you for your interest and your questions about ATI.
componenttext: We thank you all for joining us today. We have a dynamic situation coming next year. We have growth coming next year. We appreciate you joining us today and we thank you for your interest and your questions about ATI.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Allegheny Technologies Earnings Conference Call. My name is Keisha, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Dan Greenfield, Senior Director of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications. Please proceed.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keisha. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Allegheny Technologies Earnings Conference Call for the Third Quarter 2010. This conference call is being broadcast on our website at www.atimetals.com. Members of the media have been invited to listen
componenttext:
Thank you, Keisha. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Allegheny Technologies Earnings Conference Call for the Third Quarter 2010. This conference call is being broadcast on our website at www.atimetals.com. Members of the media have been invited to listen to this call. 
Participating in the call today are Pat Hassey, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Rich Harshman, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Dale Reid, Senior Vice President, Finance and Principal Financial Officer.  All references to net income and earnings in this conference call mean net incomes and earnings attributable to ATI. 
After some initial comments, we will ask for questions. During the question-and-answer session, please limit yourself to two questions to be considerate of others on the line. Please note that all forward-looking statements this afternoon are subject to various assumptions and caveats as noted in the earnings release. Actual results may differ materially.
Here is Pat Hassey.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. And thanks to everyone joining us for today's call. Our key global markets are performing well. We've seen strong year-on-year recovery as sales increased 52% in the third quarter or 39% for the full year-to-date 2009. Sales for the first 9 m
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. And thanks to everyone joining us for today's call. Our key global markets are performing well. We've seen strong year-on-year recovery as sales increased 52% in the third quarter or 39% for the full year-to-date 2009. Sales for the first 9 months of 2010  are just $45 million below our sales for all of 2009. We continue to improve the efficiency of our operations. 
Cost reductions year-to-date are $102 million. We've exceeded our $100 million goal for cost reductions in 2010 in 9 months. We have a strong cash balance and a strong balance sheet. Cash on hand increased to over $443 million. Net debt to total capitalization improved to 23% and total debt to capitalization improved to 34%. Our strategy has been to target certain market sectors that we believe are in the long-term secular growth trends that are greater than the average global GDP. We still see 2010 as a transition year to the resumption of strong secular growth in those key global markets. 
Order entry and optimism has improved from several markets. We recently announced price increases for our nickel-based alloys and specialty alloys, both in long products and flat-rolled products. 
In addition, Uniti, our industrial titanium joint venture, announced a price increase for CP titanium products. Because of extending lead times, these price increases are expected to impact 2011 performance beginning in the first quarter. As we previously announced, third quarter operating profit was negatively impacted by certain issues. First is the volatile and erratic price of LME traded nickel. We booked a significant LIFO catch-up charge in the third quarter. From April to July, the average LME nickel price dropped by 26%. From July to October, it rose 23%. So we had to change our assumptions and book the charge. We now expect a full year 2010 LIFO inventory valuation reserve charge of approximately $54 million. So the third quarter, catch-up charge was an additional $33 million. Currently, we expect a $14 million LIFO charge in the fourth quarter of 2010. These LIFO charges mainly impact our flat-rolled product results.
In addition, the nickel price movement has been causing unusual buying patterns by some customers, particularly for our standard stainless products. Shipments in September were surprisingly strong. Part of this is likely due to customer buying to beat the rising October surcharge. October buying is also strong as customers are trying to beat the November surcharge increase. While month-on-month shipments are choppy, we are seeing recovery. Overall demand for standard stainless products is keeping paced with the modest GDP growth of the U.S. and European economies.
Other issues that impacted the third quarter operating profit are the startup, idle facility and major maintenance charges. High-performance metals segment operating profit was negatively impacted by approximately $12 million of startup and idle facility costs associated with our titanium sponge operations. We expect these charges to be similar in the fourth quarter. And by approximately $7 million related to a 2-week shutdown of our zirconium facilities to adjust inventory levels and perform major maintenance. We do not expect this charge to continue in the fourth quarter 2010. 
Flat-Rolled Products segment operating profit was negatively impacted by $5 million of higher than normal major maintenance expenses. We do not expect such a charge in the fourth quarter 2010. While these startup costs have been a headwind to 2010 operating profit, we expect our strategic capital projects to benefit ATI performance in 2011 and beyond. 
The melt shop consolidation at our Brackenridge, Pennsylvania melt shop is complete. We reduced the footprint and expect to benefit by up to $30 million of annualized cost reductions beginning in 2011. 
Our titanium and superalloy forge facility in Bakers, North Carolina, continues to obtain customer qualifications and adds much needed forging and finishing capacity and capabilities. Timing on completion of this project looks good as demand is strengthening from our aerospace, oil and gas and electrical energy customers. 
The ramp-up at our Rowley, Utah, premium titanium sponge facility is continuing. We are producing sponge and we are now working on standardizing the process and improving yields. We expect capital expenditures on our new hot rolling and processing facility to begin increasing in the fourth quarter of 2010, and we now expect 2010 capital investments to be approximately $250 million.
Strength in our key markets is providing the foundation for resumption of strong secular growth beginning in 2011. We believe aerospace remains a long-term growth market for ATI. Both Boeing and Airbus have announced planned increases to their production schedules. Their backlogs are strong and they are being extended by new orders. Single-aisle aircraft production rates are growing. Double-aisle aircraft rates, such as for the 777, are also growing. The 787 has been delayed, but we expect demand from this next generation aircraft to pick up throughout 2011. 
For ATI, aero engine demand is being driven by all of the aircraft schedules. In addition, aero engine spare demand is being driven by a strong recovery in passenger and freight traffic and also the growing size of a global fleet.
Now turning to the oil and gas market. U.S. and international drill rig counts continue a steady climb, driving our order backlogs and pushing out lead times for certain products. ATI revenue from this market for the first 9 months of 2010 has grown by 65% compared to the same period in 2009. In addition, direct international sales accounted for 42% of our sales to the oil and gas market during the first 9 months of 2010. 
We expect this strong demand to continue. We're seeing opportunities to supply our products, particularly specialty plate, for several large global projects. Demand is strong in our High Performance Metals segment for our specialty steels used for non-magnetic drill collars and for our nickel-based alloys for completion tools. Demand has also improved for our tungsten drilling products. 
In the Chemical Process industry, we're seeing opportunities for several large seawater desalinization plants that could potentially, significantly drive demand for CP titanium. Titanium is being considered as a substitute for copper nickel alloys in these applications.
In the electrical energy market, demand of our grain-oriented electrical steel products remained relatively flat, but at 80% capacity levels for ATI. Demands from the nuclear electrical energy market for our zirconium products has remained flat, while activity has picked up for specialty alloy plate for spent nuclear fuel storage. Orders improved for nickel-based super alloys for gas turbines in the quarter.
The medical market reached nearly 6% of sales for the first 9 months of 2010. Biomedical sales have been steady at high levels during the year. Demand was strong for our niobium titanium alloys from the medical equipment market for MRI applications. These are all very good signs for ATI. 
ATI is innovating for the future. We're adding innovative new products to improve customer productivity and so that they can make their products better and faster. We have a robust pipeline of new products. 
In 2010, we announced the first long-term agreement for the use of our new ATI 718Plus alloy for jet engine applications. We expect this innovative new alloy to grow our share in the aero-engine market, particularly as the aircraft build schedules increase. 
Following the technical and commercial rollouts of ATI 425 titanium alloy sheet and plate this summer, the team has seen a rush of technical and material inquiries from the aerospace and defense markets, as well as other high end markets. Customer interest in this new product is strong. Our customers recognize the total cost solution this new alloy can provide. Customer testing in the early stages of qualification has gone well. Process qualification adoption of a new alloy in the aerospace business will take about 12 to 18 months. 
A prototype application constructed of our new alloys is on display this week at the Army USA Annual Meeting in Washington DC. If you plan to be there, go to the AM General Display and look for a sign that reads ATI and AM General Survivability Solutions. You'll see a blast bucket that is tested and proved and made with our new materials.
We recently added titanium fasteners stock to our list of diversified product offerings. ATI now provides titanium alloy as well as nickel and specialty alloy fastener stock to the aerospace and defense market. We expect demand from the fastener supply chain to be strong, when and as airframe production ramps up to meet the new build schedules. 
We also recently commercialized another new lean duplex stainless steel, ATI 2102 lean duplex stainless steel contains even less nickel and moly than our other lean duplex ATI 2003 alloy. This is a global leader with a broad range of super duplex, duplex and lean alloys. Demand for duplex stainless steel is growing as customers look for alternatives that reduce exposure to high and volatile raw material costs. 
ATI Ludlum is working on our new with our new ATI Powder business to develop a line of borated stainless steels. Borated stainless requires a complex chemistry that is not easily melted, thus the use of powders. These alloys are used for the storage of spent nuclear fuel.
During the first 9 months of 2010, we've been navigating through some choppiness and uncertainty that often characterizes a recovery year. We see 2010 as a transition year to the resumption of strong secular growth in our key global markets. Our new assets and innovative products are setting a solid foundation for growth. 
In my personal view, I feel more optimistic today about 2011 than I did at any other time during this year, in 2010. We are now seeing more evidence that a strong recovery is underway in our key markets. Volume is up. Asset utilization is increasing and pushing out lead times. We announced several price increases that we believe will permit us to increase the returns on our available capacity. ATI is growing our share in these markets with new products. 
We're being recognized by new customers as a strategic source due to all that we can now provide and our industry-leading quality and service. We're growing our share through our market sector teams. We're better positioned than ever in the aerospace, defense, oil and gas and nuclear energy markets. Because of market demand, we introduced titanium fastener stock and near-net shapes to the aerospace business. 
We invested in the machining center at our Sheffield U.K. facility and we're now providing fully machined drill collars and other products to the oil and gas market. Demand has been terrific for this product and lead times are pushed out well into 2011. These new assets are also capable of machining our products for the aerospace and defense industry. 
The actions we have taken allow us to improve our share and grow faster than the markets we have identified that have secular growth trends that are greater than the global average GDP. Frankly, we feel very good about 2011 and beyond. However, factors beyond our control really impact our short-term visibility. Because of so much uncertainty, particularly in the U.S. and the volatility of many raw material prices, we cannot predict the actions of our customers, particularly in the final weeks of this year. It's just uncertain. 
For example, will customers add inventory, maintain current inventory levels or reduce? Will their actions be impacted in the short-term by the uncertainty lame duck congress, actions by the Federal Reserve, uncertain regulatory environment or other outside or internal factors of their business? The answer to that is, I just don't know. 
What I do have is a strong conviction that 2011 will be far better for ATI than 2010, that 2012 will be better than 2011, and that 2013 continues and will be far better than 2012. So we have a very optimistic view of the long-term prospects starting next year and beginning to go forward. 
I think that's enough comments for me, and we'll open up the meeting now for any questions anyone might have.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Timna Tanners from UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Timna Tanners from UBS.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions from me, wanted to ask about how you're seeing the impact of new capacity coming from the Thyssen stainless mill? The second one is really in response to the article we saw on American Metal Market on the sidelines of the titanium confere
componenttext: Just 2 questions from me, wanted to ask about how you're seeing the impact of new capacity coming from the Thyssen stainless mill? The second one is really in response to the article we saw on American Metal Market on the sidelines of the titanium conference talking about Boeing's outlook for restocking being several years away, and your thoughts on that as well.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's jump on the first one, which is the Thyssen facilities. Thyssen is just starting up those facilities. As you know, they have a fairly strong position in the U.S. today with their Mexinox operations and also imports coming in from Europe and other ar
componenttext: Let's jump on the first one, which is the Thyssen facilities. Thyssen is just starting up those facilities. As you know, they have a fairly strong position in the U.S. today with their Mexinox operations and also imports coming in from Europe and other areas through Canada into the country. So this whole facility, in our view, in Alabama, is to streamline their operations and to bring stainless into their market that they already have a large share of today. So they're starting up their first mill. What they're doing as we've heard at this point in time, is it's a test, they're taking basically small orders. They're not trimming the orders or looking for confirmation of the quality out of this piece of equipment. And they're basically in the cold rolling stage. They're actually bringing in white coils out of Germany, so they're not even being hot rolled. Eventually they'll be bringing in slab from German to roll here and they'll roll it on their new hot rolling facilities and then they'll finish it in their cold rolling facilities. We think Thyssen is a good competitor. I think they're a good company. They provide a good product, and I don't think it changes much in the U.S. market except for their cost structure. The second question on Boeing restocking. I don't know if there's a restocking issue but Boeing has certainly a growing issue. So what we see is that these airplane programs are booked to the future. They're going to continue to ramp. We have a situation next year that the 787, for all practical purposes, is going to ramp up throughout 2011. They're increasing their production in their single-aisles going forward, in the 777 and 747-8. So whatever inventories that they have on hand, those inventories are going to be coming down. In our particular circumstances, we have agreements to supply that customer at certain levels. Those agreements call for take or pay volumes at certain levels and prices, and so we will be producing at least to those volumes as we go forward. I think there's also good possibilities that as the rest of the titanium business, as we see it, begins to ramp on these new projects throughout the world, that continuing supplies will start to see prices moving up, scrap prices are moving up now. I think one supplier just announced price increases for next year on sponge. We see rising scrap prices in our own domestic markets, which makes our investments in sponge look better to us every day. So I think as this market ramps up, Boeing is going to be happy they have any excess inventory on hand as the market ramps up for the production levels that we see coming throughout the industry, not just the aerospace industry but throughout the world, including the desalinization projects, chemical processing projects that we are now seeing coming on the books and being asked for and starting in 2011, '12 and '13. So we feel pretty good about the overall supply demand relationship regardless of Boeing.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question, I just want to talk about titanium sponge a bit more, and firstly just your Rowley sponge facility. Can you give us an update as far as the progress in getting the products that are certified for rotor quality products? And then secondly,
componenttext: First question, I just want to talk about titanium sponge a bit more, and firstly just your Rowley sponge facility. Can you give us an update as far as the progress in getting the products that are certified for rotor quality products? And then secondly, just the overall sponge sourcing strategy for 2011, if I remember correctly, I think you have some third-party contract that's rolling off. And just curious to see if you're going to be trying to supply more internally through Rowley or if you extended that contract or what's going on there?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just start it this way. It looks like our mill product shipments, including Uniti's conversion in 2010 are going to approach quantities in the high 30s. So we're going to have 37 million, 38 million pounds of final production shipped this yea
componenttext: Well, let me just start it this way. It looks like our mill product shipments, including Uniti's conversion in 2010 are going to approach quantities in the high 30s. So we're going to have 37 million, 38 million pounds of final production shipped this year. That number is going to increase substantially as we look at production in 2011. We're talking volumes way up in double digits. So we need sponge and we need the production out of Rowley, and we also have a fairly large amount of production coming in from outside the company, which we've always said that we're going to do because we do not have enough sponge on hand to handle our own fully loaded product lines. We still see titanium moving up into quantities over this next '11, '12 and '13, but we think we will be shipping 60 million pounds of finished product, including our Uniti joint ventures. So you see where we're coming from in overall sponge capacity. We will continue to buy on the outside. So with the Rowley facility, our goal is to get that plant up and running, rotating quality, making rotating quality sponge. In order to do that, we have to have a standardized process that is in control and capable of producing rotating quality each and every day of the week across all 36 sets of units there. So where we are today? We're in production. We are still continuing to develop that process, but we feel that we have it in control and capable and locked in on making rotating quality parts. Until we have that process locked in, then the product that we're producing goes to lower grade products, such as B quality, or aircraft frame quality, or industrial quality titanium. So there's 2 things that are happening, we're locking in the processes we need to produce the rotating quality. We're getting the equipment capable and under control. And we're working on ways to make sure that we have the right yields and the right recoveries out of what we're doing. So this is a process that we're continuing to improve, and hopefully early next year we'll have what we want in place and we'll begin the qualification process for rotating quality.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just secondly, just I'm curious to know what happened with the nickel-based alloy titanium shipments sequentially. We had seen a decline there. Can you give us a feel for what happened? What was the moving parts there? And then, maybe what
componenttext: Okay. And then just secondly, just I'm curious to know what happened with the nickel-based alloy titanium shipments sequentially. We had seen a decline there. Can you give us a feel for what happened? What was the moving parts there? And then, maybe what we can expect in fourth quarter and then in 2011?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what you've seen is product mix shifts from one category of finished product to a different one. We're selling a lot less ingot. We're selling more fabricated parts, so that moves the tonnage around on the titanium side. We've seen a lot more nick
componenttext: I think what you've seen is product mix shifts from one category of finished product to a different one. We're selling a lot less ingot. We're selling more fabricated parts, so that moves the tonnage around on the titanium side. We've seen a lot more nickel growth into the third quarter. We'll see that into the fourth quarter. I think we are seeing nickel growing into the fourth quarter and we're going to see titanium kind of staying flat and up in the aero engine side down in airframe side throughout the end of the year. A lot of this is determined by needs of customers into the first quarter. So answering your second part about the first quarter. We think that we're going to ramp fairly quickly next year into these higher quantities beginning early in the year. And we've kind of looked at the fourth quarter, as I mentioned earlier, ending the year somewhere 37 million to 38 million pounds. So we've shipped 29 million, so far, including conversion work. It shifts back and forth between forms, whether it's going to be sheet, plate, rounds, whatever. So it's mix and it's end markets. We're supplying a lot of metal outside the aerospace market these days. So oil and gas, it's chemical processing, it's airframe, it's aero engine. So all those factors are moving parts.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. What sort of volumes are you thinking about in terms of the desalination opportunities?
componenttext: Okay. What sort of volumes are you thinking about in terms of the desalination opportunities?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Those are huge volumes. Each one of those facilities, assuming that the copper nickel is replaced by titanium. And the reason for that is that in the Middle East area in warm saltwater titanium is performing very well. Copper is leaching into the oceans a
componenttext: Those are huge volumes. Each one of those facilities, assuming that the copper nickel is replaced by titanium. And the reason for that is that in the Middle East area in warm saltwater titanium is performing very well. Copper is leaching into the oceans and you have fish problems and all that kind of things. So suddenly we have a brand-new market that is not a new market but it's a really brand-new great market for titanium products. Each one of these desalination plants, if you could visualize it in your mind between all the equipment that goes into this and the power units that run it and the size of the pieces of equipment that condense and change and distill and all these kinds of things, it's about a block long. There's all the tubing, all the piping that come from the ocean in. And when you talk about a project here, you're talking millions of pounds of titanium. I mean by millions of pounds, 12 million to 15 million of titanium at a time. These are huge projects, changes the dynamics of the entire titanium supply.

componenttextpreview: On the Powder Metals business that you bought a little bit more than a year ago, do you feel you're on the timetable there that you expected to be on?

componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. Tell me -- I'm sorry, I missed your question. Powder Metals? Powder Metals is fitting in great. These are super scientist kind of guys. We are looking at those guys as how they can improve products and move our product mix up across all of our
componenttext: I'm sorry. Tell me -- I'm sorry, I missed your question. Powder Metals? Powder Metals is fitting in great. These are super scientist kind of guys. We are looking at those guys as how they can improve products and move our product mix up across all of our product forms. They're now, as you saw, as you may have seen, we have moved them into as a sub-business unit of ATI Allvac. So they're working directly in the aero engine business and in the airframe business. They're also working on the borated stainless sheet and plate, and they have other development projects for other jet engine customers and government projects in all kinds of things. So this was a great fit for us. We like the technology. It was needed in the company. We think it's a product of the future, growing each year, and the integration into ATI has been very successful.

componenttext: I'll let Dale Reid take that question.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, regarding pensions. As you know, basically, there are a couple of factors that come into the calculation. One is what's happening on the asset side, and so far our asset returns this year have been fairly good. But we won't know what that final num
componenttext: Steve, regarding pensions. As you know, basically, there are a couple of factors that come into the calculation. One is what's happening on the asset side, and so far our asset returns this year have been fairly good. But we won't know what that final number is going to be, obviously, until we reach the end of the year. The other factor, obviously, is the point in time determination of the discount rate. We've obviously seen interest rates come down over the course of the year but depending upon what happens with the Fed and what happens with interest rates between now and the end of the year, we will see where that comes out. Obviously, declining interest rates are not helpful to us from a pension expense standpoint. But to some extent, those are somewhat offset by what happens on the asset side. So, sitting here right now, it's a little bit too early to tell where we're going to end up the year, so we'll have to wait and see.
