headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat, I got them. I think Pat said it really, quite frankly, very well. The things that you just mentioned, we know that where the surcharge will be in November. We know what the trend is in terms of nickel, remember nickel isn't the only element o
componenttext: Thanks, Pat, I got them. I think Pat said it really, quite frankly, very well. The things that you just mentioned, we know that where the surcharge will be in November. We know what the trend is in terms of nickel, remember nickel isn't the only element of the surcharge but we know what that's doing and is likely to do in December or have a reasonable idea. I think what we don't know, quite frankly, is where the customer behavior pattern will be. And Pat articulated the uncertainty, I think, that exists in short-term. You see where the average number of months inventory is on the stainless side, it's really pretty low. So customers are reacting near-term to fairly longer lead times on the stainless side than they were maybe 9 months ago, but certainly still fairly short lead times. So I think our view of the fourth quarter is that the issues that we're dealing with are the same ones that the customers are dealing with. And we're going to have some cost that we incurred in the third quarter that won't be there in the fourth quarter. Pat articulated those and those are all in the earnings release. And in terms of what the volume is going to be, end up being, is really going to be dependent upon what the customers, what actions the customers do in terms of their year-end inventory management and what they need. So I think the fourth quarter is going to be the best we can make it. And we're heading into the first quarter of 2011, and 2011 quite frankly, with a lot of steam and a very optimistic outlook on how 2011 looks.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually easier to talk about a longer term period than the fourth quarter right now.
componenttext: It's actually easier to talk about a longer term period than the fourth quarter right now.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: To that question, you mentioned titanium scrap prices up, surcharges prices reset in Q1. Could you remind us again kind of what you anticipate average metal prices will do on the titanium side come Q1 relative to this year? And I say that mindful that you
componenttext: To that question, you mentioned titanium scrap prices up, surcharges prices reset in Q1. Could you remind us again kind of what you anticipate average metal prices will do on the titanium side come Q1 relative to this year? And I say that mindful that you do have quarterly surcharges at Allvac, so some of that benefit of the rising stock has been recognized through to the year. So maybe you can give us a sense for how much is going to tie to annual reindexing versus the quarterly surcharge with respect to your LPA and your non-LPA base business. So we can get a sense for what the price reset is likely to be. And then as a second part to that, if you don't mind giving us some color on any traction you've had on the titanium fastener products. Have you signed any new contracts there, and what we could expect out of that?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me put some color around it. I'm not going to talk about specific price actions that we're going to take. I will say this. I will say that the first thing in a recovery of any product line or in our businesses is the return of volume. We have now seen
componenttext: Let me put some color around it. I'm not going to talk about specific price actions that we're going to take. I will say this. I will say that the first thing in a recovery of any product line or in our businesses is the return of volume. We have now seen, in 2010, the return of volume to fairly good levels and we're anticipating very good double-digit growth next year in the overall titanium market. I also mentioned that there's now projects outside of aerospace that will take very, very large volumes of sponge and melting and finished product in order to supply. And they're coming from all over the world, mostly out of Asia and the Mid East. So these are big new projects that change the dynamics of that industry. I think a changing dynamic will be the price of scrap. And as you look of the price of scrap, that will influence the overall price of what sponge will sell for on a spot basis. So when we have those 2 things, those 2 things in the past, I think, we can presume lead to price increases, both in the surcharge, in the demand and in the pricing of the product. We have seen them move rapidly in the past, in very short periods of time. So I'm not going to predict what the pricing could be, but I will reiterate anyone that has inventories of titanium will probably be glad they have them as they move into next year. So we're bullish about the titanium market in its volume and in its ability to increase revenues, unit revenues.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the fastener?
componenttext: And the fastener?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Fastener business is a business that we have had contacts in on a nickel basis over the years, and we've had interest from our customers on our abilities to produce product. We have produced sample products across the board. We do have production orde
componenttext: The Fastener business is a business that we have had contacts in on a nickel basis over the years, and we've had interest from our customers on our abilities to produce product. We have produced sample products across the board. We do have production orders today, and we have commitments on certain alloys going into 2011. And I'll just leave it at that.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Parr with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Parr with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple things, and please pardon me for not being very smart about this, but we've seen titanium scrap be relatively tight all year. And again, I don't know if you can give some more color on how much you're seeing it move up here in the August, Septemb
componenttext: A couple things, and please pardon me for not being very smart about this, but we've seen titanium scrap be relatively tight all year. And again, I don't know if you can give some more color on how much you're seeing it move up here in the August, September, October timeframe but I'd love to give color there. And then on the other hand, you got the Boeing guys saying, Well, we got enough titanium and we're not really going to order much more than the minimum for at least a couple of years. And you've got lots of demand, and it just seems like there's a disconnect. I guess maybe there's another way for me to try to itemize this so I can make some more sense out of it. And I'm sure you talk about this until you're blue in the face, Pat, and I don't want to beat the dead horse, so to speak. But I'd really like to get your sense about how you feel the disconnect between titanium scrap and maybe some of the comments at the OEM level, how you reconcile all that?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just put some facts on the table that may frame this for you a little bit differently. Number one, in the scrap, in the United States, VSMPO and Boeing's joint venture for producing near-net parts have started up in Russia. So we've had less scrap
componenttext: Let me just put some facts on the table that may frame this for you a little bit differently. Number one, in the scrap, in the United States, VSMPO and Boeing's joint venture for producing near-net parts have started up in Russia. So we've had less scrap in the United States at least on that end of the business than what we've had in the past years. So there is some difference in what scrap 464 and aerospace products need.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the actual supply of scrap has come down?
componenttext: So the actual supply of scrap has come down?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It could be less, yes. Absolutely. Two, the industrial markets for titanium are growing very rapidly on a global basis, as I've mentioned several times here, so scrap is going to go into that kind of a market. Now in actual changes, we entered the year wi
componenttext: It could be less, yes. Absolutely. Two, the industrial markets for titanium are growing very rapidly on a global basis, as I've mentioned several times here, so scrap is going to go into that kind of a market. Now in actual changes, we entered the year with bulk weldable solid scrap around $3.50 a pound. I think the latest buy we've made is $7, $7 for processed bulk weldable scrap. So the fact to the matter is, the market tells you it's in short supply. I don't care what anybody else says, when you've got $7 of bulk weldables, it's different than in January, like twice as much. We know that business is increasing next year in the double-digit rates. So it's just going to get somewhat shorter. We in our own revert paths have locked in pads so that the scrap that we generate through our total value chain, much of it will come back to us and not go to the open market. So we have all those factors sitting out there. I think the other determination as to how much supply is at any particular customer, is there's a key phrase in there that we have to work on. And I don't have any better understanding than you do but the phrase goes like this, I have this much supply under current build rates. So I'm using so much today and if I add it all together that's how long it's going to take me to get down to the level I want. When I look at increasing build rates or a new program coming on, or for example let's just use one customer like the 175 new F-15s -- I think it's F-15 or F-18 -- F-18s out of St. Louis that were unexpected, those are all titanium bulkheads and things like that, does that change your time to move inventories? All these things have some assumptions in them. So our information and what I'm giving you is some color that says, I think that titanium is getting momentum, scrap prices are up. We know that production will be up. And there's some big projects out there that will, as they come through, can really change the dynamics of the whole thing.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so while the OEM aerospace business is providing a base load right now, there's enough other stuff going on that you're going to see growth in the interim. And then when that does come on you have a leveraged upside, I guess. Is that a fair way of thi
componenttext: And so while the OEM aerospace business is providing a base load right now, there's enough other stuff going on that you're going to see growth in the interim. And then when that does come on you have a leveraged upside, I guess. Is that a fair way of thinking about it?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is a fair way of thinking about it.
componenttext: That is a fair way of thinking about it.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Mark, in addition, I mean I think when you -- I think a lot of people think of titanium usage and the airframe and they're thinking just of the 787 program. But there's all of the models have some component of titanium in it, and then you get in to th
componenttext: And Mark, in addition, I mean I think when you -- I think a lot of people think of titanium usage and the airframe and they're thinking just of the 787 program. But there's all of the models have some component of titanium in it, and then you get in to the engine side, right? So the engine side is growing. The 737 is ramping up and growing. The A320 is ramping up and growing in terms of volume. The production of the engines to match the ramp-up of the double-aisles is demanding either bigger engines that demand more and more titanium metal products per engine set. So it's more than just the 787 program. It's every model that the airframers are making and every engine that goes on those airframes, plus the aftermarket business that's there.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, the other thing that I think people have to understand is, you don't make these products out of sponge. You have to melt it and then you have to fabricate it. And so the squeeze points or the pricing points will go into, in the end, product form. Ca
componenttext: Mark, the other thing that I think people have to understand is, you don't make these products out of sponge. You have to melt it and then you have to fabricate it. And so the squeeze points or the pricing points will go into, in the end, product form. Can I get a piece of plate? Can get a billet? Can I get a tube? Can I get a shape? Can I get a sheet? Because this capacity constraint is going to move from the sponge, to the melting, to the fabrication of those products. And the good news for the company you're talking about is that we have all those end product fabrication paths, and we have capacities in those paths that other people don't have.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: One thing, this may be just a side light, but you look at the increasing mix of double-aisled and larger planes in 2012, and those engines that are being used to drive those larger airframes may be 3x the weight, the final weight. I'm just wondering, is t
componenttext: One thing, this may be just a side light, but you look at the increasing mix of double-aisled and larger planes in 2012, and those engines that are being used to drive those larger airframes may be 3x the weight, the final weight. I'm just wondering, is there an easy way to think about the increase in titanium for those bigger engines as opposed to the increase in nickel-based alloys. I mean, is there -- does one side of the metal get more of an upside than the other?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think by weight it's still about 35, 65, something like that. The other way you really have to do it, if people just look at units -- today, if people start counting airplane programs simply by units from a metals producers' standpoint, you'll get a ske
componenttext: I think by weight it's still about 35, 65, something like that. The other way you really have to do it, if people just look at units -- today, if people start counting airplane programs simply by units from a metals producers' standpoint, you'll get a skewed answer. You really have to do what you're talking about. You have to look at the relationship of the size of the aircraft both in the engine and airframe versus the number of units. So we're in the same boat here.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask one follow-up question. And again, you guys have got so much growth and so much new programs and projects going on in '10. And you look at the Brackenridge consolidation, the ramp-up of sponge capacity, all the cost reduction momentum
componenttext: If I could just ask one follow-up question. And again, you guys have got so much growth and so much new programs and projects going on in '10. And you look at the Brackenridge consolidation, the ramp-up of sponge capacity, all the cost reduction momentum in general that you have going on. Is there any way you can quantify how much less of this kind of start up and new sort of spending activity from a P&L standpoint, how much less of that we're going to see in '11 versus '10?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, all the, hopefully, the startup costs in the primary side of the business will be finished by the end of the first quarter. We're going to have some ramp up costs in the sense of bringing people on and training them. But I think we'll have the proce
componenttext: Well, all the, hopefully, the startup costs in the primary side of the business will be finished by the end of the first quarter. We're going to have some ramp up costs in the sense of bringing people on and training them. But I think we'll have the process where we want it to be, let's say, somewhere around the end of the first quarter next year. So that will go away. The operations, the consolidation in Brackenridge are complete. We're really thrilled with what we have there. In fact, we are seeing some of those savings today at the Brackenridge plant. The way we're operating the plant on the new hot mill complex is that it's a totally separate part of plant. It's fenced off. And the older part of the plant is operating independent of the new facilities. So that will have no interference or cost factors to the new side of the plant. As time goes forward on the superalloy forging facility, it's just a matter of getting more products qualified. So we could use the facility for every end product that we would like to use it for. I think the cost of startup over there is just a question of qualification.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttextpreview: There was news recently that you have done some defense contract also. Can you tell us, I mean, in terms of titanium, what kind of penetration or what kind of interest do you see from defense side for titanium demand?
componenttext: There was news recently that you have done some defense contract also. Can you tell us, I mean, in terms of titanium, what kind of penetration or what kind of interest do you see from defense side for titanium demand?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, you want to take this?
componenttext: Rich, you want to take this?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that was a DLA order for 6-4 plate. DLA is really looking at a different way of buying titanium mill products, primarily plate, in a plate product form, to service some of the needs, the basic needs, of the DOD. We did win that. That was a nice wi
componenttext: Yes. So that was a DLA order for 6-4 plate. DLA is really looking at a different way of buying titanium mill products, primarily plate, in a plate product form, to service some of the needs, the basic needs, of the DOD. We did win that. That was a nice win for ATI. It's really one of the first initial forays, if you will, into supplying titanium product to the DLA. I think the bigger opportunities exist more on the armor side. That's where we're working using ATI 425 alloy for fabrication applications, that's the comment that Pat made in his prepared comments, at the AUSA show here this week. We're also working on some high hard steels for armor application. So I think the armor market is a relatively new market for ATI, it's one that we are focused on from a market sector team standpoint. I think initially at least, the applications will be high hard steels and ATI 425, and possibly 6-4 plate as well. In armor applications, primarily plate, but also the possibility of some of our casting product that comes out of our Wah Chang operations in high performance metals.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one more question on the -- if I look at the margins in the HPM, you have consistently improved over the last couple of quarters along with the profitability, 150 basis points in the second quarter and then 120 basis points again in the third qu
componenttext: Okay. And one more question on the -- if I look at the margins in the HPM, you have consistently improved over the last couple of quarters along with the profitability, 150 basis points in the second quarter and then 120 basis points again in the third quarter. This is all I'm -- sequentially, I'm talking about, sequential increase. Is that, I mean, can we assume that at some point in the future you may go back to the margins we saw in '05 , '06 and '07, '06, '07 and '08, of sort of 30% type of numbers. Are you thinking it's going to be more of a volume opportunity than going to that kind of high margins?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to be both. I mean, I think certainly the margins that we're making today in that segment aren't what we expect to make in the '11, '12, '13 timeframe, as we look at the full spectrum of the capabilities we have both in nickel and titan
componenttext: I think it's going to be both. I mean, I think certainly the margins that we're making today in that segment aren't what we expect to make in the '11, '12, '13 timeframe, as we look at the full spectrum of the capabilities we have both in nickel and titanium and specialty alloys and exotic alloys. But I think that the margin dollars, if you will, I think we've said this before, we're not planning, for example, despite what we said earlier, we're not planning for titanium scrap to be $20 a pound again, like it was in '07. But you know what, it may be. Who knows? If it is, we pay that eventually but you have a timing element there, perhaps, where you have a short-term advantage. But I think that the margin growth and the earnings per share growth are going to be a combination of a richer product mix, new products, including powder, higher volumes, and the benefits of all the cost reductions that we put into these businesses over the years. And the new products we're talking about are not only the development of the Powder business but also fastener stocks in all alloy systems, not just nickel but also titanium. And the end market growth, all of which Pat has talked about earlier. So I think, we're not -- as you saw from us the last time, I think we made some prognostications before the last ramp up of where we would expect those segment margins to be and we blew through them. So I think the one thing you can rest assured of, that the margins will be as good as we can make them but the earnings will come from a variety of different sources.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Yu with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Yu with Citi.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I've got 2 questions. First, at the titanium conference, there was also some comments made about substantial reductions and prior requirements on future 787 builds because of near-net shapes. I mean can you help me put this in the context of the total cos
componenttext: I've got 2 questions. First, at the titanium conference, there was also some comments made about substantial reductions and prior requirements on future 787 builds because of near-net shapes. I mean can you help me put this in the context of the total cost solution you talked about earlier and the price margin versus volume trade-off impact on ATI? And then secondly, on the high-performance metals, last quarter you mentioned that profits of growth 7% to 8% sequentially in 3Q and 4Q, we certainly saw that in third quarter results, does this continue to hold true for the fourth quarter?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's just take the first one. The interesting part about getting to near-net size is unless you change the -- completely change the product form, someplace along the supply chain, the same pounds are being made. For example, you have this new machining j
componenttext: Let's just take the first one. The interesting part about getting to near-net size is unless you change the -- completely change the product form, someplace along the supply chain, the same pounds are being made. For example, you have this new machining joint venture with VSMPO and Boeing. I'm assuming Boeing's buying from that joint venture and buying much more near-net sizes, but VSMPO still has to produce the same amount of product in order to get it into that form. The same amount of metal in the industry is being used even though Boeing may not be buying it in that form. The same thing with us as Boeing comes in and asks for near-net sized shapes, we actually have improved margins on that product even though it may be less pounds that they're buying from us, but when we look at the total amount of sponge that we cast, the total going into the melt, into the ingot to make that product, we're still making those units and using those capacities to produce a near-net size that is closer for the customer to buy and then we charge more for that product, but it takes the same utilization out of the industry. So it's a very complex thing to really understand. It isn't that the airplane in the total value chain will take less metal, it's the customer at the end is buying different products that he's buying less metal for more money. But the total value chain is still producing, basically, the same amount of product. So that's one way to look at it. I think in terms of pricing. Our price increases that we just recently announced and just recently announced on the base price, and also that's the transaction business, and also on our surcharges are pretty well set for the fourth quarter. And those kind of announcements are for product that's currently being booked into the first quarter of next year, not the fourth quarter of this year.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it sounds like the improvement in unit margins should more than offset any kind of volume reduction on a net sales basis.
componenttext: Okay. So it sounds like the improvement in unit margins should more than offset any kind of volume reduction on a net sales basis.

componenttext: That will happen. And you'll also see better pricing after the first of the year than you'll see in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: One of the earlier questions you responded by saying the lead times are about double out to about 16 or 20 weeks. headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well,  we're really talking about product forms. And you're talking about product forms that are similar but not exactly the same in terms of the end fabrication or certifications. So schedules for nickel products are well into the beginning of the first
componenttext: Well,  we're really talking about product forms. And you're talking about product forms that are similar but not exactly the same in terms of the end fabrication or certifications. So schedules for nickel products are well into the beginning of the first quarter. Titanium is out a little bit further. On the flat-rolled side, you might be able to get something of those kind of products that's plate and maybe yet something this year, but if you're really talking about generally, we're booking the first quarter there also. So whether it's oil and gas or whether it's energy or whether it's jet engine, those products are all well into the first quarter. People that have maintained buffers with us or under long-term LTAs that have blocked capacity for the quarter, they may be getting their products in a shorter lead time.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Tumazos with John Tumazos Very Independent Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Tumazos with John Tumazos Very Independent Research.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you describe the Rowley startup a little more. Are the losses steady, about the same every month or is 1 month more like 2 million, another month like 5 million? Do they vary when you try to do a longer production run and do a longer sequence? And j
componenttext: Could you describe the Rowley startup a little more. Are the losses steady, about the same every month or is 1 month more like 2 million, another month like 5 million? Do they vary when you try to do a longer production run and do a longer sequence? And just give us a flavor of your progress and state of testing, et cetera, and qualification.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to give you an overview answer. Then I'll ask Rich to give you a more -- if he wants to put any color on it. Basically, John, what we're doing is running sets of units and we are getting sponge from each run and then we have to make sure we
componenttext: I'm just going to give you an overview answer. Then I'll ask Rich to give you a more -- if he wants to put any color on it. Basically, John, what we're doing is running sets of units and we are getting sponge from each run and then we have to make sure we have good sponge. So in the end we have a sporadic issue if we have had a problem with a particular unit for some reason. But generally speaking, we're working on improving the yields across the board and then improving the overall quality that will get us to rotator quality. Basically, the chemistry looks -- is coming in line. It looks pretty good. We're making progress on that week-on-week, run-on-run. We have a curing issue on these vessels where the first run has some curing to do to it with a brand-new vessel coming into production versus a vessel that's under its second or third run. And then training of people and peer process development. So I think it's a normal progression. We are making product. We are getting sponge out of the facility. We'd like better yields and we'd like better costs. So that's what we're working on. Rich, you want to add anything to that?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I just think, John, it's a fairly uniform experience. I mean the months don't vary to that magnitude. I think once we get through the end of this year and all of the 36 furnace sets have at least one, if not 2 reduction runs on them and we start the l
componenttext: No. I just think, John, it's a fairly uniform experience. I mean the months don't vary to that magnitude. I think once we get through the end of this year and all of the 36 furnace sets have at least one, if not 2 reduction runs on them and we start the lock in. As Pat said, the chemistries, especially after the first run, and you kind of burn in the retort, the chemistries are really very good. I mean, they're right there at rotating quality. And now you really just have to go through the process of locking in the manufacturing process, getting -- once you produce that sponge cake, you've got to crush it, you've got to inspect it, you've got to get it into heat and melt it all the way through and get the chemistries of the ingot, et cetera, et cetera. And it's a fairly long, actually, manufacturing process. It's not just loading the tickle on the molten mag into the retort and then after the 7 or 8 or 9-day period, you know what you've got. You've got to take it all the way through melt, and it's a time-consuming process. So I think as we get to the end of this year and into the first quarter, this is going to be a facility that is going to be producing world-class sponge. And we and our shareholders are going to be very happy we have it.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Levy with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Levy with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Have you sort of put rough thoughts down to 2011 and 2012 CapEx?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we've said that we would be somewhere around the $300 million but we haven't locked in totally yet. There could be a project that comes along that we really, really like. I think the good news, as we look at this year, we ended this quarter w
componenttext: Yes. I think we've said that we would be somewhere around the $300 million but we haven't locked in totally yet. There could be a project that comes along that we really, really like. I think the good news, as we look at this year, we ended this quarter with $443 million in cash. Cash seems to be coming through. We've now rebuilt all of our working capital for the levels of production that we're at today. We kind of like that. We're going to generate cash. We're going to do much better next year. And I think as the hot mill project ramps up, we're going to be somewhere in that $300 million range.

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd love to get a little more color on Q4 profitability and perhaps the trajectory into the early part of '11. Not to be so shortsighted but I recall, or correct me if I'm wrong, but back in Q2, in July, the commentary, or at least my impression was that
componenttext: I'd love to get a little more color on Q4 profitability and perhaps the trajectory into the early part of '11. Not to be so shortsighted but I recall, or correct me if I'm wrong, but back in Q2, in July, the commentary, or at least my impression was that Q4 would be the best quarter of the year. And I'm not sure if any of the feelings have changed toward that, given volumes and pricing actions of late. But if you guys could help me understand the trajectory of earnings and those comments back in Q2?

headline: Allegheny Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're really not giving any guidance today, Fran, for the fourth quarter. We have too many issues around outside influences. The real issue on that quarter is going to be what happens from December 15 to December 31, in terms of what customers are going t
componenttext: We're really not giving any guidance today, Fran, for the fourth quarter. We have too many issues around outside influences. The real issue on that quarter is going to be what happens from December 15 to December 31, in terms of what customers are going to do on their own cash positions, they're going to take the product, if we have surcharges that are higher in January than in December. If they have their issues from whatever sources inside or outside, or government regulations, taxes. This is just a quarter that is difficult and foggy. And we don't want to get into giving guidance in this quarter other than what we've said. And we've had a very thorough news release that gives you all the issues. We said there's going to be, we know continuing startup costs on the primary side. And it also says that we shouldn't have anymore one-time issues that we know of today. And the commodities side, the LIFO side is a wildcard. We have own trajectory today. We've got that trajected at a $14 million LIFO reserve charge, but that could move around, too. So that's why we're not giving guidance, Fran.

componenttext: We thank you, all, for joining us today. We have a dynamic situation coming next year. We have growth coming next year. We appreciate you joining us today, and we thank you for your interest and your questions about ATI.
